                                                          GLOSSARY OF TERMS


attemperator                                       coil of pipe through which hot or cold water may be run for
                                                   regulating temperature

bridging                                           compaction of material at the base of a hopper that can inter-
                                                   fere with the flow of contents

combustion grate                                   horizontal system of platforms used for conveying and mixing
                                                   solid waste in the furnace during drying, igniting, and burning
                                                   process

deaerator                                          device used for removal of air and other dissolved gases from
                                                   the feedwater to steam-generating boilers

gland steam condenser                              heat exchanger that minimizes steam leakage and prevents air
                                                   ingress in the steam turbine system

riddlings                                          smaller materials that fall from the combustion grate through
                                                   the grate openings (same as siftings)

siftings                                           smaller materials that fall from the combustion grate through
                                                   the grate openings (same as riddlings)

small quantities                                   waste material commingled and/or mixed with other
                                                   processible waste that cannot be safely removed from the
                                                   waste stream

superheater                                        device used to convert saturated steam or wet steam into dry
                                                   steam used for power generation or processes

sewage sludge                                      treated sludge and incidental grease that originates from a
                                                   wastewater treatment plant

cess of the Frederick/Carroll County Renewable Waste-to-Energy Facility in Frederick
County, Maryland, attest that this engineering report plan has been prepared under my
supervision in accordance with good engineering practices, and that the information con-
tained herein is true and accurate to best of my knowledge.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.      ix              Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
                                                          1.0 INTRODUCTION


Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc. (WTI), has entered into a contract with the Northeast
Maryland Waste Disposal Authority (NEA) to develop, construct, and operate the nomi-
nal 1,500-ton-per-day (tpd) Frederick/Carroll County Renewable Waste-to-Energy Facili-
ty (the Facility or FCCRWTE) in Frederick County, Maryland. The Facility will serve the
long-term solid waste disposal needs of Frederick and Carroll Counties (Counties), as
well as produce approximately 55 megawatts (MW) gross (45 MW net) of electricity to
meet the Counties' governmental energy needs. FCCRWTE will be owned by NEA.


1.1        PURPOSE
The purpose of this engineering report is to address the provisions of the Code of Mary-
land Regulations (COMAR), Title 26.04.07.25B and D. Specifically, this report will ad-
dress the following information:
                        A map showing the specific location, land use, and zoning within 0.25 mile
                        of the boundaries of FCCRWTE.
                        Drawings of buildings and other structures showing types of construction,
                        layout, and dimensions for unloading, storage, and processing areas.
                        Site plan designating the property boundaries and existing and proposed
                        structures and roads.
                        Descriptive statement of processes to be used.
                        Description of: (a) major items of equipment including manufacturer, type,
                        model, capacity, and number of units; (b) types and anticipated quantities of
                        solid waste to be accepted; (c) types of solid waste not to be accepted;
                        (d) area and population that will be served by FCCRWTE; (e) measures to
                        be taken to prevent or control odors, explosions, and groundwater or surface
                        water pollution; (f) methods of treating or disposing of liquid waste resulting
                        from the operation; and (g) employee safety and sanitary facilities.
                        Operations and maintenance (O&M) manual (provided to MDE as a sepa-
                        rate document), which identifies the operation in detail, including periodic
                        cleaning and maintenance, and contingency plans.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.         1-1          Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
                        Description of the manner in which unacceptable waste that may be deliv-
                        ered to FCCRWTE will be identified, segregated, and handled before final
                        disposal.
                        Map depicting the topography in the vicinity of FCCRWTE.
                        Anticipated tonnage of solid waste to be accepted at FCCRWTE daily.
                        Location of storage areas for ash and other noncombustible waste generated
                        by FCCRWTE.
                        Identification of a proposed disposal site for the ash generated by
                        FCCRWTE.
                        Detailed engineering plans and specifications for FCCRWTE and related
                        machinery.


1.2        FACILITY LOCATION
The FCCRWTE site will be located on an 11-acre parcel in the McKinney Industrial Park
in Frederick County, Maryland, near the intersection of English Muffin Way and
Buckeystown Pike (Maryland Route 85). The site is currently vacant and bordered by
railroad tracks on the west side, the Frederick County Ballenger-McKinney Wastewater
Treatment Plant (BMWWTP) on the north side, the Monocacy River on the east side, and
the Frederick County Division of Utilities and Solid Waste Management (DUSWM) of-
fice building on the south side. Figure 1-1 depicts the Facility location and topography.
Figures 1-2 and 1-3 depict the land use and zoning designations, respectively, for the lo-
cation of FCCRWTE and surrounding areas within 0.25 mile. Furthermore, Figures 1-2
and 1-4 clearly depict that there are no public/private elementary or secondary schools
within 1 mile of the FCCRWTE site.

                                                                                     1-6
                                             2.0 SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT


2.1        SERVICE AREAS
FCCRWTE has been sized to meet the needs of all residential, business, industrial, insti-
tutional, and commercial waste generators of Frederick and Carroll Counties, Maryland,
and is sized to accommodate long-term growth in the Counties. Additional waste from
outside the primary service area will be accepted early in the life of the project at the dis-
cretion of the Counties to enable FCCRWTE to generate the maximum amount of renew-
able energy.


2.2        MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE QUANTITIES AND PROJECTIONS
Population growth is an important part of waste management planning, because it pro-
vides a base to estimate the amount of waste that will be produced. Both Frederick and
Carroll Counties are currently experiencing a growth in their populations. Typically, as
the population increases, so does the amount of waste generated, even if the per capita
waste generation rate plateaus and does not increase.


With the full implementation of the residential single-stream recycling program, in addi-
tion to planned policies and programs, both Counties anticipate the amount of waste ma-
terials separated for recycling to increase, along with the population and amount of mu-
nicipal wastes generated. Appendix A provides the draft final materials separation plan,
which provides solid waste quantities and projections for both Counties.


2.3        WASTE DESCRIPTION
FCCRWTE will combust processible waste, sewage sludge, and scrap tires. Known quan-
tities of nonprocessible solid waste will not be accepted at FCCRWTE. Processible and
nonprocessible solid wastes are described in Subsections 2.3.1 and 2.3.2, respectively.


2.3.1          PROCESSIBLE SOLID WASTE
FCCRWTE is designed to combust a nominal 1,500 tpd at 5,500 British thermal units
(Btu) per pound (higher heating value [HHV]) of processible solid waste. Actual quanti-
ties of processible solid waste combusted will vary. In general, as the Btu content (HHV)

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-1         Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
of the solid waste mixture increases, the solid waste quantity combusted decreases. Con-
versely, in general, as the Btu content (HHV) of the solid waste mixture decreases, the
solid waste quantity combusted increases. This relationship is subject to system limita-
tions. Daily quantities of processible solid waste combusted will vary based on the Btu
content of the solid waste combusted on that day. The maximum quantity of solid waste
that could be combusted annually would be 602,250 tons.


Acceptable and processible solid waste will include municipal solid waste (MSW) con-
sisting of materials and substances discarded or rejected as being spent, useless, worth-
less, or in excess to the owners at the time of such discard or rejection, including, without
limitation, waste, garbage, trash, rubbish, and refuse that is normally disposed of by, and
collected from, residential, commercial, industrial, governmental, or institutional estab-
lishments. Acceptable solid waste will be composed of waste materials or debris that can
be combusted, having a composition with characteristics such as that collected and dis-
posed of as part of normal collections of waste materials and debris in Frederick and Car-
roll Counties as well as other areas (as approved by NEA) outside the primary service
areas, Acceptable and processible solid waste will include but not be limited to:
                        Sewage sludge as defined in Section 2.3.3.
                        Garbage, rubbish, trash, and refuse.
                        Witness burn documents, paper, cardboard, cartons, and boxes.
                        Automobile and truck tires, as permitted.
                        Rags, cloth, and bedding.
                        Leather.
                        Plastics.
                        Beds, mattresses, sofas, and carpeting.
                        Bicycles, commingled tin cans, and other noncombustible residential waste.
                        Combustible construction and demolition debris.
                        Combustible commercial and industrial waste materials or debris.
                        Commingled small quantities of grass, leaves, brush, yard trimmings, and
                        tree limbs.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-2              Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
                        Lumber, logs, and trees no more than 4 feet (ft) long and/or 6 inches in di-
                        ameter.


2.3.2           NONPROCESSIBLE SOLID WASTE
FCCRWTE contractually will not accept nonprocessible solid wastes, as defined in the
following list, other than small quantities that are commingled and/or mixed with other
processible waste and that cannot be safely removed from the waste stream.
Nonprocessible solid waste not accepted by FCCRWTE will include:
                        Infectious/medical waste.
                        Hazardous materials, including radioactive substances/material.
                        Contained gaseous waste and compressed gas cylinders.
                        Dirt, concrete, and other noncombustible construction material and demoli-
                        tion debris.
                        Refrigerators, washing machines, large appliances, and similar white goods.
                        Large items of machinery, equipment, and mechanical parts, such as motor
                        vehicles and major components thereof, agricultural equipment, trailers, ma-
                        rine vessels, or any other large item of waste.
                        Sludge (except for sewage sludge defined in Subsection 2.3.3); sewage;
                        wastewater and septic waste; cesspool; or human, animal, offal, and liquid
                        wastes.
                        Incinerator residue, ashes, foundry sands, and large volumes of plastics dis-
                        posed of as waste.
                        Offsite petroleum spill cleanup materials (unless approved by permit).
                        Transformers and other bulk electrical equipment.
                        Oil, paints (liquid), acids, caustics, poisons, asbestos, bulk chemicals, explo-
                        sives or highly ignitable substances, and ordnance materials, including bulk
                        liquid waste in amounts greater than 55 gallons.
                        Other materials, the receipt and combustion of which is likely to cause dam-
                        age to or otherwise materially and adversely affect the operation of
                        FCCRWTE, constitute a material threat to health or safety, or violate or
                        cause the violation of any applicable law or any governmental approval.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-3                 Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
                        Source-separated yard waste (grass, leaves, branches, twigs, and brush), re-
                        cyclable material collected as part of any recycling program in the solid
                        waste management collection areas, and bulk loads of construction and
                        demolition waste.


2.3.3           SEWAGE SLUDGE
Sewage sludge will consist of municipal wastewater treatment plant sewage sludge deliv-
ered by or on behalf of Frederick County, Carroll County, or local governments author-
ized by Frederick or Carroll County to deliver any sewage sludge that meets the follow-
ing criteria.


Sewage sludge, or sludge with incidental grease that is authorized by Frederick and/or
Carroll County and is delivered to the Facility for processing except for sewage sludge
having any one or more of the following characteristics:
                        Hazardous sludge, defined as containing explosives or radioactive substanc-
                        es; toxic or otherwise hazardous materials as defined in Volume 40 of the
                        Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Sections 261 and 761, promulgated by
                        the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), including sludge contain-
                        ing materials listed as hazardous waste from nonspecific sources or hazard-
                        ous waste from specific sources; sludge that contains materials treated as a
                        hazardous substance under any applicable law; or materials mixed with or
                        otherwise contaminated by such sludge during processing so as to render
                        such materials hazardous substances under applicable law.
                        Solids percentage outside the range of 16 to 30 percent.
                        Average volatile solids outside the range of 65 to 80 percent.
                        Sludge with a pH of less than 5.0.
                        Sludge that exceeds the limits for contaminate concentration for land appli-
                        cation (Class I sludge) as defined in COMAR 26.04.06.02 or any equivalent
                        successor. This provision is not intended to require the addition of lime for
                        pathogen control.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-4                Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
The quantity of sewage sludge to be delivered may be up to 10 percent by weight of wet
sludge as compared to MSW. FCCRWTE will be able to combust up to 150 tpd of wet
sludge. Sewage sludge trucks will deliver sludge to the sewage sludge area of FCCRWTE
and will be spaced out so as not to overload the sewage sludge pit. Frederick and Carroll
Counties will make arrangements for temporary storage or alternate disposal of the sew-
age sludge during Facility outages.


2.3.4          SCRAP TIRES
Scrap tires will be combusted to offset the effects of sludge combustion on the HHV of
the overall solid waste mixture. Up to a maximum of 20,000 tons per year of scrap tires
may be combusted in FCCRWTE. The scrap tires will be delivered by truck and unload-
ed on the tipping floor. The scrap tires will then be pushed by the loader into the solid
waste storage pit and dispersed throughout the solid waste in the pit by the grapple opera-
tor to create a well-mixed solid waste supply for the furnace. Steam generation will be
monitored by the crane and plant operators, who will adjust operating conditions as re-
quired. Incidental scrap tires may also be combusted as part of the routine MSW delivery
process.


Scrap tire delivery will be weighed to allow for proper recording of tons of scrap tires
processed. Continuous measurement of the weight of the scrap tires (or any other element
in the solid waste mix) as fed into the hoppers is not necessary.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-5       Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
                                                          3.0 FACILITY SITE PLAN


Figure 3-1 shows the general Facility layout, including building/structures, traffic flow,
and the waste delivery/unloading area; Figure 3-2 illustrates the site grading and drain-
age, including environmental site design areas and the wet pond for stormwater detention.
Figures 3-3, 3-3A, and 3-3B provides a multiple view rendering of the site, the east and
west building elevations, and north and south building elevations, respectively.


Figure 3-4 depicts the primary buildings/structures and their dimensions. The tipping bay
building, solid waste storage pit, sewage sludge building, warehouse/maintenance build-
ing, and administration building will be designed as an integral structure. The primary
structural system will be structural steel columns, beams, and bracing for the main load
resisting system. Roofs for the other structures will be sloped slightly to drain to a low
point, where the water will be discharged through drains to the site stormwater drainage
system.


The tipping bay and the sewage sludge building and solid waste storage pit areas will be a
totally enclosed structures. Odor control in the tipping bay building, sewage sludge build-
ing, and solid waste storage pit areas will be achieved by maintaining these areas under
negative pressure using the combustor/boilers' primary air system. Water stops will be
provided at construction joints to prevent migration of groundwater into the pit and out-
ward flow of possible leachate or liquids from the bottom of the pit.


The boiler building, turbine generator building, and air quality control system (AQCS)
building will be designed as an integral structure. The primary structural system will be
structural steel columns, beams, and bracing for the main load resisting system. Air pollu-
tion control equipment will be located inside the AQCS building. Roofs for the boiler
building will be sloped slightly to drain to a low point, from where the water will be dis-
charged through drains to the site drainage system.


The primary structural system for the ash and metal recovery building will also be struc-
tural steel columns, beams, and bracing for the main load resisting system. The roof will

                                                                          3-7
be also sloped slightly to drain to a low point, from where the water will be discharged
through drains to the site drainage system.


The stack will be self-supporting steel with a reinforced concrete enclosure extending
roughly half the height of the stack. There will be several tanks and/or silos at the site.
These will include the service water tank, demineralized water tank, lime silos, sorbent
silo, aqueous ammonia tank, fuel tank, and wastewater tank. These tanks and silos will be
placed on reinforced concrete foundations. The lime silos and carbon-based sorbent silo
will be located inside the AQCS building.


The water treatment building will be a preengineered or prefabricated building. The fly
ash surge bin enclosure will be constructed of structural steel columns, beams, and brac-
ing for the main load resisting system. Their roofs will be sloped slightly to drain to a low
point, from where the water will be discharged through drains to the site drainage system.


A screen wall will be provided in the parking area outside the administration building to
visually shield the equipment and process areas. This wall will be constructed of structur-
al steel columns, beams, and bracing for the main load resisting system. Metal siding will
be installed on girts connected to the columns.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-8      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
                                         4.0 PROCESS SYSTEMS DESCRIPTION


FCCRWTE will employ state-of-the-art technology and operating principles including
the most recent advances in combustion facility design, heat recovery, and air emissions
control equipment. WTI's design includes:
                        High availability vertical convection pass boilers that are highly reliable and
                        cost-effective to operate and maintain.
                        A high-pressure (HP) steam cycle that maximizes efficiency and electric
                        power production.
                        A water-cooled combustion grate.
                        Flow-optimized swirl injection of secondary air in the combustor/boilers.
                        Flue gas recirculation.
                        Sewage sludge process and handling, including all necessary odor control
                        equipment.


The following subsections provide an overview of the materials flow and handling at
FCCRWTE. They also identify each major equipment component and describe the
movement of materials within FCCRWTE, from point of receipt through waste combus-
tion, energy recovery, electricity production, emissions control, and ash handling.


4.1        SOLID WASTE FUEL DELIVERY, HANDLING, PROCESSING, AND
           COMBUSTION
4.1.1           SITE ACCESS, TRUCK WEIGHING, AND TRAFFIC FLOW
The main entrance to FCCRWTE will be located at the end of Metropolitan Court. An
additional rear gate will provide access to the BMWWTP. FCCRWTE will accommodate
multiple types of vehicles entering and exiting the site. This section describes these vari-
ous types of vehicles and the traffic pattern they will follow while on site.


The main gate will be open during delivery hours and will be monitored with a closed-
circuit television by the control room operators. Trucks will proceed directly to the scales
and the tipping floor on FCCRWTE's interior roads. Queuing will be onsite, thereby pos-
ing no anticipated impacts to existing traffic.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-1                Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
A traffic impact study was performed for FCCRWTE by Rummel, Klepper & Kahl, LLP
(RK&K) (Appendix B). The study evaluated the anticipated impact of FCCRWTE traffic
in light of county-anticipated future growth in the corridor (by other property owners)
within the FCCRWTE timeline. A final report was submitted to the Frederick County Di-
vision of Permitting and Development Review in December 2010, which addressed all
comments provided by the Division, as well as those provided by the Maryland State
Highway Administration. The traffic impact study report identified roadway network im-
provements needed to accommodate impacts associated with future growth in the area
and the minor increases in traffic caused by the operation of FCCRWTE. With these im-
provements in place, intersections will operate at acceptable levels when FCCRWTE is in
operation. Transportation issues have been addressed in accordance with Frederick Coun-
ty's adequate public facility ordinance guidelines.


Solid waste will be delivered to FCCRWTE by self-unloading waste collection trucks and
transfer trailers that are either self-unloading or need to be tipped. Vehicles will enter at
the main entrance security gate located on the south side of FCCRWTE and proceed to
the truck scale(s) to be weighed (if required). After being weighed, vehicles will proceed
west and then south to enter the tipping bay building through the door on the west side.
Before entering the building, trucks will be queued within the two 13-ft-wide egress lanes
that extend approximately 1,300 ft from the tipping bay building to a point just beyond
the truck scales. In the tipping bay building, transfer trailers will be guided to the solid
waste storage pit (or the trailer tipper), while waste collection trucks will be directed to
the floor.


Vehicular traffic on the tipping floor will be controlled by an operator. The operator will
instruct trucks as to when to enter or where to discharge their load. Trash collection
trucks and self-emptying trash transfer trucks will enter the west door of the tipping bay
building, turn right, and back up to the southern (pit) end of the tipping floor. There will
be adequate space for turnaround and backing up to the pit within the tipping floor area.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-2      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--062712
Transfer trailers that need to use the tipper to offload will also enter the west door of the
tipping bay building and back onto the tipper. These transfer trailers will drive out of the
tipping bay building out of the east door if they have tared and approved to exit without a
weigh-out. A movement study was performed by RK&K to verify all transfer trailer
movements to and from the tipper.


Sewage sludge trucks will also enter the west door of the tipping bay building, turn left,
and back up to the sewage sludge receiving pit. During this short movement, trash trucks
will need to pause driving on or off the west side of the tipping floor.


After unloading the contents in the tipping bay, self-unloading trucks will typically exit
the tipping bay through the same door on the west side. They will then proceed north and
then east toward the truck scales to be weighed again, and then travel south to exit
FCCRWTE through the main gate.


Sludge trucks will deliver sludge to the sewage sludge area of FCCRWTE and will be
timed so as not to overload the sludge pit. Frederick and Carroll Counties will make ar-
rangements for storage or alternate disposal of the sludge during Facility outages. Sludge
delivery trucks will weigh in and out at the Facility scales. Small quantities of waste lu-
brication oil (derived from onsite vehicle/equipment oil changes) may be added to the
sludge to facilitate pumping. Appropriate regulatory approvals will be obtained for utili-
zation of used oil under the air permit regulations.


After unloading the contents, transfer trailers that require tipping and do not require re-
weighing will typically leave the tipping bay through the door located on the east side of
the bay and proceed south to exit FCCRWTE through the main gate. Some transfer trailer
trucks may proceed to the ash and metal recovery building to provide ash haul back to
Frederick or Carroll County landfills or other designated facilities.


Ash trucks will enter the main gate on the south side of FCCRWTE. Once the trucks are
beyond the scale area, they will turn left and enter the ash and metal recovery building.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-3       Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
After the ash trucks have been loaded, they will pass through the wheel wash and then
exit the building on the south side. The wheel wash station wastewater is one of the mis-
cellaneous services water uses shown on the water balance diagram depicted in Fig-
ure 4-11. This water balance shows how water within FCCRWTE is used and includes
contact water. Water that comes in contract with the ash will be collected and managed in
the contact water system as depicted on the drawing and will not be discharged into the
stormwater collection system.


Once out of the building, ash trucks will make an immediate left to advance toward the
truck scales for weighing. After weighing, they will again turn left and take the loop road
immediately west of the ash and metal recovery building and exit through the main gate
of FCCRWTE.


It should be noted that to prevent the loss of ash during transport, the following measures
will be implemented:
                        Bottom ash will be quenched with water in the ram ash expeller. The ram
                        ash expeller will squeeze out free water upon discharge but will leave the
                        bottom ash moist.
                        Fly ash will be wetted during ash conditioning in a pug mill to reduce dust-
                        ing. Water content of the combined ash will be between 10 and 20 percent.
                        The fly ash will be combined with the bottom ash before being loaded into
                        trucks for transportation offsite.
                        Ash trucks will be covered and fitted with leak proof doors (gasket seals) to
                        keep the ash with the ash truck until it has reached the disposal site.


FCCRWTE's main three-lane road, which will be used by the waste and ash trucks for
delivery of waste and removal of ash, as well as the Facility's secondary roads and park-
ing areas, will be swept periodically by FCCRWTE's road sweeper to minimize genera-
tion of airborne dust by vehicular traffic. Trash will be collected daily from the plant site
and from the approach roads, as necessary.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-4                  Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
Bulky materials, recovered metal, and other unacceptable solid wastes will be stored in
30- to 50-cubic-yard containers. The containers will be picked up when full and replaced
with empty ones. The specific locations of these containers on the tipping floor will vary
depending on the operations (e.g., away from active tipping bays, which may change over
the course of a day).


Visitors to FCCRWTE will enter through the main gate and proceed directly to the visi-
tors' parking area east of the administration building. Visitors will check-in at the admin-
istration building. When leaving FCCRWTE, they will exit directly through the main
gate.


Equipment and supply delivery vehicles will follow informational signage on the site to
proceed to their required destination areas.


4.1.2          RECEIVING, UNLOADING, SCREENING, AND STORAGE
FCCRWTE is designed to operate and accept delivery of waste 24 hours per day,
365 days per year. Solid waste will be delivered to FCCRWTE's tipping bay building by
waste collection trucks and transfer trailers. Authorized personnel will be onsite at all
times FCCRWTE is operating. A sign will be posted at the entrance identifying the deliv-
ery hours.


Solid waste from waste collection trucks will be discharged onto the tipping floor to al-
low for waste inspection by loader operator before being added to the solid waste storage
pit. Transfer trailers will discharge directly to the pit, as waste has already been previous-
ly inspected at the transfer station prior to loading into the transfer trailer. Self-tipping
trailers will unload directly into the solid waste storage pit, while nonself-tipping trailers
will be positioned on the trailer tipper to discharge into the solid waste storage pit. There
will be a tipping floor operator that will coordinate traffic in and out of the tipping bay
building. Operations on the tipping floor will be conducted in manner such that a truck
may be directed to an area near the solid waste storage pit, but separate from the ongoing
unloading operations, for the inspection of the load.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-5       Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
The floor of the tipping bay building will be sloped slightly to drain into the solid waste
storage pit (Figure 3-2). This will avoid pooling of water in the tipping bay building.
Heavy duty concrete curbs, suitable for solid waste trucks, will be provided at the edge of
the tipping bay (in front of the solid waste storage pit). A maintenance program will be in
place to keep the tipping bay in a good condition. Figures 4-1A, 4-1B, and 4-1C show the
curb location and detail. Figure 4-1B also shows the slope of the floor.


The clearance from the roof truss to the tipping floor will be sufficient for trucks with
dump bodies to unload. The loader operator will inspect loads as they are received and
will move aside any nonprocessible materials for load-out and disposal. The tipping floor
slab will be constructed with 4,000 to 5,000 pounds per square inch concrete-wearing
surface to meet the demanding requirements of truck and loader traffic.


FCCRWTE will include a permanently installed trailer tipper to discharge waste from the
transfer trailers into the solid waste storage pit. The trailer tipper will be located along the
west wall of the tipping bay building and recessed into the tipping floor. The transfer
trailers will be jockeyed onto the trailer platform. The tipper will elevate the trailer to an
angle of approximately 63 degrees to ensure waste flows via gravity into the pit. This fea-
ture requires that the roof of the tipping bay building be approximately 60 ft above the
tipping floor to provide the necessary clearance for a trailer in its upright (discharge) po-
sition. The roof of the building will be designed to provide this clearance.


The dimensions of the solid waste storage pit are 150 ft long, 70 ft wide, and 38 ft deep
from the tipping floor to the bottom of the pit. The pit will provide 5 days of storage at
1,500 tpd, if the solid waste is stacked in accordance with the specification requirement
(minimum of two-thirds of the total storage volume to be below the tipping floor and not
more than one-third of the total volume above the pit to the level of the charging hop-
pers). A solid waste density of 700 pounds per cubic yard (yd3) is expected and was used
to size the pit. Table 4-1 summarizes the storage capacity of the solid waste storage pit.
Figure 4-1 illustrates a longitudinal elevation of the Facility. Figures 4-1A and 4-1B de-
pict the solid waste storage pit with tipping bay plan and the solid waste storage pit with
tipping bay section, respectively. Figure 4-1C provides the typical construction details.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-6        Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
Table 4-1. Solid Waste Storage Pit Capacity


                                                                               Capacity


PART A. ­ Capacity of Refuse Pit below the Tipping Floor

Contract required storage capacity                                   5 days at 1,500 tons/day =
                                                                             7,500 tons
Contract requirement that a minimum two-thirds of re-               2/3 × 7,500 tons = 5,000 tons
quired capacity be below tipping floor elevation (within
refuse pit)

Designed refuse pit dimensions                                       150 ft l × 70 ft w × 38 ft d =
                                                                      399,000 ft3 or 14,778 yd3
Conversion to tons                                              14,778 yd3 × 700 lb/yd3/2,000 lb/ton =
                                                                               5,172 tons

Total weight below tipping floor                                  5,172 tons > 5,000 tons; therefore,
                                                                   specification requirement is met

PART B. ­ Storage Capacity above the Tipping Floor
Capacity calculation based on available volume, which is the area of the refuse pit up to the
height of the charging floor

Total volume of area above pit                                       150 ft l × 70 ft w × 77 ft h =
                                                                      808,500 ft3 or 29,944 yd3
Conversion to tons                                              29,944 yd3 × 700 lb/yd3/2,000 lb/ton =
                                                                              10,481 tons

PART C. ­ Total Storage Capacity

Total volume above tipping floor (see Part B)                                 29,944 yd3
Total volume below tipping floor (see Part A)                                 14,778 yd3
Total volume                                                                  44,722 yd3

Total weight above tipping floor height (see Part B)                         10,481 tons
Total weight below tipping floor height (see Part A)                          5,172 tons
Total weight                                                                 15,653 tons


Source: WTI, 2012.

    SOLID WASTE STORAGE PIT AND TIPPING BAY SECTION

                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY

    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

    FIGURE 4-1C.
    TYPICAL CONCRETE DETAILS



                                                                              4-11
The sewage sludge will be transported from BMWWTP through FCCRWTE's rear gate
and from other authorized sites through the main gate by truck.


The sewage sludge building is located adjacent to the tipping bay building, and access is
through the tipping bay. Sewage sludge delivery trucks will first enter the tipping bay
and, from there, back up through a roll-up access door into the sewage sludge building.
The overall storage pit dimensions are 26 ft long, 10 ft wide, and 10 ft deep and will have
a storage capacity of 1,485 cubic feet. The solid waste storage pit has been sized to store
two trucks worth of sewage sludge. If the sewage inventory in the refuse pit is all com-
busted, then sludge combustion would be discontinued until the next delivery of sewage
sludge is made. It is not necessary to store a large inventory of sewage sludge at
FCCRWTE, as deliveries will be spread over time, and storage is at the Ballenger Creek
McKinney WWTP, the location where the sludge is generated. Figure 4-2 depicts the
sewage sludge building plan/sections view.


4.1.3          SOLID WASTE FUEL HANDLING
Two overhead cranes will transfer processible waste from the solid waste storage pit into
the feed hoppers and will also be used for mixing, fluffing, and stacking solid waste in
the storage pit. The cranes are designed as bridge cranes with a grab trolley, hoisting
gear, and electro-hydraulic motor grab. The crane system can feed the combustor and mix
the waste in continuous operation.


The cranes will be controlled separately by operators in the crane control room. This con-
trol room will provide line-of-sight view of the combustor feed hoppers and all areas of
the storage pit. From this observation point, the crane operator will be able to readily
monitor the discharge of solid waste from the solid waste trucks on the tipping floor into
the pit.


The cranes will be equipped with manual and automatic preprogrammed controls for dis-
charge of solid waste into the feed hopper. The crane control pulpit will include a two-
way communication system for direct contact with the main control room, reception area,

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-12    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
M:\acad\100104\Biosolids Building.dwg                                                 Jan 11, 2011 - 3:04pm by ndenahan




                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY

    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

    FIGURE 4-2.
    SEWAGE SLUDGE BUILDING PLAN/SECTIONS



                                                                          4-13
and other locations where required. Oversized objects will be removed either during the
offloading process on the tipping floor or by using the overhead crane during the mixing
and fluffing process prior to feeding into the combustor. These objects will be stored
briefly for direct load-out to trucks at the tipping floor level.


The sewage sludge handling equipment will consist of a twin-auger screw conveyor and
two hydraulically driven high-density solids (sludge) pumps to extract the sludge out of
the sewage sludge storage pit (Figure 4-2) and deliver it to the inlet chutes of both com-
bustors. The sewage sludge storage pit will have sloping longitudinal side walls with a
twin-auger screw conveyor located at the bottom of the pit. The conveyor will run across
the entire length of the pit, through the pit's wall, and feed the two sludge pumps located
in an adjacent pump room. To accomplish this, the screw conveyor will have two dis-
charge openings, one for each pump. Each opening will have a slide gate to isolate the
sludge pump that is not in operation.


Each sludge pump will be capable of providing sludge to both combustors simultaneously
(Figure 4-3). The discharge of the pumps will be piped up to the combustor's feed chute,
where the sewage sludge will be fed into the combustor with the other incoming
processible waste. The sludge feed piping will be equipped with automated flow diverter
valves that will be used to balance the flow of sewage sludge between the two combus-
tors.


4.1.4          SOLID WASTE FUEL PROCESSING
Each combustor will be equipped with a solid waste feed hopper and charging chute
(Figure 4-1). The feed hopper will be a rugged, heavily reinforced unit incorporating a
combination arch breaker and cutoff gate. The rear wall of the solid waste hopper will
include a hydraulically activated pivoting plate. Controls located in the crane operator's
area will allow the plate to be activated as an arch breaker or as a cutoff gate. The arch
breaker will serve to dislodge bulky items, which could block or restrict solid waste flow
in the solid waste feed chute. To monitor the waste height in the charging chute, a relia-
ble, low-maintenance level monitor will be installed.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-14      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
M:\acad\100104\Fuel Handling.dwg                                                      Jun 11, 2012 - 4:57pm by ndenahan




                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY
    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

   FIGURE 4-3.
   SOLID WASTE FUEL HANDLING AND ODOR CONTROL



                                                                          4-15
The feed hopper system consists of a hopper, hopper flap gate, feed chute, and support
frame. The hopper flap gates will seal the combustion chamber from the solid waste stor-
age pit and receiving hall prior to waste charging and during system shutdown. The slope
of the hopper walls and the arrangement of the hopper flap gate will be designed to pre-
vent bridging and, thereby, ensure continuous delivery of waste to the combustion grate.
The height of the feed chute will facilitate a sufficiently high waste column that seals the
combustion chamber from the solid waste storage pit and receiving hall during combus-
tion. The feed chute will be designed to resist thermal stress that may occur during opera-
tion, with a cooling water jacket to cool the feed chute parts that are potentially exposed
to extreme thermal loads.


From the feed chute, waste will fall on the horizontal feeder table, over which the hydrau-
lically driven ram feeder slides. As the feeder slides in and out, waste will be pushed onto
the combustion grate. The speed of the forward stroke can be varied with each stroke.
Varying the speed of the forward stroke will allow uniform metering and immediate ad-
justment of the volume of waste required to match the combustion conditions and the sys-
tem set points; this allows for the same volumetric quantity of waste to be pushed onto
the combustion grate. Each return stroke will be made at the same speed.


4.1.5          SOLID WASTE FUEL COMBUSTION
The grate will consist of three lanes with five zones or grate elements. The first two zones
will be water-cooled, and the remaining zones will be air-cooled. The movement of the
individual grate elements will be adjusted by means of an electronic pulse control system.


For a standard combustion profile, the optimum pulse count will be preset for each grate
element. For example, the grate elements in the main combustion zone will have a higher
pulse count than those in the burnout zone. If waste throughput needs to be changed, the
pulse counts for the entire grate can be uniformly increased or decreased by the control
room operator, while maintaining the relative speeds of the individual grate elements.


If there is a change in calorific value that changes the combustion profile on the grate, the
specific pulse count for the individual grate elements can be adjusted during operation to

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-16     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
reflect the new combustion conditions. The number of working strokes impacts not only
the throughput rate and, therefore, the volume, but also the stoking effect and, thus, the
combustion profile.


The heat from the two water-cooled grate zones is recovered and returned to the furnace
with the primary air. The first stage of the primary air preheater cools the hot water com-
ing from the grate. In case emergency cooling is required, the system will be provided
with a potable water connection for temporary backup service. Figure 4-4 shows the pro-
cess flow diagram for thermal treatment.


The primary air system controls and delivers under-grate combustion air to the boiler. Air
will be drawn in from the tipping floor and storage pit charging area and delivered sepa-
rately, by the primary air fan, to the underside of the individual grate zones. The system
will be comprised of the air ducts from the inlet to the fan, the fan to the air heater, and
the air heater to the grate sifting hoppers. Air from the sewage sludge area will also be
ducted to the intake of the primary air fans for each boiler for odor control.


The air-flow rate will be controlled by a variable frequency speed control system, via the
combustion control system (CCS), and will also have the option of inlet vane damper
control. With this system, the various primary air-flow rates required for optimum com-
bustion will be provided for each individual grate zone. Air will be preheated to increase
cycle efficiency.


The primary air fan will be equipped with openings for inspection and cleaning purposes.
The fan and its drive will be mounted on a common steel frame structure (base plate).


The secondary air system delivers and regulates secondary combustion air to mix the flue
gases and complete the combustion process above the grates. Some volatile components
of the waste do not combust directly on the grate, but instead will be released on expo-
sure to heat and then burn as they pass through the furnace.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-17      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
M:\acad\100104\Thermal Treatment.dwg                                                  Jun 11, 2012 - 2:49pm by ndenahan




                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY
    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

    FIGURE 4-4.
    THERMAL TREATMENT SYSTEM PROCESS FLOW DIAGRAM



                                                                         4-18
4.1.5.1            Flue Gas Recirculation
FCCRWTE will be equipped with a flue gas recirculation system comprised of the flue
gas recirculation fan, damper, and ducts to the combustion chamber. The recirculation
causes an effective mixing of the flue gases. Flue gas recirculation increases boiler effi-
ciency, and the volume of flue gas requiring waste gas treatment is reduced. Flue gas re-
circulation has been used for many years in utility boilers that burn solid fuels.


4.1.5.2            Natural Gas-Fired Startup and Auxiliary Burner
FCCRWTE will be connected to the local utility's natural gas system by way of the
Facility's gas metering station. Natural gas will fuel the auxiliary burners during initial
startup of the combustor and heat up the combustion chamber to the specified minimum
temperature before waste charging begins. The auxiliary burner system will also be used
for backup firing if the temperature of the flue gases drops below the specified minimum
temperature during upset waste-combustion operations and will have the capability of
firing the combustors to 60 percent of maximum capacity rating.


When the combustor is shut down, the auxiliary burners will maintain the minimum tem-
perature in the combustion chamber until the waste on the grate has been burned out. The
gas-fired auxiliary burners have been specially designed for processible waste combus-
tion units. The burners will be located in the upper part of the combustion chamber.


The combustion air fan, provided separately for the burners, will aspirate the necessary
air from the boiler room and will blow it into the air manifold. The control damper will
control the volume of combustion air.


4.1.5.3            Bottom Ash Extractor
The bottom ash extractor quenches and discharges bottom ash from the furnace and
riddlings from the ram feeder and grate hoppers. Riddlings and bottom ash remaining at
the end of the combustion grate will fall into a water-filled, trough-shaped bottom ash
extractor. The bottom ash discharge chute and the bottom ash extractor will be movable
and connected to each other in an air-tight manner to provide isolation from the combus-
tion chamber. The water level control circuit will provide a constant water level in the

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-19      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
extractor. Bottom ash extractor water will be discharged into a concrete contact sump.
The water vapor that is formed by evaporation in the bottom ash discharge chute will rise
back into the combustion chamber, and the water vapor collected in the bottom ash dis-
charge hood will be fed by axial fan back into the bottom ash chute.


A hydraulically driven ram will feed the bottom ash from the bottom ash extractor to a
bottom ash conveyor. The bottom ash extractor will be designed to handle variable bot-
tom ash discharge from the combustion unit. The design of the bottom ash extractor, in-
cluding the inlet and discharge cross sections, will allow large pieces of bottom ash and
metal to be discharged without difficulty.


4.1.5.4            Grate Siftings
The combustion grate floor will be designed to minimize the amount of grate siftings that
fall between and below the grates. Under each grate element and under each ram feeder
will be a siftings hopper and chute for the discharge of the grate siftings. The chutes will
lead to a wet drag chain conveyor. The chutes will be immersed under the water level in-
side the conveyor, thus ensuring the exclusion of air intake. The wet drag chain conveyor
will quench the grate siftings and transport them toward the bottom ash extractor. To
provide for cleaning, appropriate openings will be installed on the conveyor.


4.1.5.5            Combustion Control System
The CCS allows a largely automatic and safe operation based on the control room opera-
tor's set point for steam load. Even at varying waste qualities, compliance with permitted
operating conditions, such as the combustion chamber temperature and the oxygen con-
tent in the flue gas, as well as an efficient gas and bottom ash burnout, can be assured by
means of the control interventions. The overall goals of the CCS are to: (1) keep the
steam flow preset by the operator constant, (2) keep the flue gas flow rate constant, (i.e.,
depending on the steam flow set point and the existing calorific value of the waste),
(3) maintain combustion temperature within the permissible limits, and (4) ensure an ef-
ficient flue gas burnout by keeping the oxygen content within the permissible limits with
simultaneous control of the combustion temperature.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-20    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
The values for the ram feeder speed and the grate track stroke frequency, as well as the
volume flows for total air (primary air and secondary air) and recirculated flue gas, will
be calculated from the steam flow set point. Applying these values, the basic combustion
conditions will be preset.


The measured steam flow and the oxygen content in the flue gas are representative of the
thermal capacity. When the combustion capacity is too low, the primary air-flow below
the grate will be increased; simultaneously, the secondary airflow above the grate will be
decreased by the same rate. With this intervention, the combustion capacity will be in-
creased at constant total air supply. At the same time, the grate stroke frequency and the
ram feeder speed will be increased and, as a result, the fire will be intensified and the
waste throughput improved. Conversely, when the combustion capacity is too high, the
control interventions will be reversed.


The CCS will automate the combustion process in such a way that the operator has to on-
ly determine: (1) the set point for the desired steam flow rate, and (2) an estimation of
the HHV of the waste being fed (calorific value adjustment). In case of a change of the
waste quality, basic set points will be simultaneously modified by means of the calorific
value adjustment so that favorable combustion conditions are always maintained. Addi-
tionally, manual intervention will be possible allowing the operator to further optimize
the combustion process if necessary.


The CCS will be designed so that FCCRWTE is operated within its capacity limits. This
will be assured by program-internal limits, adjustment of the control strategies, and fol-
low-up on the set points. The primary air distribution over the length of the grate will be
continuously adapted to the combustion process by means of the zone-wise control sys-
tem.


The CCS will continuously measure and process steam flow rate, oxygen content at the
boiler outlet, primary air flow rate, secondary air flow rate, flue gas recirculation flow
rate, primary air temperature, and control variables. The CCS will activate control ele-
ments for the ram feeder (speed) via autonomous control cabinet, grate stroke frequency

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-21    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
via autonomous control cabinet, primary air fan (frequency converter), secondary air fan
(frequency converter), control valve primary air preheater (steam valve), and primary air
dampers per zone (position).


4.1.5.6            Four-Pass Steam Boiler
The steam boiler will consist of the following sections:
                        First Pass--Vertical radiation upward pass, made of membrane water walls
                        in the furnace above the grates.
                        Second Pass--Vertical radiation downward pass, made of membrane water
                        walls and one dividing wall with superheater bundles.
                        Third Pass--Vertical radiation upward pass, made of membrane water
                        walls, an evaporator bundle, an economizer bundle, and superheater bun-
                        dles.
                        Fourth Pass--Vertical convection pass, made of economizer bundles.


4.1.5.7            Online Cleaning of Heat Exchange Surfaces
FCCRWTE will employ online cleaning of heat exchange surfaces by means of soot
blowers. The effectiveness of the heat exchanger surface is reduced during boiler opera-
tion due to fouling. The heat exchanger bundles in the second, third, and fourth vertical
passes of the boiler will be cleaned online by soot blowers. Released soot will be cap-
tured by the fabric filter system.


4.1.5.8            Refractory Lining of Furnace and First Pass
WTI will use a refractory lined furnace surface to protect heating surfaces from high flue
gas temperatures (corrosion protection) and achieve high residence time of the flue gases
at high temperatures for a complete burnout.


4.1.5.9            Induced Draft Fan
The induced draft (ID) fan maintains the necessary balance draft in the combustion
chamber and conveyance of the flue gases through the whole flue gas cleaning system. It
generates the negative pressure for the gases in the upper combustion chamber.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-22             Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
Connections between the individual components up to and from the ID fan will be made
via the flue gas ducts. The quantity of flue gas handled by the ID fan will be regulated by
means of a variable frequency speed control system as a function of combustion chamber
pressure.


The ID fan will be designed and constructed to convey the required quantity of flue gas
over the entire load range of the combustion capacity diagram.


4.1.5.10 Dry Flue Gas Ducts
The flue gas ducts will be sized such that excessive pressure losses, as well as excessively
high gas flow velocities, are avoided. Special attention will be given to optimum flow
dynamics, as well as to the design of diverters and inlets. Where required, access doors
will be provided for the inspection and maintenance of the flue gas ducts and the Facility
components associated with them.


The flue gas ducts between the ID fan and the stack will be operated under positive pres-
sure. These ducts will feature leak-tight designs (particularly the doors and expansion
joints).


The individual flue gas cleaning components will be connected to each other by means of
ductwork. These ducts will provide a path for the flue gas to travel between components
(e.g., from the boiler to the air emissions control equipment to the ID fan). Instrument
ports are needed for flue gas measurements in the entire flue gas duct system.


4.1.5.11 Stack
The stack will be of freestanding two-flue construction. The outlet of the stack flues will
be 270 ft above ground level.


The cleaned flue gas will enter the stack with a temperature of approximately 260 degrees
Fahrenheit (°F) at nominal load. The individual stack pipe sections will be joined to form
a gas-tight seal.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-23    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
Below the flue gas inlet, condensed water vapor or rainwater will be collected on an in-
clined stack base plate and discharged via a condensate discharge line. The collected
condensate discharge will be pumped into the bottom ash water basin.


4.2        STEAM-WATER CYCLE
4.2.1           TURBINE/GENERATOR SET
Steam produced by the boiler will be sent to a steam turbine/generator set. The tur-
bine/generator set will convert the thermal energy of the steam to mechanical energy,
then to electrical energy for the needs of the entire Facility, and to the external electrical
grid. The turbine/generator will have a nominal gross rating of 55 MW. The internal elec-
trical needs are estimated to be 5 to 10 MW, leaving approximately 45 to 50 MW for ex-
port power to the Allegheny Power electrical network.


The steam flow to the turbine will be controlled by the steam turbine's pressure control
valve. HP steam will be extracted for use in the air preheater. Medium-pressure (MP)
steam will be extracted for feed-water deaeration and air preheating. Low-pressure (LP)
steam will be extracted for feed-water heating and internal consumption in FCCRWTE.


After the steam turbine, the expanded steam will be condensed in a water-cooled surface
condenser. Demineralized water can be added for makeup from the demineralized water
storage tank.


The energy recovery system will include:
                        Controlled extraction/condensing turbine (with hydraulic and lubricating oil
                        system).
                        Generator with voltage regulator.
                        Electrical equipment for the generator.
                        A local control panel for local operation, including interface to the distribut-
                        ed control system.


During regular Facility operation, pressure control in the main steam header will be per-
formed by the steam turbine's pressure control valve. In case of a trip of the steam tur-

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-24                Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
bine, a controlled main steam release to a bypass condenser via the turbine bypass system
will be initiated to prevent the boiler safety valves from relieving pressure.


In the event that the steam turbine's admission capacity is exceeded, the turbine bypass
system will be activated, which will then take over pressure control in the main steam
header.


The turbine bypass system will also be active during startup and shutdown of the boiler to
minimize any water losses (short-time steam blow-off only).


In case of a trip of the turbine and also at partial load, a steam pressure reduction station,
between the HP steam header and the MP header, and the MP and LP steam header, will
provide the supply of MP and LP steam to the internal systems.


4.2.2          CONTROL AND LUBRICATION OIL SUPPLY
For the turbine/generator, a control and lubrication oil system will be provided, including
oil reservoir, oil cooler, and lubrication oil centrifuge for lubrication oil conditioning to-
gether with fan extraction, vented in a safe location.


The control and lubrication oil system supplies the necessary oil for the bearings and the
control oil for control system of the turbine. The oil tank is made from carbon steel and
located next to the turbine casing. The main oil pump circulates oil through the system.
The emergency oil pump will be used during startup and also in emergency situations.


4.2.3          COOLING SYSTEM
The major equipment of the cooling system will consist of a surface condenser, turbine
bypass condenser, and mechanical draft cooling tower. The cooling system will be ade-
quately sized to accommodate the maximum continuous operating steam flow.


The steam surface condenser extracts the latent heat of vaporization from the turbine ex-
haust (a mixture of steam and water) and transfers this heat to the cooling water. The sur-
face condenser will consist of a series of parallel tubes through which cooling water will

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-25      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
pass, enclosed in a metal condenser located below the turbine/generator. The surface
condenser will have a design heat-removal capacity for approximately 340 million Btu
per hour. The exhaust steam from the turbine enters the upper region of the condenser
and passes down, around, and between the tubes in the tube bundle, thereby condensing
the steam.


The dump or bypass condenser will be supplied, in conjunction with a surface condenser,
for use during periods of startup, shutdown, and turbine/generator unavailability. The by-
pass condenser will receive and condense HP boiler steam and return the condensate to
the deaerator.


The cooling tower rejects heat absorbed by the cooling water system in the surface con-
denser and collects the water in a concrete basin. The cooling water will be pumped by
circulating water pumps located in the tower basin through the circulating water system,
returning the water to the tower. The tower will be noise-abated and adhere to applicable
standard fire and lightning codes. Treated effluent from the BMWWTP will normally
provide makeup water to replace cooling tower evaporation, drift, and blowdown.


The cooling tower will be a three-cell, counter-flow mechanical draft-type tower. The
structure will have high-efficiency fill and drift eliminators. Each cell will contain a fan
with an electric-drive motor.


Maximum total dissolved solids concentration in the cooling tower recirculating water
closed loop system is estimated to be 5,500 milligrams per liter. Particulate emissions
from the cooling tower will be controlled using high-efficiency drift eliminators. The
cooling tower will achieve a drift loss rate of no more than 0.0005 percent of the cooling
tower recirculating water flow.


The feed-water system will consist of the deaerator/feed-water storage tank with a useful
volume of approximately 10 to 20 minutes of operation, two electric motor driven feed-
water pumps, and associated pipes and valves. It will feed the boiler with deaerated water
of feed-water quality and provide spray water as cooling water for the attemperators in

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-26    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
the superheater, steam pressure reduction station of the turbine bypass, and HP/MP/LP
steam pressure reduction station.


The condensate system will consist of two condensate pumps, steam ejector condenser,
one LP condensate heater, gland steam condenser, two boiler external economizers, pip-
ing for condensate coming from the condenser to the deaerator, and condensate or drain
piping from the LP feed-water heater, ejector condenser, and the gland steam condenser
to the condenser hotwell.


4.3        AIR QUALITY CONTROL SYSTEM
An AQCS will be installed to reduce emissions in the flue gas prior to flue gas exit at the
stack. The AQCS will be designed to ensure compliance with federal and state air pollu-
tion control laws and regulation, which restrict regulated emissions to certain allowable
limits.


The AQCS consists of a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) unit with an ammonia injec-
tion system to reduce nitrogen oxides (NOx); a spray dryer absorber (SDA) such as a
Turbosorp® reactor or equivalent to remove acid gases, mercury, and organic contami-
nants; and a fabric filter to remove particulates.


FCCRWTE will be designed to satisfy all emission requirements required by 40 CFR 60,
Subpart Eb. Oxygen content for emission levels will be 7 percent dry. Detailed emissions
information is provided in FCCRWTE's air permit application filed separately with the
Maryland Department of the Environment's Air Resource Management Administration.


4.3.1          ACID GAS, PARTICULATE, TRACE METALS, AND DIOXIN/FURAN
               CONTROL
FCCRWTE will use a semi-dry acid gas removal system such as the Turbosorp® process.
The Turbosorp® process consists of a closely integrated Turbosorp® reactor and fabric
filter. Figure 4-5 illustrates the system.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-27    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
       M:\acad\100104\Turbosorp.dwg                                                       Jan 03, 2011 - 9:55am by ndenahan
4-28




                                                                      FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY

        FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY


        FIGURE 4-5.
        TURBOSORP REACTOR AND FABRIC FILTER
The Turbosorp® reactor removes acid gases (i.e., hydrochloric acid [HCl], sulfur dioxide
[SO2], sulfur trioxide [SO3], and hydrofluoric acid [HF]), mercury, and dioxins/furans
and other organics in a fluidized bed of hydrated lime and a carbon-based sorbent. Effi-
cient removal of contaminants from the flue gas at a temperature of approximately 295°F
is achieved through chemical reactions with the injected hydrated lime and adsorption
with the sorbent. The fabric filter will remove particulates from the flue gas stream.


4.3.1.1            Spray Dryer Absorber
An SDA is a semi-dry acid gas removal system that uses finely atomized, alkaline lime
slurry droplets in an absorbing chamber to remove acid gases from the flue gas stream.
The lime slurry droplets absorb the gases and react to form salts. Flue gas heat evaporates
the water, leaving tiny particles of mixed salt and unreacted alkali. Cooling the gas has
been proven to be a major factor influencing the removal of acid gases. The semi-dry flue
gas treatment process is designed to achieve high acid gas (i.e., SO2, SO3, HCl, and HF)
removal efficiencies by contact-sorption. At the same time, removal of mercury and or-
ganic contaminants, such as dioxins and furans, are also enhanced by adsorption on a
carbon-based sorbent (such as activated carbon, lignite, or other carbon-based reagent).
The fly ash, hydrated lime, sorbent, and other solids will be separated from the flue gas in
the downstream fabric filter. The separated lime, sorbent, and other solids will be recircu-
lated back into the SDA to maximize use of any unreacted lime or sorbent.


The semi-dry acid gas removal process is designed to operate from 60- to 110-percent
load with respect to the design flue gas flow rate.


4.3.1.2            Hydrated Lime Supply
Hydrated lime will be delivered to the site in pneumatic trailers. A pneumatic transfer
system will convey the lime to two storage silos, each with a nominal capacity of
6,500 cubic feet (ft3), using the on-board truck compressor and the installed fill line. A
bin vent filter on the roof of each silo will separate the entrained lime from the conveying
air prior to discharging the air into the AQCS building. Level indicators installed in the
silos will prevent over-filling and will report actual levels to the distributed control sys-



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-29     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
tem. Safety dampers on the silos will protect the system from positive or negative over-
pressurization.


The discharge of lime from the silos will be facilitated by a mechanical discharge and
metering system. Hydrated lime will be conveyed to the Turbosorp® reactor pneumati-
cally and injected as a dry powder directly into the Turbosorp® reactor independent of
the water injection.


4.3.1.3            Carbon-Based Sorbent Supply
A carbon-based sorbent, such as activated carbon, lignite, or other carbon-based reagent,
will be delivered to the site in pneumatic trailers. A pneumatic transfer system will con-
vey the sorbent to the 2,500-ft3 storage silo, using the on-board truck compressor and the
installed fill line. A bin vent filter on the roof of the silo will separate the entrained
sorbent from the conveying air prior to discharging the air to the AQCS building. Level
indicators installed in the silo will prevent overfilling and report the actual levels to the
distributed control system. Safety dampers on the silo will protect the system from posi-
tive or negative over-pressurization.


The discharge from the sorbent silo will be facilitated by a mechanical discharge and
weight loss-based metering system. The sorbent will be conveyed to the Turbosorp® re-
actor pneumatically. The sorbent will be injected as a dry powder directly into the
Turbosorp® reactor independent of the water injection. The amount of sorbent injected
into the Turbosorp® reactor will be set during the initial commissioning/compliance
stack testing and annually thereafter.


4.3.1.4            Fabric Filter Flue Gas Particulate Removal
A pulse jet-type fabric filter removes particulates, including reacted lime, sorbent, fly ash,
and other solids from the flue gas after the Turbosorp® reactor. High particulate removal
efficiency will be accomplished primarily by mechanical filtration on the surface of the
fabric filter bag membrane. Additionally, secondary filtration will occur from filter cake
that builds up on the bag membranes. This filter cake will provide additional contact be-



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-30      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
tween the flue gas and adsorbents, providing some final secondary removal of acid gases
and mercury.


The dust and adsorbent-laden flue gas will directly enter the fabric filter from the
Turbosorp® reactor. To assure a uniform distribution of flow through the filter chambers,
the raw gas will be passed across distributor panels where coarse particles will be sepa-
rated and discharged directly into the hopper below. Each compartment will consist of
numerous, vertically arranged filter bags suspended from internal cages. The flue gas will
flow from the outside to the inside of the filter bags and will pass into the clean side of
the compartment and then into the common clean flue gas duct.


The flow characteristics created by the chamber geometry, as well as the pressure drop
across the bag membrane, will result in uniform gas flow through the filter bags. This
will cause uniform deposition of solids and absorbents on the outside of the individual
filter bags.


The filter bags will be cleaned automatically and sequentially to maintain the desired
pressure-drop set point. The cleaning of the filter bags will be initiated when the pressure
drop increases to the set point. An elapsed timer will ensure bags are cleaned at some
minimal frequency to ensure optimum gas flow through the fabric filter during short-term
transients of high flue gas flow periods. The collected solids on the fabric filter bags will
be released by sudden inflation of the bags with pulses of compressed air.


The compressed air pulses will force the solids to crumble and fall into the hoppers below
the filter bags. The solids will be removed from the hoppers by fluidized air pneumatic
conveyors. A major portion of the collected solids will be recirculated back into the
Turbosorp® reactor to maintain the fluidized bed level, while the rest of the solids will be
discharged and transported to the residue silo. The hoppers of the fabric filter compart-
ments can be isolated from the pneumatic conveyors by means of manually operated slide
gates to perform online inspections and maintenance.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-31     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
In case of Facility shutdown, the solids are intended to remain in the hoppers and pneu-
matic conveyors for up to 72 hours. During longer shutdowns, the fabric filter will be
cleaned manually and the hoppers emptied into the fly ash collecting drag conveyor.


4.3.1.5            NOx Control System
Good steady-state combustion is important for optimizing NOx control system operation.
Good combustion control reduces NOx formation and maintains more consistent furnace
temperatures.


NOx emissions will also be controlled by SCR. The reaction of NOx with ammonia can be
efficiently accomplished at low temperatures (e.g., 446 to 460°F) in the presence of an
appropriate catalyst. NOx in the flue gas are converted to nitrogen gas and water.


Within the SCR process, a catalyst is used to lower the required reaction temperature to a
technically favorable level. The catalyst consists of titanium dioxide as support material
as well as vanadium pentoxide and tungsten trioxide as active substances in a ceramic
substrate.


Heating of flue gas upstream from the catalyst to the temperature required for the SCR
process is performed in the gas/gas heat exchanger. The flue gas coming out of the bag-
house will be heated up to approximately 428°F from 193°F using the gas/gas heat ex-
changer. Flue gas is cooled to approximately 329°F after the catalyst by means of the
same gas/gas heat exchanger.


The 19-percent aqueous ammonia solution is pumped from the storage tank to the ammo-
nia injection system. The ammonia solution is sprayed upstream from catalyst into the
flue gas duct together with compressed air. The ammonia flow of each injection nozzle is
measured to control an equal flow of each nozzle or detect a nozzle blockage. For main-
tenance, a service connection for flushing is installed for each nozzle.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-32     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
A bypass duct enables the bypass of the complete SCR system during startup. The bypass
duct is equipped with double isolation dampers (with sealing air) in the inlet and outlet
zones.


4.3.1.6            Process Continuous Emissions Monitoring System
Dedicated process continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMSs) will be installed
on each combustor line. Separate analyzer trains will measure SO2/oxygen at the boiler
exit before the spray dryer and after the SCR to control the flow of hydrated lime. In ad-
dition, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, HCl, and NOx will be monitored at the SCR
outlet of each combustor line.


The CEMS and continuous opacity monitoring system (COMS) will be interfaced into a
single, centralized, computer-based data acquisition system. The CEMS and COMS will
meet state, federal, and local permit requirements for data availability, accuracy, calibra-
tion and recordkeeping, and reporting requirements.


4.4        BOTTOM ASH, BOILER ASH, AND FLY ASH/SCRUBBER RESIDUE
           HANDLING AND STORAGE
Figures 4-6 through 4-10A provide material flow diagrams of the bottom ash, boiler ash,
and fly ash/scrubber residue handling and storage systems as well as the preliminary
equipment and conveyor arrangement for these systems and for the ash and metal recov-
ery building. The following subsections provide a narrative description of how these sys-
tems operate.


4.4.1          BOTTOM ASH HANDLING AND METAL RECOVERY
Bottom ash will fall from the end of the combustion grates through a chute and into a hy-
draulic ram-type bottom ash extractor. The ash will be quenched within the water-filled
extractor. The water vapor formed when the ash is quenched will rise into the combustion
chamber through the bottom ash chute. A level control circuit will be used to maintain a
constant water elevation in the extractor.
