     ASH AND METAL RECOVERY BUILDING PLAN/SECTIONS



                                                                          4-41
M:\acad\100104\Fig4-10A Ash Metal Recovery.dwg                                            Jun 11, 2012 - 4:54pm by ndenahan




                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY

    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

   FIGURE 4-10A.
   ASH AND METAL RECOVERY BUILDING ELEVATIONS


                                                                              4-42
A relatively small quantity of ash will not make it to the end of the grate and instead, will
fall through small openings between grate blocks or air holes in the grates. This material
known as grate siftings or riddlings will be collected in a series of under-grate chutes that
lead to a wet drag conveyor. The drag conveyor will deposit the siftings into the bottom
ash extractor.


The main bottom ash vibrating pan conveyor, common to both units, will receive
quenched bottom ash from the two bottom ash extractors from each combustor. The main
vibrating conveyor will transfer the ash to a bottom ash belt conveyor. This conveyor,
fully enclosed within a gallery, in turn, will convey the bottom ash to a 6-inch finger deck
screen located inside the ash and metal recovery building. The 6-inch finger deck screen
is a large vibrating screen that will separate oversized material (primarily ferrous) from
the remaining bottom ash. The oversized fraction (bulkies) will be deposited into a stor-
age bunker at grade, while the remaining bottom ash will be fed by vibrating feeder onto
a belt transfer conveyor for transport to a rotating drum magnet. Ferrous metals removed
by the magnet will be discharged onto a belt conveyor that will transport the material and
drop it into the ferrous metal storage bunker at grade. The remaining bottom ash will be
transferred by belt conveyor to the nonferrous metals recovery train. The bottom ash will
be discharged from the transfer belt conveyor to a 0.375-inch feeder/screener. The
0.375-inch feeder/screener, in turn, will feed the nonferrous metals eddy current separa-
tor. In the eddy current separator, some nonferrous metals such as aluminum, copper, and
brass will be removed and discharged onto a transfer belt conveyor for deposit into the
nonferrous storage bunker at grade. Any bottom ash that passes through the 0.375-inch
feeder/screener (smaller particles) and the eddy current system will fall onto a reversible
stackout conveyor. The combined ash reversible stackout conveyor discharges bottom
ash along with fly ash off either end into the combined ash storage bunker before offsite
disposal. In the event the feeder/screener is out of service, a diverter gate will be activat-
ed to bypass the feeder/screener and send the bottom ash directly to the bunker. The bun-
kers are located inside the ash and metal recovery building.


Total ash produced will be between 22 and 32 percent by weight of incoming MSW, de-
pending on the characteristics of the MSW. The actual percentages of ferrous and nonfer-

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-43      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
rous metal recovered will be dependent largely upon the percent by weight of ferrous and
nonferrous metal in the MSW delivered to FCCRWTE.


4.4.2          BOILER ASH
Boiler horizontal backpass sections present an obstacle to the flue gas stream and cause
some ash entrained in the flue gas to drop out. The residues that collect within the boil-
er's backpass hoppers are known collectively as boiler ash. Screw conveyors will collect
the boiler ash from the second and third pass and economizer hoppers of each boiler.
Double flap valves will be located above the boiler ash screw conveyors to provide air-
locks to prevent both ambient air from getting into the boiler and flue gas from getting
into the ash handling system. The screw conveyors will be routed to a main fly ash ele-
vating drag conveyor, common to both units, where the boiler ash will be comingled with
the ash collected from the AQCS equipment.


4.4.3          FLY ASH/SCRUBBER RESIDUE
Fly ash/scrubber residues will be discharged from each unit's Turbosorp® reactor recir-
culation bed through a double flap valve and screw feeder directly to the fly ash elevating
drag conveyor. Fly ash is also discharged from the corresponding fabric filter's pneumat-
ic recirculation conveyors through rotary valves to screw conveyors, which will be routed
to the same fly ash elevating drag conveyor. The height of the recirculation bed will con-
trol the rotary valve speed and fly ash discharge rate. The fly ash combines with the boil-
er ash within the common elevating drag conveyor where it is also combined with hy-
drated lime. The combined ash and lime will then be conveyed to the fly ash surge bin
within the fly ash surge bin enclosure. Pug mills/mixers will be used to wet the fly ash
discharged from the bin prior to discharging onto the fly ash elevating belt conveyor for
transport within a fully enclosed gallery to the ash and metal recovery building. Within
the building, the elevating conveyor will discharge onto the combined ash reversible
stackout conveyor where it is combined with the bottom ash prior to discharging off ei-
ther end into the combined ash storage bunker inside the ash and metal recovery building
for offsite disposal.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-44    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
4.4.4          ASH STORAGE
Storage bunkers for the ash and metals will be located inside the ash and metal recovery
building separated by 20-ft-high structural concrete walls. The different storage bunkers
will be designed to hold the equivalent of a minimum of 5 days of residues during
FCCRWTE's normal operation at full load. All ferrous and nonferrous separation equip-
ment, along with feeders and conveyors, will be located on a platform(s) above these
walls. The bottom ash will be combined with fly ash on the combined ash reversible
stackout conveyor above the storage bunkers. A front-end loader will be used to load the
combined ash onto trucks for offsite disposal. Since the volume of bottom ash generated
is much larger than the volume of fly ash, there may be instances when the bottom ash
will not be combined with fly ash before loading onto the trucks.


A wheel wash system will be provided for trucks exiting the building. It will consist of
pumps, piping, and jets that spray water onto the tires to remove any ash dust that may
stick to the tires. Wash water will then be pumped to the contact water treatment system.


There will be an operator (truckmaster) in the ash and metal recovery building who will
control and guide the trucks to the loading location for the various ash components.


4.5        WATER MANAGEMENT
4.5.1          WATER USE
County water will be used in FCCRWTE's potable water system. It will be used in the
fire protection, service water, and makeup demineralizer systems. The makeup deminer-
alizer system will treat County water by means of reverse osmosis and electro-
deionization to produce demineralized water suitable for makeup to the boiler ­ turbine
cycle. The average County water use is estimated to be 35 gallons per minute or
50,400 gallons per day (gpd).


Treated effluent from the BMWWTP will be primarily used to make up for evaporation,
drift, and blowdown in the cooling tower. The rate of cooling tower blowdown will be
regulated to produce approximately three to six cycles of concentration. A portion of the
cooling tower blowdown will be sent to the wastewater tank as needed to supply the air

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-45      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
quality control and ash handling systems. The remainder of cooling tower blowdown will
be discharged to the Potomac River through a diffuser. The average BMWWTP effluent
water use is estimated to be 1.0 to 1.2 million gpd.


Water chemistry in the cooling tower and cooling water system will be controlled by the
addition of chemicals. Sodium hypochlorite will be added to prevent biological fouling,
and sulfuric acid will be added to prevent scaling. A corrosion inhibitor will also be add-
ed.


4.5.2          WASTEWATER
The only wastewater to be discharged from FCCRWTE will be cooling tower blowdown.
The average quantity is estimated to be 0.1 to 0.4 million gpd. The cooling tower blow-
down will be discharged to the Potomac River. A National Pollutant Discharge Elimina-
tion System application was submitted to MDE in February 2011, and it identifies the
routing of the discharge to the Potomac River via an existing Frederick County Division
of Utilities and Solid Waste Management's pipeline with diffuser. Supporting infor-
mation included in the application demonstrates the impacts to the Potomac River are
minimal. Figure 4-11 depicts the water balance for the Facility.


A wastewater tank will receive rejects from reverse osmosis trains in the makeup demin-
eralizer system, boiler blowdown, and a portion of the cooling tower blowdown. Water
for the AQCS will be supplied from this tank. It will be evaporated in this system.


Water that may come into contact with ash, including floor and equipment wash down
water and blowdown from ash area air scrubbers, will be collected and treated in a con-
tact water treatment system. This water, as well as some water from the wastewater tank,
will be used as make-up to the bottom ash and fly ash handling systems.


Figures 4-12 and 4-13 provide a flow diagram of the biosolids building drain system and
contact water wastewater treatment system, respectively.

                                                                                                 4-50
4.5.3          STORMWATER
Pollutants from the handling, transfer, or storage wastes, including accidental spills and
rainfall events, will be collected and properly disposed. A stormwater management con-
cept plan (SKC-204, Stormwater Management Plan) has been submitted to and received
approval by the Frederick County Division of Permitting and Development Review as
required by Frederick County Ordinance §1-15.2-5.1, Stormwater Management Plans. A
final stormwater management development plan, including final erosion and sedimenta-
tion control plan, will be submitted to Frederick County. A preliminary erosion and sed-
imentation control plan and a response to comments letter have also been provided to the
Frederick Soil Conservation Distrct. A notice of intent for a construction general permit
will be submitted to MDE after all local approvals have been received and prior to the
initiation of construction. Figures 4-14 and 4-15 depict the stormwater management plan
and associated stormwater management details, respectively.


4.6        ODOR CONTROL
There will be three areas in FCCRWTE from which odors generated by the MSW and the
sewage sludge will emanate. These areas are the tipping bay building, solid waste storage
pit, and sewage sludge building (see Figure 4-3).


The tipping bay building is directly connected to the adjacent solid waste storage pit;
there is no dividing wall between the two. For odor generation and control consideration,
these two areas can be considered as one. The sewage sludge building is located adjacent
and connected to the tipping bay.


Odor control in the tipping bay building and solid waste storage pit areas will be achieved
by maintaining these areas under negative pressure using the boilers' primary air system.
The primary air fans of these systems will create suction from a separate high point air
intake located in the building wall above the solid waste storage pit, thus creating an air
flow path from the buildings' external openings toward the air intakes. From the air in-
takes, the air will be ducted to the fans and from the fans to the corresponding boiler. The
two independent air systems will allow the tipping bay building and the solid waste stor-
age pit to be kept under negative pressure even if one of the combustors is not operating.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-51    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
M:\acad\100104\Fig4-14 Stormwater Plan.dwg                                                Jun 26, 2012 - 9:57am by ndenahan




                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY

    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

   FIGURE 4-14.
   STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PLAN



                                                                              4-52
M:\acad\100104\Fig4-15 Stormwater Detail.dwg                                              Jun 26, 2012 - 9:59am by ndenahan




                                                                  FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES ONLY

    FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

   FIGURE 4-15.
   STORMWATER MANAGEMENT DETAILS


                                                                              4-53
In the occasional case when the two combustors are not operated, odors will be controlled
by keeping the buildings' openings closed as much as practical.


The sewage sludge building will have a separate ventilation system to create a negative
pressure within the area to control odors. The exhaust from the sewage sludge ventilation
system will be ducted to both of the boiler primary air supply intakes located above the
solid waste hoppers. Thus, the exhaust will handle odor control even when one combus-
tor is out of service. In addition, a second and separate ventilation system, that will in-
clude a carbon filter, will be installed to take suction from the sewage sludge building and
exhaust to the atmosphere. This system would be used in the occasional occurrence when
both combustors are down. It is intended that the overhead doors in the sewage sludge
building will be kept closed as much as practical, except for the ingress and egress of de-
livery vehicles.


4.7        FIRE PROTECTION
The fire protection systems, interior sprinkler systems, exterior fire mains, equipment,
and installations will be governed by the applicable sections of the following regulations,
codes or standards:
             ·          State and local codes, where existing or insurance underwriter's require-
                        ments.
             ·          National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) standards.
             ·          Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA).
             ·          Underwriters' Laboratories Fire Protection Equipment List and Factory Mu-
                        tual Approval Guide.
             ·          National Board of Fire Underwriters.
             ·          Factory Mutual loss prevention requirements.


The source of firewater will be the Frederick County water system. The maximum water
demand and pressure demand will be calculated for FCCRWTE; this will determine the
size of the supply pipeline within the Facility. A normal service electric motor-driven
firewater booster pump and an emergency firewater pump diesel engine will be used to


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-54            Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
maintain system pressure. Figure 3-3 provides the location of the emergency firewater
pump diesel engine.


The system will meet or exceed the requirements of NFPA, International Building Code,
Factory Mutual, and state of Maryland codes. Rated firewalls will be provided throughout
the plant as required by applicable codes.


4.7.1            EXTERIOR FIRE PROTECTION
An underground fire loop will be installed around the plant that will include hydrants
spaced at maximum 300-ft intervals. The loop will consist of an underground pipe sized
as required with laterals to various sprinkler areas, post indicator valves, sectional control
valves, and fire hydrants with a fully equipped fire hose house at each hydrant.


4.7.2            INTERIOR FIRE PROTECTION
Fire protection will be provided, as required, for the following structures:
             ·          Tipping Bay Building Floor Area--An automatic sprinkler system extend-
                        ing out from the solid waste storage pit wall will be installed in the tipping
                        floor area. Sprinkler density will be designed for 0.25 gallon per minute per
                        square foot (gpm/ft2) over the most remote 3,000 square feet (ft2) of floor
                        area. Hose stations will be located around the perimeter of the tipping bay
                        building.
             ·          Solid Waste Storage Pit--A preaction sprinkler system will be installed at
                        the roof over the solid waste storage pit area. The preaction sprinkler system
                        will have a density of 0.32 gpm/ft2 over the most remote 4,000 ft2 of
                        pit/floor area. An electric rate-of-rise detection system will actuate the
                        preaction valve. Manually operated water cannons will be located on the
                        charging floor around the solid waste storage pit area. Hose stations will be
                        located near the charging openings.
             ·          Turbine/Generator--Sprinklers will be provided to protect the turbine bear-
                        ings, oil reservoir, lubrication oil piping, hydrogen seal unit, and hydrogen
                        cylinders if located nearby. Hose stations will be located nearby.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-55               Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
             ·          Boiler Building--Small hose stations will be installed at various levels of
                        the boiler building. Sprinkler protection will be provided in areas where
                        flammable hydraulic oil is stored and other areas, as required.
             ·          Cooling Tower--The cooling tower will be protected with an applicable and
                        appropriate fire protection system.
             ·          Control Room and Crane Pulpit--The control room will be provided with an
                        FM-200® fire protection system with smoke detectors. This system will be
                        installed in the raised floor cable spreading room area. The ceiling of the
                        control room and crane pulpit will be provided with a double-interlock
                        preaction system with smoke detectors and quick response automatic sprin-
                        klers.
             ·          Electrical Room--The electrical room will be provided with smoke detec-
                        tors.
             ·          Administration Building--Portable (hand) fire extinguishers and a sprinkler
                        system will be installed in the administration building.


4.8        EXPLOSION CONTROL
In the unlikely event that gas containers (propane tanks) or explosives are delivered with
the solid waste, explosion events could be created in the combustor. To minimize the
chance of such events, the tipping bay operators, as well as the crane operators, will be
trained in the checking and detecting such items in the delivered solid waste and in its
removal for safe disposal. If these find their way into the combustor, any resulting explo-
sion will be absorbed in the large combustion volume.


4.9        LIQUID CONTROL
Diesel fuel will be delivered by truck and stored within FCCRWTE in an outdoor,
aboveground, steel tank encased in a concrete vault. The fuel stored in this tank will only
be used to fuel vehicles that are operated onsite (e.g., maintenance trucks, front-end load-
ers, forklifts, etc.). The preliminary nominal capacity of the tank is 2,000 gallons. The
tank's concrete encasement, with an interstitial leak detection/monitoring system, pro-
vides continuous leak detection monitoring of the primary inner steel shell. The fuel stor-


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-56               Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
age tank will be located within a curbed area to contain accidental spills during tank fill-
ing operation and maintenance.


Liquid chemicals, except for ammonia, will be stored indoors. For spill and leak control,
liquid chemicals, except for ammonia, will be stored within curbed areas with no floor
drains. The curbed areas will be of such size to contain 110 percent of the volume of the
largest storage tank within the area in case of rupture of such tank. Alternatively, some
chemicals may be stored in double-walled tanks. In those cases, the volume of the curbed
areas does not have to account for the volume of such tanks.


Aqueous ammonia (19-percent solution) will be stored outdoors under a roof canopy in a
steel tank with a preliminary nominal capacity of 10,000 gallons. The tank will be located
inside a concrete containment area with a minimum volume equal to 110 percent the ca-
pacity of the ammonia tank, plus 6 inches minimum of free board. The containment area
will be provided with a sloping roof extending beyond the containment area to minimize
the rain water collected. The containment area will be furnished with a manually operated
sump pump and drain, which will be maintained closed. In case of a spill or leak, the con-
tents will be removed by the operator for safe disposal outside FCCRWTE. Rainwater
collected in the containment area will be inspected by the operator and, if found to be
clean, will be manually drained by opening the drain valve for forwarding to the
wastewater storage tank.


The aqueous ammonia will be delivered to FCCRWTE by trucks, which will use the
ammonia delivery station designed for such purpose. The delivery station will have a
curbed area to contain any accidental spill. The curbed area will have an open drain con-
nected to the ammonia containment area, which will have its floor located lower than the
delivery station.


4.10 NOISE CONTROL
Noise generated by FCCRWTE will be controlled by integrating noise controls into the
design of the system and the structures within which key pieces of equipment are housed.
Noise control considerations include:

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-57    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
             ·          Silencers on the ID fans.
             ·          Ducted air intakes and silencers for the forced draft and distributor air fans.
             ·          Acoustical lagging treatment for the induced draft fan ductwork.
             ·          Acoustical lagging for the generator.
             ·          Silencers for the boiler safety valves and steam vents.
             ·          Silencers for dust collector fan discharges.
             ·          Silencers for other vents and fans.
             ·          Tipping and unloading activities located indoors.


It is expected that incorporation of these noise control features into the design of
FCCRWTE will result in a minimal contribution of operational noise to the surrounding
areas.


4.11 SANITARY FACILITIES
Sanitary facilities will be provided, as required, in the various areas of FCCRWTE. Sepa-
rate facilities will be provided for men and women in selected areas. Number of fixtures
provided will be commensurate with anticipated usage in the area.


At a minimum, sanitary facilities will be provided adjacent to the visitors/ reception area,
conference room(s), office areas, control room, and in the locker room.


In addition, locker room traffic flow will be arranged in a manner that employees will
pass through a clean area at the start of the shift, go to a changing area, and then enter the
Facility through the dirty area. At the end of the shift, they will enter the dirty area, dis-
card the clothing in laundry bins, shower, change, and exit through the clean area.


A separate facility will be provided adjacent to the ash and metal recovery building for
use by truck drivers, truck scale personnel, and personnel working in the ash and metal
recovery building.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-58                Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
4.12 EMERGENCY SHOWER AND EYEWASH STATIONS
Emergency shower and eyewash stations will be located in the vicinity of those areas
where chemicals or other substances that can have a harmful effect on plant personnel are
stored. Preliminarily, the locations and number of stations are as follows:
             ·          Water treatment building = 2.
             ·          Battery room = 1.
             ·          Boiler chemical injection area = 2.
             ·          Ammonia storage/unloading area = 3.
             ·          SCR ammonia injection area = 2.


The station locations and numbers be finalized in detailed design and will comply with
the requirements of American National Standards Institute No. Z358.1-2009 for Emer-
gency Eyewashes and Shower Equipment.


4.13 PLANT ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS
FCCRWTE's electric power will be supplied from the 13.8-kilovolt (kV) generator
through six transformers used to step down the voltage for distribution. The 13.8-kV
metal-clad switchgear will be constructed for indoor service and suitable for use on a
13.8-kV, three-phase, three-wire, 60-hertz system. A 4.16-kV plant system will be pro-
vided to support large motor loads and will be fed from the 13.8-kV system via step-
down transformers. A 480-volt plant distribution system will be provided to serve motors
below 250 horsepower, lighting and building services, and miscellaneous non-motor
loads


4.14 COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS
In addition to landline telephones, an intra-plant paging system will be installed (a Gai-
Tronics-type system or equal) in various areas of FCCRWTE, with receivers located in
strategic locations throughout the plant. Facility offices and the control room will be
wired for high-speed Internet access. Two-way radios will be used extensively through-
out the operation across all departments in the course of daily operations.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-59     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\ENGRPT.DOCX--061212
4.14.1 PROCESS CONTROL, INSTRUMENTATION, AND DATA LOGS
A detailed description of the process control and instrumentation for FCCRWTE will be
available when the Facility is operational.


4.14.2 COMPUTER DATA LOGS
Computer data logs will be captured and maintained. FCCRWTE will use sophisticated,
computerized tracking systems to capture operating data of the critical equipment and
systems. This data will be used for trending, analysis, maintenance planning, and to en-
sure that required reports (whether required by permit, facility operating contract, OSHA,
regulatory agencies, etc.) are prepared and submitted in a timely manner.


A state-of-the-art plant data logging system will be provided that will log and record a
multitude of plant parameters on a regular, timed basis. The data logger will be config-
ured to support the permits, monitoring requirements, and preferences.

Table 4-2 identifies FCCRWTE's typical major items of equipment including manufac-
turer, type, model, capacity, and number of units. This equipment list should be consid-
ered preliminary as final design has not been completed. Equipment manufacturers are
for illustration purposes only. Equivalent equipment may be selected as part of the final
engineering design.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.         iii         Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                                                          GLOSSARY OF TERMS

Acceptable Material                           municipal solid waste consisting of materials and substances dis-
                                              carded or rejected as being spent, useless, worthless, or in excess
                                              to the owners at the time of such discard or rejection, including,
                                              without limitation, waste, garbage, trash, rubbish, and refuse that
                                              is normally disposed of by, and collected from, residential, com-
                                              mercial, industrial, governmental, or institutional establishments.
                                              Acceptable waste will be composed of waste materials or debris
                                              that can be combusted, having a composition with characteristics
                                              such as that collected and disposed of as part of normal collec-
                                              tions of waste materials and debris in Frederick and Carroll
                                              Counties as well as other areas (as approved by NEA) outside the
                                              primary service areas, Acceptable and processible solid waste
                                              will include but not be limited to:

                                                     ·    Acceptable sewage sludge
                                                     ·    Garbage, rubbish, trash, and refuse
                                                     ·    Witness burn documents, paper, cardboard, cartons, and
                                                          boxes
                                                     ·    Automobile and truck tires, as permitted
                                                     ·    Rags, cloth, and bedding
                                                     ·    Leather
                                                     ·    Plastics
                                                     ·    Beds, mattresses, sofas, and carpeting
                                                     ·    Bicycles, commingled tin cans, and other noncombustible
                                                          residential waste
                                                     ·    Combustible construction and demolition debris
                                                     ·    Combustible commercial and industrial waste materials or
                                                          debris
                                                     ·    Commingled small quantities of grass, leaves, brush, yard
                                                          trimmings, and tree limbs
                                                     ·    Lumber, logs, and trees no more than 4 feet long and/or 6
                                                          inches in diameter

Acceptable Recycla-                           material accepted by the respective Counties' curbside single-
ble Material                                  stream recycling programs, drop-off recycling centers, and ma-
                                              terial recovery facilities

bulky/oversized items                         large items of solid waste that, because of their size or weight,
                                              require handling other than normally used for solid waste

CFR                                           Code of Federal Regulations




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.              iv                      Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                                                          GLOSSARY OF TERMS
                                                           (Continued, Page 2 of 4)

collection                                    act of picking up solid waste at its point of generation or storage
                                              and placing it in a vehicle for transportation

COMAR                                         Code of Maryland Regulations

commercial waste                              waste materials originating in business, wholesale, retail, institu-
                                              tional, or service establishments

compost                                       relatively stable decomposed organic material resulting from the
                                              composting process

County/Counties                               Frederick and/or Carroll Counties

curbside collection                           collection programs where Acceptable Material or Acceptable
                                              Recyclable Material are collected at the curb, often using special
                                              containers, to be brought to various processing and disposal facil-
                                              ities

disposal                                      orderly processing and placement of solid waste including but not
                                              limited to transfer station, incineration, and landfill

drop-off facility                             method of collecting recyclable or compostable materials in
                                              which the materials are taken by individuals to collection sites
                                              and deposited into designated containers

DUSWM                                         Frederick County Division of Utilities and Solid Waste Manage-
                                              ment

EAC                                           Carroll County Environmental Advisory Council

Facility                                      Frederick/Carroll County Renewable Waste-To-Energy Facility

FCCRWTE                                       Frederick/Carroll County Renewable Waste-To-Energy Facility

generator                                     one who produces waste materials

grasscycling                                  recycling grass clippings through use of mulching mowers or
                                              leaving clippings on the lawn

hauler                                        one engaged in the act of collection of solid waste and or trans-
                                              porting such waste between solid waste facilities




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.              v                     Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                                                          GLOSSARY OF TERMS
                                                           (Continued, Page 3 of 4)

HHW                                           household hazardous waste--refuse, sludge, or other waste ma-
                                              terial generated in a residential household (exempt from regula-
                                              tions governing hazardous waste due to relatively small volume
                                              of generation) that, because of quantity, concentrations, or chemi-
                                              cal, physical, or infectious characteristics, as defined in
                                              40 CFR 261, may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to
                                              human health or the environment when improperly treated,
                                              stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed

landfill                                      facility at which solid waste is deposited on or into the land as fill
                                              for the purpose of complete and ultimate disposal and which has
                                              received all necessary permits

MDE                                           Maryland Department of the Environment

MES                                           Maryland Environmental Service

MOU                                           memorandum of understanding

MRA                                           Maryland Recycling Act

MRF                                           material recovery facility--a processing facility designed, operat-
                                              ed, and permitted to process a nonhazardous source-separated
                                              material waste stream by using manual and/or mechanical me-
                                              thods to separate from incoming material stream categories of
                                              useful, reusable, or recyclable material for reprocessing and reuse

MSP                                           materials separation plan

MSW                                           municipal solid waste--garbage, refuse, rubbish, trash, and other
                                              solid waste from residential, commercial, industrial, and commu-
                                              nity generators that is collected in aggregate but does not include
                                              special handling wastes, hazardous waste, HHW, Acceptable Re-
                                              cyclable Material, residual waste, automobile hulks, ash, non-
                                              combustible construction and demolition debris, mining wastes,
                                              industrial sludge, agricultural wastes, tires, and other materials
                                              collected, processed, and disposed of as separate waste streams

NEA                                           Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority

NSPS                                          New Source Performance Standards (as defined by the U.S. Envi-
                                              ronmental Protection Agency)

                                                          GLOSSARY OF TERMS
                                                           (Continued, Page 4 of 4)

processible solid                             waste that was not recycled and is available to process at the
waste                                         WTE facility

recyclables                                   materials that can be separated from the waste stream and con-
                                              verted into raw materials from which new products can be manu-
                                              factured

recyclable white                              large appliances (i.e., generally weighing more than 50 pounds)
goods                                         including but not necessarily limited to air conditioners, clothes
                                              washing and drying machines, dish washers, hot water heaters,
                                              refrigerators and freezers, or stoves and ovens

solid waste                                   garbage, refuse, residue, sludge, and other nonliquid discarded
                                              materials resulting from personal, residential, community, min-
                                              ing, agricultural, industrial, or commercial activity

SWMP                                          solid waste management plan--county plans developed as re-
                                              quired by MDE regulations (COMAR 26.03.03)

tpd                                           ton(s) per day

tpy                                           ton(s) per year

transfer station                              intermediate waste facility at which mixed MSW or other mate-
                                              rials are temporarily deposited before being transported to a
                                              processing facility

waste diversion rate                          MRA recycling rate plus the MDE source reduction credit.

waste-to-energy                               conversion of solid waste into energy to produce steam and/or
                                              electricity

WTE                                           waste-to-energy

WTI                                           Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc.

white goods                                   refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, air conditioners, hot wa-
                                              ter heaters, etc.

yard waste                                    materials normally generated in the maintenance of gardens,
                                              yards, lawns, or landscaped areas, whether residential, commer-
                                              cial, or public, including leaves, grass clippings, plants, shrubs,
                                              prunings, and trimmings



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.              vii                   Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                                                          1.0 INTRODUCTION


1.1        PURPOSE
The purpose of this final draft materials separation plan (MSP) is to identify the goals and
approaches for separating certain components of the municipal solid waste (MSW)
stream in the Frederick and Carroll Counties' (the Counties') service areas in order to
make the separated materials available for recycling. The nonrecycled Acceptable Ma-
terial will be processed at the Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority's (NEA's)
Frederick/Carroll County Renewable Waste-to-Energy Facility (FCCRWTE or the Facili-
ty). FCCRWTE will also accept tires under a scrap tire acceptance permit and sewage
sludge under a sewage sludge utilization permit. Both Counties have contractually desig-
nated FCCRWTE as the central solid waste acceptance facility for the disposal of nonre-
cycled Acceptable Material generated in their respective county.


This final draft MSP fulfills one of the requirements of Title 40 of the Code of Federal
Regulations (CFR), Part 60, Subpart Eb, New Source Performance Standards (NSPS) for
FCCRWTE.


The standard also prescribes a specific process that must be followed to ensure the oppor-
tunity for public review and comment on the draft MSP. The process consists of the fol-
lowing:
             ·          Preparation and issuance of a preliminary draft MSP for public comment.
             ·          Notification of a public meeting for accepting oral and written comments on
                        the preliminary draft MSP.
             ·          Acceptance of written comments on the preliminary draft MSP.
             ·          Preparation of written responses to any public comments.
             ·          Identification of the location(s) where written responses to public comment
                        on the preliminary draft MSP will be available for inspection.
             ·          Preparation of a final draft MSP, considering the public comments
             ·          Submission of the following to the Maryland Department of the Environ-
                        ment (MDE) as part of the facility's application for a construction permit:


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.         1-1            Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                        o          Copy of the notification of the public meeting.
                        o          Transcript of the public meeting.
                        o          Document summarizing responses to public comments.
                        o          Copies of both the preliminary draft and final draft MSPs.


1.2        BACKGROUND
NEA was created by the State of Maryland to assist its member jurisdictions with their
integrated solid waste needs. NEA's member jurisdictions include seven Maryland coun-
ties and the city of Baltimore. The Counties are both members of NEA and have entered
into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) by and among Frederick County, Carroll
County, and NEA for the development of a regional energy recovery facility (July 2009).
This MOU describes the site location in Frederick County; the ownership, design, and
capacity of the Facility; as well as the responsibilities of NEA, the Counties, and the
Vendor, Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc. (WTI).


WTI has entered into a service contract with NEA for the design, construction, and opera-
tion of a 1,500-tons-per-day (tpd) nominal regional waste-to-energy (WTE) facility in
Frederick County, Maryland. The Facility will serve the long-term solid waste disposal
needs of Frederick and Carroll Counties, as well as produce for sale approximately
45 megawatts of electricity to meet the Counties' governmental energy needs.
FCCRWTE will be owned by NEA.


Each county in Maryland is required to have a county solid waste management plan
(SWMP) in accordance with the Code of Maryland Regulations (COMAR),
Title 26.03.03. Both Counties have approved SWMPs. Carroll County's most recent
SWMP (Carroll County, Maryland 10-Year Solid Waste Management Plan 2002 ­ 2012
[Updated 2006]) was approved by MDE in 2007. Frederick County's most recent SWMP
(Frederick County, Maryland Division of Utilities and Solid Waste Management Solid
Waste Management Plan 1998 ­ 2017) was revised and approved by the Frederick Coun-
ty Board of County Commissioners in 2010 and conditionally approved by MDE in 2011.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.    1-2                       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
This final draft MSP has been prepared to satisfy the federal air permit application re-
quirements (40 CFR 60.57b). NEA is acting on behalf of the Counties in seeking the
permits for FCCRWTE and, as such, has incorporated aspects of the Counties' current
approved SWMPs and currently planned revisions in this MSP. Table 1-1 identifies spe-
cific goals of the Counties' plans.


Each of the Counties' SWMPs and recycling programs strive to reduce the amount of ma-
terials entering the MSW stream, thus reducing the amount of wastes needing to be trans-
ported either out of state for disposal or to a local landfill. In general, the recognized ben-
efits of reducing the MSW stream through recycling include a reduction in transportation
costs, a reduction in the amount of disposal fees to the citizens due to reduced volumes,
and an increase in the longevity of the life of the local landfills. Most importantly, by ac-
tively supporting recycling efforts, the Counties and NEA are preserving valuable re-
sources. In addition, the SWMPs act as guidance documents to assure that the Counties
meet and exceed the state of Maryland's mandatory 20-percent recycling goal for each
county and the voluntary statewide waste diversion goal of 40 percent (Annotated Code
of Maryland, Env. Art. §9-1705).


NEA, through its contractor WTI, will achieve additional recycling at FCCRWTE with
the recovery of recyclable metals (ferrous and nonferrous) from the waste stream both
before and after processing. Large bulky metal items will be recovered on the tipping
floor, while other metals will be collected in FCCRWTE's ferrous and nonferrous metal
recovery systems. Recovered metals will be recycled.


The Counties' recycling programs will not compete with FCCRWTE for solid waste. On-
ly solid waste that is not recycled will be used for conversion into energy at FCCRWTE.
It has been shown that communities nationwide using WTE programs have an aggregate
recycling rate at least 5 percentage points above the national average (Recycling and
Waste-to-Energy, Are They Compatible? 2009 Update Governmental Advisory Asso-
ciates, Inc., Eileen Brettler Berenyi June 2009). This is true in Maryland as Baltimore,
Harford, and Montgomery Counties have some of the highest MDE waste diversion rates
(MDE 2009 data: 42.94, 62.03, and 47.04 percent, respectively).

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   1-3          Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711

                          · Maintain the solid waste program

   Carroll                · Provide for facilities that are adequate to treat, recover, or dispose of
                            solid waste in a manner that is consistent with the applicable state, fed-
                            eral, and local laws and regulations that relate to air pollution, water
                            pollution, and land use

                            and recycling that allows sufficient flexibility to react to changes in

                                   2.0 SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM


2.1        SERVICE AREAS
The primary service areas for the MSP described in this document include residential,
business, industrial, institutional, and commercial waste generators of Frederick and Car-
roll Counties, Maryland. FCCRWTE has been sized to meet the needs of the Counties
over the planned life of the facility and, therefore, is sized to accommodate growth. Addi-
tional waste from outside the primary service area must be accepted to enable
FCCRWTE to operate at its designed capacity. NEA will allow Acceptable Waste from
outside the Counties' service area upon written direction from both Counties.


2.2        FACILITIES AND COMPONENTS
2.2.1         FREDERICK COUNTY
2.2.1.1 Collection
The city of Frederick provides collection of MSW using municipal employees and
equipment. The remainder of the incorporated municipalities contract directly with pri-
vate haulers.


Citizens not living within an incorporated area of Frederick County may have the collec-
tion of MSW provided by their home owners association via contract (if applicable), are
free to contract with a private hauler, or may take their waste directly to the Reichs Ford
Road Landfill (see Table 2-1).


Commercial and institutional establishments in unincorporated areas of Frederick County
and certain incorporated portions of the County may also contract directly with private
haulers or self-haul directly to the landfill.


2.2.1.2 Collection Agreements
Frederick County entered into an agreement with BFI Waste Services, LLC, designating
them as Frederick County's private hauler for the residential single-stream recyclable
program.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.              2-2             Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
2.2.1.3 Recycling Drop-Off Facilities
Only County residents may use any of the 11 recycling drop-off locations in Frederick
County for single-stream recycling. Schools, businesses, churches, organized groups, or
commercial entities must contract with a solid waste management contractor for recy-
cling services. The locations of the recycling drop-off facilities are:
             ·          214 13th Avenue, Brunswick.
             ·          3612 Buckeystown Pike, Buckeystown.
             ·          1200 North East Street, Frederick.
             ·          1820 Rosemount Avenue, Frederick.
             ·          9031 Reichs Ford Road, Frederick (also a landfill).
             ·          4606 Lander Road, Jefferson.
             ·          7628 Coblentz Road, Middletown.
             ·          8098 Crum Road, Mt. Pleasant.
             ·          30 Eyler Road, Thurmont.
             ·          3604 Urbana Pike, Frederick.
             ·          8948 Indian Springs Road, Frederick.


In addition to residential single-stream recycling collection, the Reichs Ford Road Facili-
ty accepts commercial single-stream recycling, bulky/oversized rigid plastic items, tex-
tiles, scrap metal, motor oil, flexible foam, white goods, lead acid batteries, antifreeze,
tires, and electronics. Residential and commercial single-stream recyclables are sent to
the Recycle America Material Recovery Facility (MRF) in Elkridge, Maryland.


Unbagged or paper bagged (only) leaves, grass clippings, brush trimmings, and limbs (no
longer than 8 feet [ft] long and 6 inches in diameter) can be left by residents at two Coun-
ty locations: Reichs Ford Road Yard Trimmings/Mulch and Compost Site and Walkers-
ville Heritage Farm Park (drop-off only). There is currently no cost to drop off these ma-
terials. This program currently produces two grades of mulch: premium double-ground
and basic single-ground. The program also produces a finished, screened compost prod-
uct. These products are for sale in bulk at the Reichs Ford Road facility.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-3                 Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
2.2.1.4 Transfer Stations
Frederick County currently has in operation an MSW transfer facility capable of accept-
ing solid waste at no more than 720,000 tons per year (tpy) of MSW. The transfer station
is located at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill site. The transfer facility provides benefits of
an integrated solid waste management program by providing the following:
             ·          Extension of the life of Reichs Ford Road Landfill by transporting MSW to
                        out-of-county disposal facilities.
             ·          Long-term options for recycling and/or managing nonprocessible waste.
             ·          Convenient residential and commercial single-stream recyclables process-
                        sing/transfer to contract MRFs.


Upon construction of FCCRWTE, the transfer station may be used to transfer incoming
MSW to the Facility for processing


2.2.1.5 Landfills
According to the 2010 Frederick County SWMP, there are several landfills in operation
for waste collection and disposal purposes in Frederick County:
             ·          The Reichs Ford Road Sanitary Landfill, Site B, is a 58-acre sanitary landfill
                        located on 183 acres approximately 4 miles east of the city of Frederick.
                        This landfill is owned by Frederick County and accepts wastes from residen-
                        tial, business, commercial, and institutional entities.
             ·          The Fort Detrick Landfill is a sanitary landfill located on 61 acres of land in
                        the northwest corner of the city of Frederick and owned by the U.S. Army.
                        This landfill accepts U.S. Army bypass (unburnable) waste and incinerator
                        ash.
             ·          The Eastalco facility is a private 10-acre industrial waste landfill located in
                        the southern part of Frederick County and owned by Eastalco Aluminum
                        Company, Inc. This facility accepts Eastalco potliner brick and pollution
                        control device debris wastes. Operations were curtailed in December 2005.
                        Eastalco has a MDE solid waste disposal permit that expires in October
                        2014.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-4                     Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
             ·          The Eyler Land Clearing Debris Landfill is a 14-acre rubblefill located in
                        northeastern Frederick County and owned by John C. Eyler. This landfill
                        accepts land-clearing debris only.


2.2.2         CARROLL COUNTY
2.2.2.1 Collection
Businesses and residents in unincorporated areas of Carroll County can either self-haul
their waste and recyclables to the Northern Landfill and Recycling Center or Hoods Mill
Landfill convenience center or contract for the services directly with any hauler licensed
by Carroll County. Under the licensing requirements, each hauler is required to offer col-
lection for all County-approved recyclables. Seven of the incorporated municipalities
provide waste and recycling services for their residents through contractors. Sykesville
provides collection of MSW and recyclables using municipal employees and equipment.
(see Table 2-2).


2.2.2.2 Collection Agreements
Although no formal agreements exist between any one hauler and Carroll County, haulers
used within the seven municipalities and/or unincorporated portions of Carroll County
must secure a license from Carroll County and operate under the requirements of the Car-
roll County Solid Waste Ordinance (Chapter 185 Solid Waste).


2.2.2.3 Recycling Drop-Off Facilities
Businesses and residents may use both of the recycling drop-off facilities located at Car-
roll County's two landfill sites. The landfill sites accept single-stream recycling items in
addition to bulky/oversized items, textiles, scrap metal, automotive materials, motor oil,
antifreeze, tires, and electronics. The locations of the recycling drop-off facilities are:
             ·          1400 Baltimore Boulevard, Westminster (Northern Landfill).
             ·          7901 Kabik Court, Woodbine (Hoods Mill Landfill).


The Recycling Center, located at the Northern Landfill, accepts materials recycled
through the Carroll County's curbside program (Acceptable Recyclable Materials) plus
textiles, rigid plastics, grocery and empty clear food bags, CD/DVD cases and disks, car

and truck batteries, used motor oil, antifreeze, vinyl siding, used frying oil, and kitchen
grease. Aluminum can reimbursement is offered during certain times. Reimbursement
rates fluctuate with the aluminum market value.


The Northern Landfill also accepts for recycling white goods/scrap metal and electronics
and has a waste exchange program through The Northern Landfill Swap Shop.


Separated yard trimmings are accepted at the yard waste area at Carroll County Landfills.
The wood trimmings, grass, and leaves are mulched. The mulch is available to Carroll
County residents at no charge.


Recycled Green Industries, LLC (Recycled Green), leases a parcel of the Hoods Mill
Landfill for the operation of a compost/soil amendment program. The program operates
by receiving food and yard waste material (generated both in and out of Carroll County),
treating it, mixing it with soil, and selling it in bulk. In 2009, Recycled Green accepted a
reported 34,000 tons of yard waste material.


2.2.2.4 Material Recovery Facility
A MRF began operation adjacent to the transfer station at the Northern Landfill in 1999.
The MRF has a permitted capacity of 61,000 tpy of commingled recyclables (residential
and commercial), although it has historically processed approximately 14,000 tpy. Con-
tainers (glass, plastic, and cans) are reloaded and sent to another facility outside Carroll
County for further processing. Old corrugated cardboard and mixed paper are baled and
sent to markets. The MRF is a County-owned facility; however, the operation, transfer,
and processing are contracted through a private operator.


2.2.2.5 Transfer Stations
Carroll County currently has in operation an MSW transfer facility located at the North-
ern Landfill site with a permitted capacity of 305,000 tpy of MSW. It has historically
transferred between 66,000 and 104,000 tpy of MSW to landfills in Virginia and Penn-
sylvania.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-7        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
The transfer facility provides benefits of an integrated solid waste management program
by providing the following:
             ·          Extension of the life of Northern Landfill by transporting MSW to out-of-
                        county disposal facilities.
             ·          Long-term options for recycling and/or managing nonprocessible waste.
             ·          Convenient residential and commercial single-stream recyclables process-
                        sing/transfer to contract MRFs.


Upon construction of FCCRWTE, the transfer station may be used to transfer incoming
MSW to the Facility for processing


Roll-Off Express is a privately owned and operated waste processing facility on Dede
Road in Finksburg that is open to the public and contractors. Roll-Off Express recycles
wood, cardboard, metal, and concrete. Residuals are disposed of in properly permitted
solid waste facilities outside of Carroll County.


2.2.2.6 Landfills
According to the Carroll County 10-Year Solid Waste Management Plan 2002 - 2012
(Updated 2006), Carroll County currently has one landfill, the Northern Landfill, in oper-
ation for waste collection and disposal purposes. The Northern Landfill is located on
200 acres of land and is owned by Carroll County. The facility accepts all types of resi-
dential and commercial solid wastes.


The Hoods Mill Landfill, located on 125 acres of land and also owned by Carroll County,
is no longer in operation as a landfill. This facility is now currently accepting wastes for
transfer, recycling, and yard waste for mulching. The Hoods Mill facility operates as a
noncommercial customer convenience drop-off station on Saturdays only. Waste and re-
cyclables are backhauled to Northern Landfill for processing. Carroll County also distri-
butes mulch from this site.


C. J. Miller, LLC, located on Dede Road in Finksburg, is the only construction and demo-
lition facility in Carroll County that accepts and/or processes waste for reuse or disposal.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-8               Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
The facility accepts broken concrete and old asphalt paving, which is crushed and used as
aggregate in new asphalt.


2.3        SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL AGREEMENTS
To provide economical, efficient, and environmentally responsible solid waste disposal
services, the Counties have entered into agreements with multiple companies for waste
disposal.


2.3.1         FREDERICK COUNTY
Frederick County, in cooperation with Carroll County in July of 2009, entered into an
MOU and an Energy Recovery Agreement with NEA for the development of a 1,500-tpd
WTE facility to provide long-term disposal capacity for the Counties.


Frederick County entered into an agreement with NEA to develop landfill gas processing
at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill for electricity generation in 2009.


Frederick County currently has solid waste transfer and single-stream recyclables
processing contracts through NEA. Frederick County uses two NEA contracts for the
transportation and disposal of Acceptable Material. They also use an NEA contract for
the transportation and processing of single-stream recyclables. All three contracts transfer
material from the transfer station at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill.


2.3.2         CARROLL COUNTY
Carroll County, in cooperation with Frederick County in July of 2009, entered into an
MOU and Energy Recovery Agreement with NEA for the development of a 1,500-tpd
WTE facility to provide long-term disposal capacity for the Counties.


Interstate Waste Services, Inc., currently has a contract to transfer at least 50,000 tpy of
MSW from Northern Landfill to one of three Subtitle D permitted landfills in Pennsylva-
nia.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-9          Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
2.4        MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE QUANTITIES AND PROJECTIONS
2.4.1         FREDERICK COUNTY
Frederick County is currently experiencing a growth in its population. Population growth
is an important part of waste management planning, because it provides a base to esti-
mate the amount of waste that will be produced based on projected population growth
and waste generation rates. The Frederick County Comprehensive Plan (April 2010)
(Figure 02-3, Historic and Projected Population [Page 02-8]) shows the 2010 population
of 235,364 growing to a projected population of 331,700 through 2030.


Waste generation projections for Frederick County were obtained from NEA's planning
model. Typically, as the population increases, so does the amount of waste generated,
even if the per capita waste generation rate plateaus and does not increase.


With the full implementation of the residential single-stream recycling program through-
out the County, in addition to planned policies and programs, Frederick County antic-
ipates the amount of waste materials separated for recycling to increase, along with the
population and amount of municipal wastes generated. Figure 2-1 depicts the Frederick
County recycling and waste tonnage projections.


2.4.2         CARROLL COUNTY
Carroll County is currently experiencing a growth in its population. Population growth is
an important part of waste management planning, because it provides a base to project an
estimate of the amount of waste that will be produced based on past populations and
waste generation rates. The Carroll County Comprehensive Plan (October 2010) (Chapter
2: Page 15) shows the 2010 population of 171,739 growing to a projected population of
203,036 through 2030.


According to the Carroll County SWMP (updated 2006), it is also anticipated that, as the
population has increased, so will the amount of wastes generated.


With the continuous implementation of the single-stream recycling program and policies
in place, in addition to future policies and programs, Carroll County anticipates the
