                                           3.0 MATERIALS SEPARATION PLAN


3.1        OBJECTIVES/GOALS
The Maryland Recycling Act (MRA) (Annotated Code of Maryland, Environment Article
§ 9-1705) requires that counties with populations greater than 150,000 recycle 20 percent
of their waste. Additionally, in 2000, Maryland established a voluntary statewide waste
diversion goal of 40 percent by 2005. The waste diversion goal is comprised of the MRA
recycling rate plus source reduction credits (maximum 5 percent) that Maryland counties
earn through activities designed to reduce the amount of waste going to the waste stream.
The MRA excludes from its scope certain scrap metals, land clearing debris, construction
and demolition debris, sewage sludge, and hospital wastes. As part of the monitoring of
recycling activity, annual collection of data is gathered from businesses that recycle all or
part of their waste. Each county collects local data then submits information to MDE. Re-
cyclable materials tracked in this annual report include:
             ·          Compostables--Mixed yard waste, wood waste, and food waste.
             ·          Glass--Containers, mixed glass, and fluorescent light tubes.
             ·          Metals--Cans, scrap, and white goods.
             ·          Paper--Corrugated cardboard, mixed paper, newspaper, books, telephone
                        books, and shredded paper.
             ·          Plastic--Mixed plastics, films, and containers.
             ·          Other Materials--Laser toner cartridges, lead-acid batteries, oil filters, and
                        wood pallets.


The latest available MRA data from MDE are "County Recyclables by Commodity in
Tons for Calendar Year 2009" and can be found at http://www.mde.state.md.us/programs
/Land/RecyclingandOperationsprogram/StateCountyandCityContactInfo/Pages/programs/
landprograms/recycling/local/recylingrates.aspx; accessed January 28, 2011.


The Counties intend to meet and exceed these recycling goals with the cooperation of
their citizens, businesses, and FCCRWTE. Recycling is a crucial component of the Coun-
ties' integrated waste management systems.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-1                  Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
3.2        FREDERICK COUNTY
3.2.1         MATERIALS SEPARATION STRATEGY
For calendar year 2009, MDE certified Frederick County's waste diversion rate
(41.63-percent MRA recycling rate and 5-percent source reduction credit) as
46.63 percent. Frederick County Commissioners have established a waste diversion goal
(material removed from the waste stream through recycling, composting, and other strat-
egies including source reduction credits) of 60 percent by the year 2025.


Frederick County's Department of Solid Waste Management February 2010 newsletter
(Volume 2, Issue 1) notes that during the first year (2009) of the Frederick County single-
stream recycling system, the residential recycling program experienced a dramatic in-
crease in not only the number of households actively participating but also in the amount
of material being collected. The program witnessed an escalation in the 37-percent set-
out rate from the old dual-stream program; set-out rates in the new single-stream program
average around 65 percent--almost doubled. (The recycling set-out rate is the percentage
of households that set-out for curbside pick-up on a particular day.) The tons of material
collected from curbside recycling increased an average of 66 percent between 2008 and
2009. Frederick County also amplified its education efforts by adding new staff to the
Office of Recycling team to create newspaper articles, public service announcements, and
residential communications (including the newsletter) throughout the year.


3.2.1.1 Education/Awareness/Outreach
Public education, awareness, and outreach are integral parts of the recycling portion of
the Frederick County SWMP. Frederick County incorporates outreach and education
elements into almost all of the different recycling programs. For example, a significant
amount of outreach is attributed to the contract curbside recycling program and therefore
assigned as a cost for that particular program and not reflected in the separate outreach
program budget.


Frederick County has a recycling outreach coordinator, a commercial recycling program
coordinator, and additional staff support (total 2.1 full time equivalents) devoted to the

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-2       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
recycling education/outreach effort. The recycling outreach program coordinator is avail-
able for answering recycling or composting questions, providing on- or offsite education-
al programs, coordinate events, and provide information on recycling and waste man-
agement practices in Frederick County. The staff provides technical assistance to busi-
nesses in establishing or expanding their existing recycling and waste reduction pro-
grams. The staff is also available to provide information on available recycling resources,
monitoring solid waste and recycling activities, waste reduction strategies, and other en-
vironmentally friendly tips.


The annual expenditures for recycling education/outreach during the 2010 fiscal year
were $218,904.


Frederick County maintains a recycling page on its county government Web site
(http://frederickcountymd.gov/index.aspx?nid=1764; accessed January 11, 2011). Four
times a year, the Frederick County Department of Solid Waste Management issues an
informative digital newsletter. This newsletter can either be viewed on the Frederick
County Web page (http://frederickcountymd.gov /index.aspx?NID=3941; accessed Janu-
ary 11, 2011) or it is available for direct e-mail upon request. The Frederick County De-
partment of Solid Waste Management also conducts direct mailing up to four times per
year to all single-family homes to provide updates and guidance on the curbside recycling
program.


A guidebook, titled A Citizens Guide to Waste Management in Frederick County, was
created to provide information on recycling and waste reduction. This booklet serves as a
resource that covers topics from waste disposal programs to maps of the facilities and
contact numbers. The booklet may either be downloaded from the Frederick County Web
site (http://frederickcountymd.gov/index.aspx?NID=4046; accessed January 11, 2011) or
requested in a printed format.


A similar guidebook, titled Mind Your Business! Guide to Integrated Waste Management
Practices for Organizations and Workplaces, was created specifically to address the
needs of businesses and organizations within Frederick County. This guidebook is avail-

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-3       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
able for download (http://frederickcountymd.gov/index.aspx?NID=3473; accessed Janu-
ary 11, 2011) or a printed copy by request.


According to Frederick County's Department of Solid Waste Management, Frederick
County was a recent recipient of a grant from The Curbside Value Partnership (CVP), a
program of Keep America Beautiful, Inc. CVP selected three communities nationwide to
work with that have strong existing curbside recycling programs, the means to measure
the effectiveness of those programs, and a desire to "think outside the box" when it
comes to educating their residents about recycling. The "Learn More, Recycle Better"
campaign officially kicked off on September 16, 2010, with discussion of campaign de-
tails and plans for a countywide education blitz that will include billboards, radio, cine-
ma, and print advertisements; direct homeowner outreach; and a new Web site
(http://www.LearnMoreRecycleBetter.org).


3.2.1.2 Waste Generation Prevention/Reduction
Frederick County encourages waste generation prevention and source reduction as an
integral part of their waste management and recycling plan. The County has a multifa-
ceted waste reduction program using advertising, educational, and informative programs
and techniques. They also offer assistance to both commercial and residential entities
providing education and practical applications.


To encourage local business owners to create less waste, Frederick County, in coopera-
tion with other local agencies and organizations, created a new awards program to recog-
nize the innovative steps that forward-thinking local businesses are taking to create less
waste. Participating businesses compete by using waste prevention and source reduction
techniques for the annual Frederick County Source Reduction Award. This program en-
courages businesses to incorporate waste prevention and source reduction policies in the
workplace.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-4       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
3.2.2         MATERIALS SEPARATION PROGRAMS
3.2.2.1 Single-Stream Recycling
Frederick County has incorporated single-stream recycling as part of their recycling pro-
gram. Because no separation of materials is necessary, single-stream recycling is easier
and more appealing than traditional curbside recycling programs that require items to be
placed in separate bins. Single-stream recycling is a service provided to single-family
homes in Frederick County through curbside service at a cost of approximately
$4,033,000 (2010 fiscal year). The Department of Solid Waste Management has com-
pleted some preliminary work on a 6-month multifamily recycling pilot program for
apartments and condominiums in Frederick County. This draft pilot program has not been
finalized and is not likely to be implemented until fiscal year 2012.


In addition, the single-stream recycling approach applies to recycling drop-off facilities in
Frederick County. Single-stream recycling for commercial and industrial facilities is pro-
vided on a case-by-case basis by their respective contracted hauler.


The following items are accepted in Frederick County's single-stream recycling program
(Citizens             Guide            to       Waste     Management   in   Frederick   County        Fall     2009;
http://frederickcountymd.gov/documents/Utilities%20&%20Solid%20Waste%20Manage
ment/Recycling/DSWM%20Residential%20Guidebook%20for%20web.PDF;                                             accessed
January 11, 2011):
             ·          Magazines and catalogs, junk mail, and envelopes.
             ·          Newspapers, including inserts.
             ·          Brown paper bags.
             ·          Nonmetallic wrapping paper and craft paper.
             ·          Paperboard boxes (cracker and cereal boxes without liners).
             ·          Thick paper (cardstock, file folders, etc.).
             ·          Corrugated cardboard.
             ·          Books (paperbacks, hardbacks and telephone books).
             ·          Clean paper products (colored and white, such as typing, fax, copy, letter-
                        head, notebooks, etc.).


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.         3-5                     Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
             ·          Shredded paper.
             ·          Milk cartons (paper or plastic) and juice boxes (not juice pouches).
             ·          Glass food and beverage containers (jars and bottles).
             ·          Tin and steel food and beverage containers (pet food, soup and vegetable
                        cans).
             ·          Aluminum food and beverage containers (clean aluminum foil and alumi-
                        num pie pans).
             ·          Empty aerosol cans.
             ·          Plastic bags (grocery bags, newspaper bags, and others) gathered together
                        within one bag.
             ·          Empty household plastic containers and lids, including narrow-neck bottles
                        and wide-mouth containers such as peanut butter, margarine, or yogurt con-
                        tainers, etc.


If there is a new material added by the single-stream recycling vendor, Frederick County
will add that material to the list of accepted items for curbside recycling.


Business Recycling
In Frederick County, businesses, institutions, and industries account for nearly 50 percent
of Frederick County's MSW; therefore, it is important that these facilities incorporate
aspects of Frederick County's SWMP into their business. To ensure that companies assist
in meeting the recycling goal, Frederick County recommends that businesses, institutions,
and industries work together with the County and the Chamber of Commerce to continue
to track recycling progress and provide literature, forums, and programs on business re-
cycling.


The city of Frederick in 2010 began offering free recycling services to commercial busi-
nesses located within a pilot project area. The pilot project area coincides with those
downtown streets that currently receive six-night-a-week trash service from the city of
Frederick.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-6                    Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
While the Frederick County Department of Solid Waste Management does not provide
recycling collection services for businesses or commercial properties in Frederick Coun-
ty, it does offer a financial incentive for those businesses that choose to recycle. There is
a tipping fee differential to encourage commercial properties to recycle single-stream; the
base tipping fee for municipal solid waste is $76, while the fee for 1 ton of single-stream
recycling is $25.


The Department of Solid Waste Management also has a commercial recycling program
coordinator to assist businesses in establishing or expanding existing recycling and waste
reduction programs. The program coordinator provides general overall support for recy-
cling program implementation through assisting with waste audits, training employees
and custodial staff, providing public presentations for meetings and trainings, providing
reproducible literature on recycling and waste reduction, providing templates for creating
posters and newsletter information, sharing a database of service contacts and networking
information, and providing a step-by-step guide to integrated waste management practic-
es to reduce waste in the workplace.


3.2.2.2 Additional Recyclable Programs
Additional recyclable materials are accepted at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill. These in-
clude:
             ·          Bulky/Oversized Rigid Plastics--Lawn furniture, toys (such as outdoor play
                        sets), coolers, kiddie pools, plastic buckets, tubs and storage totes, plastic
                        shelving, milk crates, laundry baskets, etc. (Not accepted: garden hoses, po-
                        lyvinyl chloride [PVC] items, vinyl siding, soft flexible plastics, rubber.)
             ·          Flexible Foam--Foam carpet padding, foam couch cushions, foam-only
                        mattresses. (Not accepted: jute/fiber carpet padding, StyrofoamTM.)
             ·          Reusable Clothing--Clean, wearable clothing, shoes, handbags, backpacks,
                        and coats; clean linens in good condition, such as blankets, sheets, and to-
                        wels. (Not accepted: rags, damaged clothing, rugs, curtains.)




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-7                    Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
             ·          Appliances/Scrap Metal--White goods such as refrigerators, stoves, wash-
                        ing machines, air conditioners, hot water heaters, etc. (Not accepted: small,
                        nonmetal body appliances such as blenders, alarm clocks, etc.)
             ·          Lead Acid Batteries


3.2.2.3 Yard Waste Composting
Ordinance No. 06-03-399 enacted on January 17, 2006, by Frederick County banned
landfill disposal of yard waste from both residential and commercial entities. Residents
and businesses are encouraged to dispose of and/or recycle yard waste at home using
grasscycling and backyard composting practices. Curbside yard waste collection is often
available to single-family residences in Frederick County by their contracted MSW hau-
ler.


There are two county-operated facilities currently in operation in Frederick County where
yard waste may be taken for composting or mulching: Walkersville Heritage Farm Park
(residential use only) and Reichs Ford Road Mulch and Composting Facility (residential
and commercial). Mulch generated as part of the yard waste acceptance and composting
operations are available for free at the Walkersville Farm Park and for a fee at the Reichs
Ford Road Facility. Compost products are available at the Reichs Ford landfill for a fee.


3.2.2.4 Household Hazardous Waste
Household hazardous wastes (HHWs) are not accepted as part of the Frederick County
recycling program. The Division of Utilities and Solid Waste Management (DUSWM)
typically hosts two residential HHW drop-off events per year to collect HHWs that resi-
dents may accumulate.


In 2008 and 2009, the HHW contractor recycled 780 and 1,113 pounds, respectively of
the HHW collected. Recycled materials included batteries, mercury and mercury-
containing items, fluorescent light tubes, and bulbs.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-8                 Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
3.2.2.5 Waste Oils/Antifreeze
Frederick County, in cooperation with the Maryland Environmental Service (MES), as
well as with local municipalities and businesses, offers several motor oil and antifreeze
recycling locations for County residents in addition to the Reichs Ford Road Landfill.
County facilities have a limit of 15 gallons per resident per trip. A number of these loca-
tions are not affiliated with Frederick County but offer these services as a convenience
for the public (see http://www.menv.com/usedoilcollectionlocations.shtml [accessed Jan-
uary 11, 2011] for used motor oil and antifreeze collection centers).


In 2008 and 2009 Frederick County residents recycled 48,214 and 57,806 gallons of oil
and 3,307 and 4,228 gallons of antifreeze, respectively.


3.2.2.6 Tires
The disposal of scrap tires has been banned in Maryland landfills since 1994. Tires are
accepted for recycling and disposal at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill Facility for a fee of
$3.80 per 100 pounds for residential (limit 5 annually) and $8.00 per 100 pounds for
commercial.


DUSWM has a scrap tire disposal policy that includes specific requirements for segrega-
tion, delivery, and disposal of tires. Conformance with this policy ensures compliance
with the DUSWM's Solid Waste Disposal Permit and Secondary Scrap Tire Collection
Facility License (2008-RSC-00280).


In 2008 and 2009 5,097 and 4,445 tires, respectively, were recycled as part of this pro-
gram.


Upon completion of construction of FCCRWTE, scrap tires delivered to landfills or other
permitted scrap tire facilities may be transported to the Facility to process for energy and
metals recovery.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-9           Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
3.2.2.7 Electronics
Electronics are accepted at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill for a fee for every 100 pounds
of electronics. Acceptable electronic items include laptops, computer monitors/mice, cel-
lular telephones, circuit boards, power supplies, computer batteries, computer/electronics
cables, computer chips/cards, printers, central processing unit (CPU) towers, scanners,
televisions and keyboards.


3.2.2.8 Scrap Metals/Recyclable White Goods/Ash Recovery
Scrap metal/recyclable white goods are accepted at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill. Ac-
ceptable scrap metal and recyclable white goods items include metal shelving, cabinets,
bicycles, fencing, lawn mowers, wire coat hangers, grills, swing sets, aluminum lawn
chairs, appliances, etc.


When FCCRWTE becomes operational, Acceptable Material will be brought to the Facil-
ity where they will be processed. Following combustion, bottom ash will be passed
through a screen to separate large metal materials; a magnetic separator will remove addi-
tional ferrous metals. An eddy current separator will remove nonferrous metals. Metals
recovered at FCCRWTE will be recycled contractually.


A percentage of ash recovered from FCCRWTE will be taken to the Reichs Ford Road
Landfill, where it will be used as daily cover in place of soil materials from other sources.
NEA, in cooperation with Frederick County, will investigate other ash recycling options.


3.3        CARROLL COUNTY
3.3.1         MATERIALS SEPARATION STRATEGY
The vision of the Carroll County recycling operation is to encourage a culture of waste
reduction, reuse, and recycling. The County's goal is to recommend and facilitate pro-
grams; educate students, residents, and businesses to minimize the waste stream; and
maximize the recovery of valuable and useful materials.


For calendar year 2009, MDE certified Carroll County's waste diversion rate
(38.05-percent MRA recycling rate and 4-percent source reduction credit) as

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-10        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
42.05 percent. Carroll County Board of Commissioners have established a waste diver-
sion goal (materials removed from the waste stream through recycling, composting, and
other strategies) of 40-percent recycling and a 5-percent source reduction credit by 2015.


3.3.2         EDUCATION/AWARENESS/OUTREACH
Carroll County recognizes the importance of public education, awareness, and outreach
as part of the recycling portion of the Carroll County SWMP. Carroll County has one
employee (recycling manager) devoted full time to the recycling effort and part-time ad-
ministrative support. The annual budget for recycling during the 2010 fiscal year was
$274,300. The recycling manager participates in many educational opportunities and has
an array of volunteers that include the Master Gardeners' Association, school groups, and
environmental activists.


Carroll County maintains a recycling page on its county government Web site
(http://ccgovernment.carr.org/ccg/recycle/default.asp; accessed January 11, 2011). The
Carroll County Office of Recycling has a Facebook page to inform the public of events
and activities of their program.


The Carroll County Board of Commissioners established the Carroll County Environ-
mental Advisory Council (EAC) in 2003 to provide for public input with regard to envi-
ronmental concerns. The focus of the EAC has been to provide information on issues of
environmental concerns (i.e., solid waste management) to the citizens of Carroll County.
The existence of the EAC also serves at an outreach to the community; providing the op-
portunity for citizens to be involved in, question, and comment on the environmental
processes of Carroll County. The EAC made recommendations to the Carroll County
Board of Commissioners on addressing solid waste in Carroll County in October of 2007
(http://ccgovernment.carr.org/ccg/eac/recommend.pdf; accessed January 11, 2011).


Carroll County has produced a video promoting waste prevention, reuse, and recycling,
which is available at County libraries. The video is also widely used by County personnel
during recycling presentations.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-11      Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
Carroll County has provided a mail-out of their Waste Management and Recycling
Handbook, which incorporates the waste management hierarchy and summarizes County
waste management programs.


3.3.3         WASTE PREVENTION/REDUCTION
Carroll County regards waste prevention and reduction as one of its main objectives in its
SWMP. Carroll County anticipates implementing waste reduction throughout the County
using a combination of internal policies and citizen education programs. The County uses
the following techniques and procedures in an effort to meet its waste prevention and re-
duction goals:
             ·          Make a waste reduction education and information package available for
                        public and private use.
             ·          Provide waste reduction information and tips on the Carroll County Web
                        site.
             ·          Include a segment on waste management as part of all presentations of waste
                        management given within Carroll County.
             ·          Provide technical assistance to homeowners and small businesses on the
                        subject of waste reduction.
             ·          Provide technical assistance to municipal governments, schools, and quasi-
                        public institutions assisting them in implementing local waste reduction
                        programs.
             ·          Provide technical assistance to homeowners and residential developers pro-
                        moting and assisting in the implementation of composing and mulching pro-
                        grams.
             ·          Implement in-house purchasing procedures that encourage the purchase of
                        materials that have a reuse value and the purchase of materials made from
                        recycled material.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-12               Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
3.3.4         MATERIALS SEPARATION PROGRAMS
3.3.4.1 Single-Stream Recycling
The single-stream recycling approach has been generally accepted countywide and is
used by nearly all residential and commercial entities of Carroll County. Single-stream
recyclables can be recycled through curbside pickup or brought to one of the two desig-
nated recycling facilities in Carroll County.


The following items are accepted in Carroll County's single-stream recycling program
(Carroll           County             Single-Stream       Recycling   Program   Acceptable     Items;       http://
ccgovernment.carr.org/ccg/recycle/docs/acceptable.pdf; [accessed January 11, 2011]):
             ·          Plastic:
                        o          Wide-mouth containers (empty peanut butter, margarine/butter, yogurt,
                                   cottage cheese, sour cream, mayonnaise, whipped topping, and pre-
                                   scription medicine containers).
                        o          Narrow-neck empty plastic containers (with plastic resin identification
                                   code 1 through 7).
             ·          Metal:
                        o          Empty metal food and beverage containers (aluminum or other met-
                                   als).
                        o          Aluminum foil and aluminum pie pans.
                        o          Empty aerosol cans.
                        o          Glass (empty jars and bottles, all colors accepted).
             ·          Paper:
                        o          Juice and broth boxes.
                        o          Milk and juice containers (gable-top cartons).
                        o          Cardboard and paperboard boxes (cereal boxes without liners).
                        o          Office paper (typing, fax, copy, letterhead, NCR).
                        o          Envelopes.
                        o          Newspapers (including inserts).
                        o          Magazines and catalogs.
                        o          Junk mail.
                        o          Books (paperbacks, textbooks, and hardbacks).

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.       3-13                   Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                        o          Brown paper bags (craft paper).
                        o          Corrugated boxes.
                        o          Telephone books.
                        o          Nonmetallic wrapping paper.
                        o          Computer printouts.


If there is a new material added by the single-stream recycling vendors, Carroll County
will add that material to the list of acceptable recycling materials.


Curbside Recycling
Curbside recycling is available to residents and businesses of Carroll County through
County-licensed and approved haulers. Single-stream recycling is collected from all
County and school facilities. Seven of the eight incorporated municipalities of Carroll
County provide residential curbside recycling through contracted haulers selected
through a specific municipal bid process. Sykesville operates its own MSW collection
and recycling program using municipal employees and equipment.


Business Recycling
Businesses and industries in Carroll County account for approximately 50 percent of the
County's waste stream. Business and industry in Carroll County rely on either private
waste management companies that offer full-service hauling and disposal or commercial
haulers and government disposal facilities. Carroll County does not provide services re-
lated to collection of recyclables from businesses.


3.3.4.2 Additional Recyclable Programs
Additional recyclable materials are accepted at the Northern and Hoods Mill Landfill:
             ·          Car batteries.
             ·          Concrete/asphalt pieces smaller than 6 inches in diameter.
             ·          Fluorescent bulbs and tubes (must be wrapped in paper and placed in a plas-
                        tic bag).
             ·          Latex paint cans (residual paint must be hardened or dry).


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-14                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
             ·          Rigid plastic, grocery and empty clear food bags, DVD/CD cases and disks.
             ·          Appliances: white goods such as scrap metal, washers, dryers, hot water
                        heaters, etc. (Not accepted: freezers, refrigerators, and air conditioners.)


Additional recyclable materials are accepted only at the Northern Landfill:
             ·          Appliances: white goods such as freezers, refrigerators, and air condition-
                        ers.
             ·          Textiles, including clean, dry, and odor free clothes, linens, drapes, hats,
                        paired shoes and socks, etc.
             ·          Aluminum beverage cans.


3.3.4.3 Yard Waste Mulching
In May of 1994, Carroll County banned yard trimmings from both residential and com-
mercial entities from being landfilled. Residents and businesses are encouraged to dis-
pose of and/or recycle yard waste at home using grasscycling and backyard composting
practices. The eight incorporated municipalities of Carroll County provide residences
with drop-off sites and curbside collection through their licensed and contracted haulers
for yard trimmings. Residents and businesses located in unincorporated areas of Carroll
County may contract with a licensed hauler for yard waste pick-up for recycling.


County haulers, municipalities, businesses, and residents may deliver acceptable yard
waste to the Northern Landfill and Hoods Mill Landfill at no charge. The mulch generat-
ed from the yard waste is available to Carroll County residents and businesses at no
charge.


3.3.4.4 Household Hazardous Waste
HHWs are not accepted as part of the Carroll County recycling program. Carroll County
offers HHW events twice yearly. The events include HHW collection, prescription drug
turn-in, and paper shredding.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-15                   Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
In 2009 and 2010, the HHW contractor recycled 608 and 853 pounds, respectively of the
HHW collected. Recycled materials included batteries, mercury and mercury-containing
items, propane cylinders, fluorescent light tubes, and bulbs.


3.3.4.5 Waste Oils/Antifreeze
Carroll County, in cooperation with MES, as well as with local municipalities and busi-
nesses, offers several motor oil and antifreeze recycling locations for County residents.
Used oils and antifreeze for recycling are received at the Northern Landfill, Hoods Mill
Landfill, and town maintenance garages in Hampstead and Sykesville. Used oil only may
be dropped off at Westminster's Public Works Facility, Manchester Garage, and Taney-
town Memorial Park, in addition to the facilities previously listed. There is a drop-off
limit of 5 gallons per week per resident. A number of these locations are not affiliated
with Carroll County but offer these services as a convenience for the public (see
http://www.menv.com/usedoilcollectionlocations.shtml; [accessed January 11, 2011] for
used motor oil and antifreeze collection centers).


In 2008 and 2009 Carroll County residents and commercial businesses recycled 35,039
and 37,738 gallons of oil and 1,777 and 2,627 gallons of antifreeze, respectively.


3.3.4.6 Tires
The disposal of scrap tires has been banned in Maryland landfills since 1994. Tires are
accepted for recycling and disposal at the Northern Landfill and the Hoods Landfill fa-
cilities at a limit of five tires per year per household.


In 2008 and 2009 1,357 and 1,368 tires, respectively were recycled as part of this pro-
gram.


Upon completion of construction of FCCRWTE, in accordance with the contract, scrap
tires generated in Carroll County will be transported to the Facility to process for energy
and metals recovery.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-16      Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
3.3.4.7 Electronics
Residents may drop off electronics for recycling at the Northern Landfill Facility free of
charge. Acceptable items include computer monitors, computer speakers, televisions (no
consoles), CPUs, computer mice, keyboards, cellular telephones, personal digital assis-
tants, printers, power supplies, laptop computers, scanners, computer cables and cords,
and miscellaneous circuit boards, chips, and cards.


3.3.4.8 Scrap Metals/Recyclable White Goods/Ash Recovery
Scrap metals/recyclable white goods are accepted for recycling at the Northern Landfill
and Hoods Mill Landfill facilities.


When FCCRWTE becomes operational, Acceptable Material will be brought to the Facil-
ity where it will be processed. Following combustion, bottom ash will be passed through
a screen to separate large metal materials; a magnetic separator will remove additional
ferrous metals. An eddy current separator will remove nonferrous metals. Metals recov-
ered at FCCRWTE will be recycled contractually.


A percentage of the ash recovered from FCCRWTE will be taken to the Northern Land-
fill where it will be used as daily cover. NEA, in cooperation with Carroll County, will
investigate other ash recycling options.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-17     Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                                          4.0 ALTERNATE DISPOSAL OPTIONS


4.1        FREDERICK COUNTY
Frederick County in 2005 identified the following as alternate solid waste disposal op-
tions:
             ·          Continuation of the current long-haul transfer to disposal facilities located
                        outside of Frederick County.
             ·          Investigation of alternative conversion technologies that show potential in
                        converting the MSW stream to energy products (waste to ethanol, waste ga-
                        sification, and plastics to oil).
             ·          Construction of a County-only WTE facility sized to meet the waste dispos-
                        al needs of just Frederick County.
             ·          Construction of a regional WTE facility sized to meet the waste disposal
                        needs of Frederick County and other public entities in the area.
             ·          Construction of a solid waste composting facility where process residues are
                        long-hauled out of Frederick County for disposal.


To preserve disposal capacity at the Reichs Ford Road Landfill, Frederick County is pur-
suing the construction and operation of FCCRWTE. The landfill will continue in opera-
tion at a reduced tonnage acceptance rate to serve as a buffer to transfer operations and as
an alternative waste management option in the event that conditions develop that prec-
lude solid waste transfer to FCCRWTE or another disposal site. FCCRWTE will neither
accept source separated Acceptable Recyclable Material nor prohibit the further devel-
opment of the County's existing recycling and waste reduction programs.


4.2        CARROLL COUNTY
Carroll County in 2005 identified the following as alternate solid waste disposal options:
             ·          Continuation of the transfer, transportation, and disposal of County waste at
                        disposal facilities located outside Carroll County.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.     4-1                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
             ·          Investigation of alternative conversion technologies that show potential in
                        converting the MSW stream to energy products (waste to ethanol, waste ga-
                        sification, and plastics to oil).
             ·          Construction of a County-only WTE facility sized to meet the waste dispos-
                        al needs of just Carroll County.
             ·          Construction of a regional WTE facility sized to meet the waste disposal
                        needs of Carroll County and other public entities in the area.
             ·          Construction of a solid waste composting facility where process residues are
                        long-hauled out of Carroll County for disposal.
             ·          Co-composting of MSW with sewage sludge at the landfill (this option was
                        explored but rejected for a variety of logistical reasons).


To preserve disposal capacity at the Northern Landfill, Carroll County is pursuing the
construction and operation of FCCRWTE. The landfill will continue in operation at a re-
duced tonnage acceptance rate to serve as a buffer to transfer operations and as an alter-
native waste management option in the event that conditions develop that preclude solid
waste transfer to FCCRWTE or another disposal site. FCCRWTE will neither accept
source separated Acceptable Recyclable Material nor prohibit the further development of
the County's existing recycling and waste reduction programs.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.     4-2                  Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711
                                                          5.0 SUMMARY


Both Frederick and Carroll Counties have developed and updated SWMPs that provide
the framework for implementation of solid waste management decisions in their respec-
tive counties. The SWMPs incorporate source reduction, reuse, and recycling programs
that demonstrate achievement of and exceed the state of Maryland's waste diversion
goals. Both Counties have comprehensive and successful material separation and recy-
cling programs that have been in place for a number of years. Frederick County was one
of three communities nationwide selected in 2010 by CVP, a program of Keep America
Beautiful, Inc., to develop an educational recycling campaign called "Learn More, Re-
cycle Better." FCCRWTE will complement and enhance these county programs.


As a result of long-range planning investigations with NEA, both Counties entered into
an MOU by and among Frederick County, Carroll County, and NEA for the development
of a regional WTE facility (July 2009). This MOU described the site location in Frede-
rick County; the ownership, design, and capacity of the facility; as well as the responsi-
bilities of NEA, the Counties, and the vendor.


Through the reduction, reuse, and recycling strategies described herein, a considerable
amount of materials will be separated, reused, and recovered for recycling purposes prior
to entering the MSW stream. Only nonrecycled solid waste will be delivered and
processed at FCCRWTE, where it will be used to generate clean, renewable electricity
for potential use at the government facilities of Frederick and Carroll Counties.
FCCRWTE will be an integral part of the Counties' recycling programs, as some ferrous
and nonferrous metals that are not currently recycled will be recovered from the ash as
part of the FCCRWTE operations and reused for various purposes.


NEA believes the reduction, reuse, and recycling strategies described in this document
will ensure the Counties will continue to meet and exceed the state of Maryland's waste
diversion goal of 20 percent, the voluntary statewide waste diversion goal of 40 percent,
and assist the Counties in achieving their recycling and diversion goals.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.       5-1       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP.DOCX--020711

19                For introduction, the Northeast Maryland

20   Waste Disposal Authority has developed in Frederick and

21   Carroll Counties a renewable waste-to-energy facility to

22




                                                        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                    8



 1   serve the long-term solid waste disposal needs of

 2   Frederick and Carroll counties.

 3                This Preliminary Draft Material Separation

 4   Plan is prepared to fulfill the requirements of the

 5   Environmental Protection Agency New Source Performance

 6   Standard, and you can see the citation there for the

 7   facility.

 8                What the Preliminary Draft MSP does is

 9   identifies the goals and approaches for separating

10   certain components of the material solid waste stream in

11   the two counties in order to make the separated

12   materials available for recycling.

13                Now, the facility is located in Frederick

14   County's McKenney Industrial Park, adjacent to the

15   County's Ballenger-McKenney sewage treatment plant.

16   It's a nominal 1500-ton-a-day municipal solid waste

17   facility.   It will treat thermally up to 50,000 tons of

18   sewage sludge.   It will accept and thermally treat scrap

19   tires, will generate up to 55 megawatts of electricity,

20   with the export of 45 megawatts or more for sale.     It

21   will recover approximately 15,000 tons of ferrous and

22




                                                       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                    9



 1   nonferrous metals not otherwise recovered as part of the

 2   County's recycling program.

 3                The size of the service area is basically,

 4   the primary service area is all residential, business,

 5   industrial, business institutions and commercial waste

 6   generators of Frederick and Carroll Counties.

 7                Now, additional waste from outside the

 8   primary service area may be accepted, subject to the

 9   County's approval, to enable the facility to generate

10   the maximum amount of renewable energy.

11                Each County is required under Maryland law

12   to have a Solid Waste Management Plan.    Frederick County

13   has a plan that was updated in 2005, and currently that

14   plan is under revision.

15                Carroll County has a ten-year solid waste

16   management plan that was updated in 2006 and reviewed in

17   2007.

19   waste tonnage projections for Carroll and Frederick

 8               JUDGE SHARER:    Karen Tone?   Am I correct?

10               MS. TONE:    Karen Tone.   And I am a common

11   sense resident from Brunswick, Maryland.

12               If the purpose the purpose of this plan, as                   TOME-1
13   stated on page 1-1 is to identify the goals and

14   approaches for separating certain components of the

15   municipal waste stream in both Frederick and Carroll

16   Counties in order to make the separated materials

17   available for recycling, then why aren't we looking at

18   maximizing that amount of material in the first place?

19               In an email from County Attorney John                         TOME-2
20   Mathias -- in an email from the County Attorney, John

21   Mathias stated, "The BOCC may impose conditions on a

22




                                                        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                    23




 1   hauler's use of a County facility such as a County                        TOME-2 (cont.)
 2   sanitary landfill or transfer station, but these

 3   conditions would not apply if the hauler chose not to

 4   use the County facility."

 5              Continuing, he stated, "The BOCC is provided

 6   authority in State law to prescribe rules for the use of

 7   County solid waste facilities.   These rules provide that

 8   only haulers providing only certain services, such as

 9   curbside recycling and pickup to its customers would be

10   licensed to use the County facilities.   Those rules

11   would only apply to those haulers who use the County

12   facilities," end quote.

13              A friend of mine has referred to this as "my

14   landfill, my rules."   Since tiered pricing programs,

15   which treat trash and recycling disposal in the same way

16   that utilities do -- in other words, you pay only for

17   what you throw out in the trash, the recycling charge is

18   also included in that price.   Since these programs have

19   been shown to drastically reduce the amount of waste

20   that has to be disposed of in a community, why wouldn't

21   the authority first recommend this strategy?   Granted,

22




                                                        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                  24




 1   it would involve sitting down with the haulers in our                   TOME-2 (cont.)
 2   county and working out a renewable program.   It would

 3   also involve having the County step back a bit from what

 4   they view as a costly recycling program and in turn give

 5   the opportunity to our local private businesses for

 6   hauling.

 7              Since the County has been given the                          TOME-3
 8   authority to develop the best type of recycling and

10   other options on page 4-1 as an alternate solid waste

11   disposal option?

12              On page 1-3 of the plan, it states, "The                     TOME-4
13   recognized benefits of reducing the MSW stream through

14   recycling include a reduction in transportation costs, a

15   reduction in the amount of disposal fees to the citizens

16   due to reduced volumes, and an increase in the longevity

17   of the life of the local landfill.   Most importantly, by

18   actively supporting recycling efforts, the Counties and

20   Environmental Advisory Council in October of 2007.

22




                                                         Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                  32




 1   ccgovernment.carr.org/cpg/eac/recommend.pdm.   I want to                ANDREWS-1 (cont.)

 2   cover a few of those recommendations for this meeting.

 3              First, the council recommended that Carroll                  ANDREWS-2
 4   County change the paradigm from solid waste management

 5   to resource management.   That would involve elevating

 6   recycling as the driving element of resource management,

 7   one, by creating and verifying recycling reporting

 8   policies, and two, by managing its own system in order

 9   to direct recycled goods to specific recovery centers,

10   and three, by increasing funding to recycling operations

11   for expanded public education efforts.

12              The board also recommended that the Board of

13   County Commissioners view public education and behavior

14   modification as essential in the transition to the new

15   paradigm of resource management.   This will require

16   staff and media attention as needed.

17              Again, the board -- or the council also

18   recommended not supporting the plan for the construction

19   of this waste-to-energy facility, but, rather, that the

20   County's efforts direct its resource management strategy

21   as outlined above, or as I have described, for a period

22




                                                      Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                   33




 1   of five years.                                                           ANDREWS-2 (cont.)
 2              The council also recommended that the Board

 3   of Commissioners implement and support pay-as-you-throw

 4   trash collection programs and the commission, the EAC,

 5   to work in concert with the Department of Public Works

 6   to create a community process to begin or to design

 7   essential elements of that program.

 8              The council also recommended that the Board

 9   of Commissioners of Carroll County undertake a

10   feasibility study of creating a county-wide composting

11   facility where organic material could be turned back

12   into useful products for local farmers and reduce

13   greenhouse gases.

14              In closing, I just wanted to make everyone

15   aware of those recommendations and that they be

16   referenced in this plan.

 1               Thank you.

 2               (Applause.)

 3               JUDGE SHARER:   Sally Sorbello.

 4               MS. SORBELLO:   Good evening.   My name is

 5   Sally Sorbello.   I live in Frederick, Maryland.

 6               My concerns regarding the Authority's Draft                   SORBELLO-1
 7   Materials Separation Plan include, but are not limited

 8   to the following:   Trends documented in reports from the

 9   Covanta incinerator in Montgomery County, Maryland, have

10   shown that, A, increased recycling decreases the

11   quantity of materials available for incineration, and B,

12   source reduction and recycling of materials such as

13   paper and plastic diminishes the energy value of

14   incineration, which reduces the electrical generating

15   capability of the facility.

16               In other words, as other speakers have said,

17   recycling and incineration are not compatible.     They

18   directly compete with each other, both materially and

19   financially.   I don't believe our county can afford a

20   comprehensive recycling program if we are spending tens

21   of millions of dollars a year to subsidize the

22




                                                        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                     40




 1   incinerator operation and we cannot produce enough                         SORBELLO-1 (cont.)
 2   electricity for incineration if we are recycling

 3   effectively.

 4                Also, I'm concerned that there is no                          SORBELLO-2
 5   separation of material at the incinerator.   Any milk jug

 6   or aluminum cans or paper or plastic that arrives at the

 7   plant will be burned.   Also, any recovered ferrous metal

 8   is retrieved by use of magnets to pull them out of the

 9   ash after burning.   I believe that these materials can

10   be recovered without the incinerator.

11                I also find it troubling on the authority                     SORBELLO-3
12   website in the About Us section, there is an image of

13   recyclable materials, cans, bottles, et cetera, which

14   are twirled around, and then they become a light bulb.

15   I think this is really implying that it's preferable to

16   burn these materials for a small amount of energy

17   recovery, rather than recycle them in order to save

18   energy.   Recycling saves three to five times the amount

19   of energy that incinerators produce when you look at the

20   life cycle of these materials.

21                Also, on page 3-8 of the Draft Material                       SORBELLO-4
22




                                                         Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                     41




 1   Separation Plan, it states that tires will be brought to                   SORBELLO-4 (cont.)
 2   the facility for burning, rather than being recycled.

 3              The environmental community discourages

 4   under any circumstances the use of tires as fuel.

 5   Burning tires is extremely polluting.    In tests all

 6   around the country there have been increases in air

 7   pollution as a direct result of tire incineration.

 8   There have been increases in mercury, lead, zinc,

 9   sulphur dioxide, carbon monoxide, arsenic and benzine.

10   These compounds are carcinogenic.    Mercury from tire

11   burning is linked to brain, lung, kidney damage,

12   reproductive problems and death.    Very young children

13   and the unborn are especially vulnerable to these

14   effects.

15              Tires can be utilized instead for an almost

16   unlimited range of creative uses, including auto parts,

17   playground equipment, sound barriers, railroad ties and

18   tennis courts.   Burning tires for limited energy

19   production which results in ash and air pollution is the

20   lowest use of scrap tires.

21              Also, I want to just reiterate, other people                    SORBELLO-5
22




                                                         Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                    42




 1   have said that due to the fact that the proposed                          SORBELLO-5 (cont.)
 2   incinerator requires approximately 1500 tons per day of

 3   material, which is almost twice what Frederick and

 4   Carroll Counties are currently producing, we will have

 5   to import from other counties, and probably other states

 6   as well.   Trash truck traffic will cause pollution,

 7   clogging our roads and our lungs for decades to come.

 8                This issue is not over.    I encourage all

 9   concerned Frederick residents to vote for candidates for

10   Frederick BOCC that oppose this plan.

11                Thank you very much.

 3               In April, the local paper reported that                        DUNSMORE-2
 4   haulers are dumping at illegal sites in order to avoid

 5   tipping fees for leaving it at the incinerator.

 6   According to The Patriot-News, a County employee has

 7   been hired and paid $15.40 per hour to follow the trucks

 8   to make sure that they make it to the incinerator.

 9               If this isn't working very well for

10   Harrisburg, I don't think it's going to work very well

11   for us.

12               Thank you.

13               (Applause.)

14               JUDGE SHARER:    Thank you.    Dennis Jung?

15               MR. JUNG:    Good evening.    My name is Dennis

16   Jung.   That's J-U-N-G, like Freud.

17               The report, the Frederick County MSP report,                   JUNG-1
18   says that it will burn acceptable materials, including

19   tires, sludge and perhaps hospital waste.      It was not

20   very detailed on that.    Hospital waste and these other

21   sources are all very rich sources of dioxins.

22




                                                         Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                  47



 1                I used to live in Columbus, Ohio, and this

 2   is like, as Yogi Berra would say, deja vu all over

 3   again.   In 1983, they opened up a WTE plant that was

 4   also promoted as being clean-burning and environmentally

 5   safe at the time, at the cost of only a hundred million

 6   dollars.   However, after the plant opened and started

 7   operation, residents of the downwind community, Grove

 8   City, Ohio, became concerned and found out that the

 9   dioxin levels by their schools and in their community

10   was many times greater than background.   Needless to

11   say, their property values didn't increase.

12                Columbus spent millions of dollars trying to

13   improve the separation process, trying to reduce the

14   emissions, dioxins, and also to improve the operation.

15   It didn't work.   One contract alone was $7 million.

16                In 1994, the dioxin levels represented about

17   two to three additional cancer deaths per every million

18   people exposed, according to the Ohio EPA.

19                In 1994, the plant was shuttered, and in

20   2005, the three smokestacks of the Central Ohio WTE were

21   imploded, ending a several-hundred-million-dollar

22




                                                      Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                    48



 1   investment in the WTE.   The smokestack materials were at

 2   that point recycled.

 3               My concern and question is, how will the                      JUNG-2
 4   Frederick County WTE be monitored for emissions of

 5   dioxins and other toxins into the surrounding

 6   environment.   Not at the smokestack level, but outside.

 7   The dioxins can go through the process untouched; they

 8   can generate dioxins and also in the smokestack as they

 9   are going out they can be generated.

10               They're fat-soluble, so they're readily

11   absorbed and slowly eliminated from the body, so

12   long-term exposure is a problem.

13               As in the old computer adage Bill Gates

14   might use, garbage in, garbage out, and here the

15   question is, dioxin precursors in, how much is coming

16   out.

17               And as the plant is built, I believe that                     JUNG-3
18   air sampling should be performed by an independent

19   agency at designated sites, including schools in the

20   area around the plant before the plant becomes

21   operational to establish a baseline mode of dioxin and

22




                                                        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                 49




 1   other toxins that will be released by the process, and                 JUNG-3 (cont.)
 2   then on a routine basis at times not known to the

 3   operators so they can manipulate the plant, samples

 4   should be taken to monitor revisions, and these reports

 5   should be made part of the public record to assure

 6   citizens of Frederick County that they're not being

 7   exposed to hazardous levels of toxins from the plant.

 8              Thank you.

 9              (Applause.)

10              JUDGE SHARER:    Greg Brown.

11              MR. BROWN:    Thank you.

12              My name is Greg Brown, and I have lived and

13   worked in Frederick County for over 25 years, and I'm                  BROWN-1
14   here to support the project, and I applaud Frederick

15   County and Carroll County for bringing the project

16   forward.

17              Listening to a lot of the other comments                    BROWN-2
18   going on, I feel that Frederick and Carroll County have

19   exhaustively studied the project for over five years and

20   concluded that this project is both environmentally

21   sound and cost-effective.

                                                                     50




 1                 The project will provide significant local                   BROWN-3
 2   spending and jobs in Frederick, while increasing

 3   recycling and reducing our waste footprint by as much as

 4   90 percent.

 5                 I'm primarily concerned about the                            BROWN-4
 6   environment and future landfill problems.      The company I

 7   work for has worked around our local landfill, and I

 8   have the realization of what happens when you actually

 9   just bury all the things that we're talking about, and

10   my feeling is that by burying, it doesn't solve the

11   problem.

12                 Working in the construction industry, I see

13   the extreme amount of waste that we end up generating

14   that goes into our landfills, and understanding the

15   waste-to-energy possibility, can see that this is a much

16   better option than burying things in the landfill, and

17   by burying things, hope they just go away forever.        That

18   actually is not a fact.

19                 Thank you.

20                 (Applause.)

21                 JUDGE SHARER:   Thank you.   Brigit Forton?

22




                                                         Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                     51



 1                MS. FORTON:   I give my name and my town, is

 2   that all, Mr. Speaker?

 3                JUDGE SHARER:   Yes, ma'am.

 4                MS. FORTON:   Brigit Forton, Myersville.

 5                This plan calls for burning recyclable                        FORTIN-1
 6   material at a time when all efforts should be directed

 7   toward recycling as much as possible.      Plans to increase

 8   recycling while sustaining a furnace that requires such

 9   an input cannot occur without Frederick becoming a local

10   dumping ground for trash from every surrounding suburban

11   area, as well as the cities of Baltimore, Washington and

12   beyond.   Calling it acceptable material does not change

13   the fact that it should be recycled, rather than burned.

14   Burning recyclables is just plain dumb and should not be

15   part of this plan.

19   designed to put the local government into the trash

20   business, at the opposition and extreme displeasure of

21   the taxpaying citizens who must breathe this air.

                                                                    52




 1              The fact that this plan would burn                             FORTIN-3
 2   recyclable generic materials to me is a clear indication

 4   geared to make a business opportunity out of what is

 5   supposed to be a public service.

 6              The Materials Recovery Plan is yet another

 7   attempt to greenwash this project and perhaps an attempt

 8   to clean up its act by making it sound as though

 9   recyclables will be sorted at the facility.     However,

10   the plan does not call for that at all, and instead is

11   more like a laundry list of all the good recyclable

12   materials that it sees fit to burn.

13              I, for one, must protest and ask that the

14   plan be rewritten so as to make every attempt to presort

15   recyclables and send them to a recycling facility.

18   believe you wish to be heard?

20   S-C-H-M-I-D-T.

21              Currently, our solid waste contains a                          SCHMIDT-1
22




                                                        Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                   53




 1   significant proportion of liquid.   Could you tell us                    SCHMIDT-1 (cont.)
 2   what this proportion is?   How is this liquid going to be

 4              Thank you.

 5              JUDGE SHARER:    There is a gentleman in the

 6   back who came down a moment ago, and I'm having

 7   difficulty reading your name, but don't take it

 8   personally, because I can barely read my own most of the

 9   time.

10              MR. D'ALMALE:    Everybody has that problem.

11              My name is Mike D'Almale; I'm from

12   Johnsville, Maryland, which is in Frederick County.

13              The biggest fault I see in the planning                       ELMALEH-1
14   process is a common fault in long-term planning that I

15   have been involved with, and that is what I would call

16   the fallacy of fixed assumptions.

17              We try to plan ahead, look thirty years,

18   twenty years in advance, and we of course are using

19   assumptions about how things are done today.   That is a

20   very dangerous planning position to be in.

21              Specifically, when you look at the kind of                    ELMALEH-2
22




                                                       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                   54




 1   waste stream that we have today versus what we probably                  ELMALEH-2 (cont.)
 2   will have thirty years in the future, I think we are

 3   looking at a dramatically different composition of that

 4   stream.   I think it's completely unrealistic to assume

 5   that the manufacturing process that now gives you the

 6   percentage breakdowns of recyclable, reusable,

 7   compostable and nonrecyclable, noncompostable,

 8   nonreusable percentages are going to stay the same over

 9   a thirty-year period.   Over a thirty-year period.     It's

10   simply unrealistic.

11                The manufacturing processes that are going

12   on today, the kind of research and development, the kind

13   of work in nanotechnology, biofuels and all kinds of

14   material engineering, are such that they are going to

15   move in the direction of greater recyclability, greater

16   reusability and less of the kind of composition, the

17   kind of waste composition that this plant basically says

18   it's going to be twenty, thirty years from now.    It is

19   absolutely laughable.

20                This is not good science.   This is not

21   realistic projection.   You have to take into account

22




                                                       Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMS.DOCX--012711
                                                                  55




 1   what is going on in research and development, you have                  ELMALEH-2 (cont.)
 2   to look at long-term trends, not as they are today, but

 3   what they're likely to be in the future.

 4              Now, admittedly you cannot always determine

 5   what the future is going to look like, but in a highly

 6   dynamic environment where we're looking at significant

 7   changes in technology, it is foolish to commit yourself

 8   to a 19th-century technology.

 9              (Applause.)

10              And I have to say, with all due respect to

11   the staff and all the people who support this, you are

12   using static assumptions.   And it would be laughable if

13   it weren't so tragic.

14              Thank you.
