                      FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY
                  RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

                         MATERIALS SEPARATION PLAN
                          COMMENTS AND RESPONSES
                  Public Meeting Transcript, August 30, 2010


The spelling of some of the commenters names have been corrected based on the sign-in
sheets collected at the public meeting.


DYSON-1: I have reviewed the Preliminary Draft Material Separation Plan for Frede-
          rick and Carroll County waste energy facility, and I agree with the plan
          set forth and with the ultimate destination of specific waste to the waste-
          to-energy facility in Frederick County.
Response:
Comments in support of the project noted for the record.


DYSON-2: Source separation promotes the removal of all designated recyclable mate-
          rials from the waste stream, and therefore helps to achieve high solid
          waste reduction rates.

              There is a Maryland Executive Order which states that each county will
              attain a 20 percent recycling goal. Frederick County's 2007 recycling rate
              was estimated to be at 41.32 percent, while Carroll County's 2007 recy-
              cling rate was estimated to be at 28.33.

              Although both counties are currently exceeding the 20 percent target, de-
              velopment of a formalized source separation program with additional
              reusable material separated before and after the waste energy
              process.[sic] This will increase those percentages, thereby reducing the
              counties' expenses for transportation of out-of-state solid waste, as well
              as reducing the associated environmental impact, greenhouse gas, for ex-
              ample.
Response:
Frederick and Carroll Counties have established a number of formal material separation
programs that are identified in Sections 3.2 (Frederick County) and 3.3 (Carroll County)
of the Material Separation Plan (MSP). The Energy Recovery Agreements (individually
signed by each County in July 2009 with the Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Au-



                                           1                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
thority [NEA]) do not restrict any County recycling programs or require the delivery of
solid waste that either County elects to include in a future recycling program.


DYSON-3: My experience has been with the studies done on background biological
         indicators, as the chemical uptake in vegetables, skin tissue of fish, cow's
         milk, as well as air monitoring of particulates and chemical deposition
         before the start of an incinerator project and one to two years after the
         start of a project.

              The results that I had access to showed that the biological indicators
              showed no increase or change to the chemical uptake from the baseline.
              The air monitoring showed that there was an increase in particulate de-
              position; however, it was still well below the federal regulatory limits.
              Chemical deposition did change; however, not significantly, and again,
              well below the federal regulatory limits.
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


DYSON-4: I encourage the Frederick and Carroll County commissions to move for-
          ward with the Material Separation Plan and with the waste energy facili-
          ty.
Response:
Comments in support of the project noted for the record.


IACCARINO-1: I have reviewed the draft of the Material Separation Plan for the
              Frederick and Carroll County renewable waste and energy facility.
              I agree with the goals and objectives of the draft plan for separat-
              ing components of the municipal solid waste stream and to make
              these separated components available for recycling before the post-
              recycling materials are processed by the WTE facility.

                    The reduction, reuse and recycling strategies described in the draft
                    plan indicate that a considerable amount of materials will be sepa-
                    rated, reused and recovered for recycling purposes.
Response:
Comments in support of the project noted for the record.


IACCARINO-2: As an environmental professional with over thirty years of experience
              and a long-time resident of Frederick County, I believe the WTE fa-

                                             2                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
                   cility represents the right answer to Frederick County's municipal
                   solid waste problems.

                   The WTE facility is a prudent process for the safe disposal of post-
                   recycled municipal solid waste and will result in the generation of
                   clean, renewable energy.
Response:
Comments in support of the project noted for the record.


IACCARINO-3: From an environmental standpoint, the WTE facility will be equipped
              with state-of-the-art air pollution control technology and meet all
              federal and State emission limits and ambient air quality standards.
Response:
Comment noted for the record. The proposed Frederick/Carroll County Renewable
Waste-to-Energy Facility (FCCRWTE or Facility) will be required to have advanced air
emission controls. FCCRWTE will meet all applicable emission limits, and the impacts
of the Facility's emissions will meet all federal and state emission limits and ambient air
quality standards. An air quality permit application describing these controls, as well as
predicted impacts on air quality, is being prepared and is expected to be submitted to the
Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) early in 2011. The permit application
will be publically noticed and available for review and comment.


IACCARINO-4: The WTE project will also result in reduced generation of green-
              house gas emissions which would otherwise be generated from the
              equivalent generation of electricity up to 55 megawatts, the green-
              house gas emissions associated with transportation of municipal
              solid waste to other out-of-state landfills, and the subsequent gen-
              eration of methane, a greenhouse gas associated with the landfil-
              ling of municipal solid waste.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Comment noted for the record.


RAK-1: I have not reviewed the entire document, but I notice that there was an omis-
        sion. Section 2.1 says, "Additional waste from outside of the primary service
        area will be accepted to enable the Frederick/Carroll County renewable
        waste energy facility to operate at its designed capacity."

                                            3                 Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
        I think that is that it must be accepted in order to allow it to operate as its de-
        sign capacity, and the draft for material separation is missing the informa-
        tion for the other trash that will be imported.
Response:
The purpose of this preliminary Draft MSP is to identify the goals and approaches for
separating certain components of the municipal solid waste stream in the Frederick and
Carroll Counties' service areas to make the separated materials available for recycling.
The nonrecycled Acceptable Material will be processed at NEA's FCCRWTE.


Additional solid waste will be required for FCCRWTE to operate at its design capacity.
The Frederick and Carroll Counties' Energy Recovery Agreements (individually signed
in July 2009 with NEA) require that NEA be provided written direction by both Counties
prior to receiving Acceptable Waste from outside the Counties' service area. The Final
Draft MSP will be modified to incorporate this information.


TWIGG-1: In 2.1, in the service areas, it mentions that additional waste from outside
          of the primary service area will be accepted to enable the facility to oper-
          ate at its design capacity. And if you look at figure 2.1 in the chart there,
          it shows by 2025, the projected amount of waste will be approximately
          390,000 tons, and that's before you separate out the recoverable mate-
          rials.

              I did a little bit of math on that, and it still doesn't come to 1,500 tons a
              day, so it's obvious that they must take solid waste from other areas to
              enable the plant to operate at peak capacity in order to achieve that 55
              megawatts that the plant will generate.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Figure 2-1 was revised for the Final Draft with updated Carroll County
solid waste and recycling projections. The revised Figure 2-1 now shows the 2025 pro-
jected amount of processible solid waste from Frederick and Carroll Counties is approx-
imately 317,900 tons. In addition, sewage sludge and tires will be processed at
FCCRWTE. Processible solid waste is defined as waste that was not recycled and is
available to process at FCCRWTE. In this same revised figure, in 2025, approximately



                                            4                 Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
302,800 tons of Frederick and Carroll County Maryland Recycling Act (MRA) tons are
expected to be recycled.


Please refer to the response to RAK-1.


TWIGG-2: I found the point to be vague; there was not much detail on transporting
          this waste from the transport area to the facility at the McKenney
          [McKinney] site. I'm very concerned about that and the traffic that that
          will generate in that area. There is really a very large lack of detail in this
          draft.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. The purpose of this Preliminary Draft MSP is to identify the goals and
approaches for separating certain components of the municipal solid waste stream in the
Frederick and Carroll Counties' service areas to make the separated materials available
for recycling. A traffic study will be prepared to evaluate the impact of FCCRWTE as
part of the Frederick County development review process.


TWIGG-3: I would also like to see the studies the County performed in alternative me-
          thods. I don't think we have seen those, and I would like to have those
          somewhere public.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. The Frederick County Board of County Commissioners had a number of
studies completed to consider alternatives. These studies can be found on the respective
County's      Web          site   under      Frederick      County            Waste-to-Energy
(http://www.frederickcountymd.
gov/index.aspx?nid=4199 [accessed January 11, 2011]) and Carroll County Recycling
and   Solid   Waste    Future     Disposal   Methods     (http://ccgovernment.carr.org/ccg
/pubworks/sw-future/default.asp [accessed January 11, 2011]).


TWIGG-4: And some of the speakers before me mentioned about the materials being
          discharged to the air, and all plants that burn create dioxins, and science



                                             5                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
              just doesn't know yet what the effects of those dioxins are on people; they
              can only guess.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. A siting analysis will be prepared as part of the MDE air permit applica-
tion that will analyze the impact of the FCCRWTE on ambient air quality, visibility,
soils, and vegetation. The siting analysis will consider air pollution control alternatives
that minimize, on a site-specific basis and to the maximum extent practicable, potential
risks to the public health or the environment.


TWIGG-5: I am strongly opposed to this plant, and I think this draft report is poorly
          written and lacking in detail.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Comment opposing the project noted for the record. The purpose of this
Preliminary Draft MSP is to identify the goals and approaches for separating certain
components of the municipal solid waste stream in the Frederick and Carroll Counties'
service areas to make the separated materials available for recycling. The level of detail
provided in the Preliminary Draft MSP satisfies or exceeds the regulatory requirements.


TOME-1: If the purpose of this plan, as stated on page 1-1 is to identify the goals and
          approaches for separating certain components of the municipal waste
          stream in both Frederick and Carroll Counties in order to make the sepa-
          rated materials available for recycling, then why aren't we looking at max-
          imizing that amount of material in the first place?
Response:
Frederick and Carroll Counties have established a number of formal material separation
programs that are identified in Sections 3.2 (Frederick County) and 3.3 (Carroll County)
of the Preliminary Draft MSP. Additional information can be found on each county's
Web site.


The latest data provided by MDE's County's Recyclables by Commodity in Tons for Ca-
lendar Year 2009 report shows Frederick County had a waste diversion rate of



                                             6                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
46.63 percent while Carroll County had a waste diversion rate of 42.05 percent1. Calen-
dar Year 2008 data provided by the Counties showed Frederick County with a waste di-
version rate of 44.4 percent, while Carroll County had a waste diversion rate of
37.9 percent. MDE defines the waste diversion rate as the sum of the recycling rate and
the source reduction credit (based on voluntary reporting of source reduction activities).
Both counties exceed the MRA requirement of 20 percent.


TOME-2: In an email from County Attorney John Mathias -- in an email from the
        County Attorney, John Mathias stated, "The BOCC may impose conditions
        on a hauler's use of a County facility such as a County sanitary landfill or
        transfer station, but these conditions would not apply if the hauler chose
        not to use the County facility."

                Continuing, he stated, "The BOCC is provided authority in State law to
                prescribe rules for the use of County solid waste facilities. These rules pro-
                vide that only haulers providing only certain services, such as curbside re-
                cycling and pickup to its customers would be licensed to use the County fa-
                cilities. Those rules would only apply to those haulers who use the County
                facilities," end quote.

                A friend of mine has referred to this as "my landfill, my rules." Since
                tiered pricing programs, which treat trash and recycling disposal in the
                same way that utilities do -- in other words, you pay only for what you
                throw out in the trash, the recycling charge is also included in that price.
                Since these programs have been shown to drastically reduce the amount of
                waste that has to be disposed of in a community, why wouldn't the authori-
                ty first recommend this strategy? Granted, it would involve sitting down
                with the haulers in our county and working out a renewable program. It
                would also involve having the County step back a bit from what they view
                as a costly recycling program and in turn give the opportunity to our local
                private businesses for hauling.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Legislative authority for a pilot Pay As You Throw (PAYT) program did
not exist until October 1, 2010. The 2010 Board of County Commissioners stated that the
construction and implementation of a PAYT pilot be a decision made by the next elected
Board. The new Board was sworn in on December 1, 2010.


1
    http://www.mde.state.md.us/programs/Land/SolidWaste/PermittedFacilities/Documents/recyclables%20by
            %20commodity%20in%20tons%202009.pdf (accessed January 28, 2011).

                                                   7                  Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
TOME-3: Since the County has been given the authority to develop the best type of
          recycling and disposal program, why was this never identified with the
          other options on page 4-1 as an alternate solid waste disposal option?
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Please refer to the response to TOME-2.


TOME-4: On page 1-3 of the plan, it states, "The recognized benefits of reducing the
        MSW stream through recycling include a reduction in transportation costs,
        a reduction in the amount of disposal fees to the citizens due to reduced vo-
        lumes, and an increase in the longevity of the life of the local landfill. Most
        importantly, by actively supporting recycling efforts, the Counties and the
        authority, NEA, are preserving valuable resources."

            If this is truly what the Authority is all about, then why doesn't the service
            contract state that the facility will not burn valuable recyclable material?
            Or could it be that this plan is just what many people are referring to as
            window dressing.
Response:
Solid waste that is not recycled will be combusted at FCCRWTE. The Frederick and
Carroll Counties' Energy Recovery Agreements (individually signed in July 2009 with
NEA) state under Recitals 3, "The County has determined to provide for the conversion
into energy of solid waste that is not recycled using capacity at a regional resource re-
covery facility (the "Facility"). Nothing in this Agreement restricts any County recycling
programs or requires the delivery by the County to the Facility of solid waste that the
County elects to include in a recycling program" (emphasis added). The Final Draft MSP
will be modified to include this information.


TOME-5: Another question I had, I wanted to make one comment, that 20 percent of
          waste recyclables is pitiful, in my opinion. That's just way too low. I know
          that's not an argument with the plan. It's just my opinion.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-1.

Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-4,

             print a copy and then circulate it that way.

             has access to a computer and a printer and should be concerned about this
             big monstrosity that's coming to our county, we should all have access to
             this.
Response:
A printable electronic copy of the public notice and the Preliminary Draft MSP was add-
ed to NEA's Web site immediately after the public meeting. A hard copy of the notice
and the report were available at eight Frederick County libraries and six Carroll County
libraries prior to the July 30, 2010, public notice.


CUBIT-2: I would also like to follow up on Mr. Twigg's comment about the ineffec-
          tuality of the document itself. There is a lot of words on it. I didn't see an-
          ything of substance. I saw the numbers. We have things to disagree with.
          We would like to see the numbers behind the assumptions made in a lot of
          parts of this document.
Response:
Waste generation projections using County-approved numbers for Frederick and Carroll
Counties were obtained from NEA's planning model. Typically, as the population in-
creases, so does the amount of waste generated, even if the per capita waste generation
rate plateaus and does not increase.



                                               9             Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
CUBIT-3: I think the whole process has been like this, in that it gives the community
          as little as possible and let's just sneak this project by as fast as we can.
Response:
Frederick County Board of County Commissioners and Carroll County Board of Com-
missioners held numerous meetings and public hearings over the last 5 years in evaluat-
ing the solid waste management options. Detailed reports and information can be found
the Counties' government Web sites and the NEA Web site.


BURRUSS-1: I object to the term "thermally processed." I think the correct word is
            "burned." That's what most people will understand.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. FCCRWTE will combust solid waste, which is the process of burning a
fuel to produce thermal energy. The use of the term "thermally processed" describes the
controlled nature of the combustion process in the combustors. "Burned" would also be
an acceptable term for the combustion process.


BURRUSS-2: The table, figure 2-1 that we saw on the screen earlier, does indicate, as
            a previous speaker mentioned, that in the year 2025 it is projected that
            there will be from Frederick County 575 tons per day of fuel for the
            plant and 411 tons per day from Carroll County, for a total of 986
            tons. This leaves a deficit, according to your figures, of 514 tons per
            day in the 1500 tons per day capacity of the facility. So it's built into
            the plan as presented here that there clearly has to transport from oth-
            er jurisdictions in order to operate the plant at anywhere near its peak
            efficiency.
Response:
Figure 2-1 was revised for the Final Draft with updated Carroll County waste and recy-
cling projections. The revised Figure 2-1 shows in the year 2025 approximately 212,000
and 105,680 tons of processible solid waste from Frederick and Carroll Counties, respec-
tively, will be available to FCCRWTE. The total processible solid waste is approximately
72 percent of Annual Throughput Guarantee (first year) required of the Service Contract.
Additional solid waste will be required to meet the design capacity of FCCRWTE.


Please refer to the response to RAK-1 for additional information.

                                           10                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
BURRUSS-3: On page 3.1, at the very bottom, continuing onto page 3.2, it states,
           "The Frederick County Commissioners have established a waste divi-
           sion [diversion] goal that the material removed from the waste stream
           for recycling, composting or other strategies, including source reduc-
           tion, of 60 percent by the year 2025." I presume those figures, then,
           were based on including that 60 percent figure.

                 I think we should take into account the possibility that future Boards
                 of County Commissioners could very well take a more aggressive
                 stance toward that reduction through more recycling from residential
                 and business and industry and reducing the waste stream considerably
                 by recycling and composting of food wastes from institutions, restau-
                 rants, grocery stores and so forth, so that the more the waste stream is
                 reduced, the less is going to be left to burn. I mean, this is just com-
                 mon sense. And so it is inevitable that we're going to importing more
                 and more fuel for the plant.
Response:
The MRA Diversion Rate of 73 percent for Frederick County and 55 percent for Carroll
County was assumed for the year 2025. This MRA Diversion rate includes FCCRWTE
recycling of metals and ash and includes a County source reduction credit of 5 percent.
As previously mentioned, 2009 Frederick and Carroll Counties MRA diversion rates are
46.63 and 42.05 percent, respectively.

            to become energy-independent, but trash-dependent.

This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal

The Frederick and Carroll Counties' Energy Recovery Agreements (individually signed
in July 2009 with NEA) require that NEA be provided written direction by both Counties

Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. The purpose of this Preliminary Draft MSP is to identify the goals and
approaches for separating certain components of the municipal solid waste stream in the
Frederick and Carroll Counties' service areas to make the separated materials available

                                            12                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
for recycling. Information regarding jobs and permanent employment at FCCRWTE will
be provided to the public through local job postings and Web sites. Information will also
be posted on the NEA Web site (http://www.nmwda.org).


ANDREWS-1: I think the comment on page 3-10 needs to be further elaborated if
            you're going to make mention of it, and specifically, there should be
            a link to the recommendations that were put forth from the Environ-
            mental Advisory Council in October of 2007. Those recommends can
            be found at ccgovernment.carr.org/cpg/eac/recommend.pdm.[correct
            link is http://ccgovernment.carr.org/ccg/eac/recommend.pdf]
Response:
The correct link to the October 2007 Carroll County Environmental Advisory Council
recommendations is noted. The comment is noted for the record, and the link has been
added to the Final Draft MSP.


ANDREWS-2: First, the council recommended that Carroll County change the para-
            digm from solid waste management to resource management. That
            would involve elevating recycling as the driving element of resource
            management, one, by creating and verifying recycling reporting poli-
            cies, and two, by managing its own system in order to direct recycled
            goods to specific recovery centers, and three, by increasing funding to
            recycling operations for expanded public education efforts. The board
            also recommended that the Board of County Commissioners view
            public education and behavior modification as essential in the transi-
            tion to the new paradigm of resource management. This will require
            staff and media attention as needed. Again, the board -- or the coun-
            cil also recommended not supporting the plan for the construction of
            this waste-to-energy facility, but, rather, that the County's efforts di-
            rect its resource management strategy as outlined above, or as I have
            described, for a period of five years. The council also recommended
            that the Board of Commissioners implement and support pay-as-you-
            throw trash collection programs and the commission, the EAC, to
            work in concert with the Department of Public Works to create a
            community process to begin or to design essential elements of that
            program. The council also recommended that the Board of Commis-
            sioners of Carroll County undertake a feasibility study of creating a
            countywide composting facility where organic material could be
            turned back into useful products for local farmers and reduce green-
            house gases. In closing, I just wanted to make everyone aware of
            those recommendations and that they be referenced in this plan.

Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal

WEST-1: I, too, have read this report from cover to cover, and I couldn't help but
          wonder what this Material Separation Plan had to do with waste energy
          incineration.
Response:
This preliminary draft MSP fulfills one of the requirements of Title 40 of the Code of
Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 60, Subpart Eb, New Source Performance Standards
(NSPS) for FCCRWTE. The standard also prescribes a specific process that must be fol-
lowed to ensure the opportunity for public review and comment on the preliminary draft
MSP. The process consists of the following:
      ·     Preparation and issuance of a preliminary draft MSP for public comment.
      ·     Notification of a public meeting for accepting oral and written comments on
            the preliminary draft MSP.
      ·     Acceptance of written comments on the preliminary draft MSP.
      ·     Preparation of written responses to any public comments.
      ·     Identification of the location(s) where written responses to public comment.


WEST-2: In my opinion, recycling and waste-to-energy are competing for the same
          resources. They're in direct competition. And I must say that I am severely
          underwhelmed by my county, Carroll County's, efforts when it comes to
          recycling. There is no incentives for the residents, there is no commercial
          program, no composting of food waste. Frankly, I view it as a lack of lea-
          dership.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-1 for current MRA Diversion rates and BUR-
RUSS-3 for projected MRA Diversion rates.


WEST-3: And within the media, within the Material Separation Plan, there is a table
         on page 1-1 that talks about the Frederick and Carroll County Solid Waste
         Management Plan, and under Carroll County it says, "The effective im-
         plementation of an integrated system of solid waste management and recy-


                                          14                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
            cling that will allow sufficient flexibility to react to changes in regulation,
            technology and market conditions."

            I guess my question is, how does a thirty-year agreement with this waste
            energy facility meet those criteria?
Response:
An integrated system of solid waste management includes provisions for recycling, re-
source recovery (waste-to-energy), waste transfer and disposal. A waste-to-energy facili-
ty provides a long-term solid waste disposal option, for waste that is not recycled, that
meets current and future disposal needs, generates clean renewable energy, and is com-
patible with recycling and metal recovery programs.


WEST-4: In closing, I view this evening's effort as a bit disingenuous. My question of
          the EPA and the Maryland Department of the Environment is simply, is
          your mission to protect the health of our citizens and the environment of
          our state, or to protect the health of waste management and the environ-
          ment for these big industries?
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. FCCRWTE is required to obtain a number of permits associated with
refuse disposal, sewage sludge utilization, tire-derived fuel use, wastewater discharge,
and air emissions from MDE. During the MDE permit review process, these permit ap-
plications will be available for public review and comment. Comment noted for the
record.


REAVER-1: I would just like to say I'm in support of this project. A majority of our
           Frederick County commissioners have joined with a majority of Carroll
           County commissioners to craft a plan after more than five years of study
           that includes the best long-term options for the waste reduction, recy-
           cling and dependable, cost-competitive renewable waste energy technol-
           ogy that has successfully served other communities in Maryland, the
           United States and the world.

               Many communities fail to plan for their future needs and invest in their
               long-term infrastructure. Our county leaders have done their homework
               and set a responsible course of action that is safe, sustainable and will
               solve our trash problem.

                The County's plan for recycling renewable waste energy as reflected in
                the Material Separation Plan has my support. I would encourage others
                to consider the benefits of this project.
Response:
Comments in support of the project noted for the record.


SNYDER-1: First I would like to mention that in this plan that's referenced, on page
           4-1, they talk about the solid waste options for Frederick County being
           the construction of a composting facility to process residues long-hauled
           out of Frederick County for disposal.

                Some of us -- and I'm involved with an environmental group -- some of
                us would ask why wasn't a large-scale source separating composting fa-
                cility concerned?
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. This alternate solid waste disposal option was considered in 2005 and was
determined not to be as cost effective as waste-to-energy. Further information can be
found      on   Frederick    County's     Web     site     under     Waste         to      Energy
(http://www.frederickcountymd.gov/index.aspx?nid=3208 [accessed January 11, 2011]).


SNYDER-2: Basically, I think it's important -- from what I know, the plans for this
           waste-to-energy, this incinerator to burn trash, these plans were made
           way before the remarkable use in recycling rates offered to Frederick
           City, especially since we began the single stream process. And such a
           cost, with those possible dangers that are unknown, made before we
           have this new information, need to be reconsidered.
Response:
The Frederick County (which includes Frederick City) single-stream recycling program is
an integral part of the solid waste management program that includes the waste-to-energy
project.


SORBELLO-1: My concerns regarding the Authority's Draft Materials Separation
            Plan include, but are not limited to the following: Trends docu-
            mented in reports from the Covanta incinerator in Montgomery
            County, Maryland, have shown that, A, increased recycling decreas-
            es the quantity of materials available for incineration, and B, source
            reduction and recycling of materials such as paper and plastic dimi-

                                           16                 Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
                  nishes the energy value of incineration, which reduces the electrical
                  generating capability of the facility.

                  In other words, as other speakers have said, recycling and incinera-
                  tion are not compatible. They directly compete with each other, both
                  materially and financially. I don't believe our county can afford a
                  comprehensive recycling program if we are spending tens of millions
                  of dollars a year to subsidize the incinerator operation and we can-
                  not produce enough electricity for incineration if we are recycling
                  effectively.
Response:
Communities nationwide using waste-to-energy have an aggregate recycling rate at least
5 percentage points above the national average (Recycling and Waste-to-Energy Are
They Compatible? 2009 Update Governmental Advisory Associates, Inc., Eileen Brettler
Berenyi, June 2009). This is true in Maryland as Baltimore, Harford, and Montgomery
Counties have the some of the highest MDE waste diversion rates (MDE 2009 data:
42.94, 62.03, and 47.04 percent, respectively). The Final Draft MSP will be revised to
emphasize this point.


SORBELLO-2: Also, I'm concerned that there is no separation of material at the inci-
             nerator. Any milk jug or aluminum cans or paper or plastic that ar-
             rives at the plant will be burned. Also, any recovered ferrous metal is
             retrieved by use of magnets to pull them out of the ash after burning.
             I believe that these materials can be recovered without the incinera-
             tor.
Response:
FCCRWTE is a mass-burn type waste­to-energy facility that directly combusts the deli-
vered solid waste. This type of facility works effectively with single-stream recycling
programs as the majority of recyclables are removed from the collected solid waste
stream before it is sent to the waste-to-energy facility. FCCRWTE will also recycle met-
als and ash that would otherwise be landfilled. Recovered metal volumes will depend on
the amount of metals remaining in the MSW delivered to FCCRWTE.


SORBELLO-3: I also find it troubling on the authority website in the About Us sec-
             tion, there is an image of recyclable materials, cans, bottles, et cetera,
             which are twirled around, and then they become a light bulb. I think
             this is really implying that it's preferable to burn these materials for


                                          17                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
                  a small amount of energy recovery, rather than recycle them in order
                  to save energy. Recycling saves three to five times the amount of
                  energy that incinerators produce when you look at the life cycle of
                  these materials.
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


SORBELLO-4: Also, on page 3-8 of the Draft Material Separation Plan, it states that
             tires will be brought to the facility for burning, rather than being re-
             cycled.

                  The environmental community discourages under any circumstances
                  the use of tires as fuel. Burning tires is extremely polluting. In tests
                  all around the country there have been increases in air pollution as a
                  direct result of tire incineration. There have been increases in mer-
                  cury, lead, zinc, sulphur dioxide, carbon monoxide, arsenic and ben-
                  zine [benzene]. These compounds are carcinogenic. Mercury from
                  tire burning is linked to brain, lung, kidney damage, reproductive
                  problems and death. Very young children and the unborn are espe-
                  cially vulnerable to these effects.

                  Tires can be utilized instead for an almost unlimited range of crea-
                  tive uses, including auto parts, playground equipment, sound bar-
                  riers, railroad ties and tennis courts. Burning tires for limited energy
                  production which results in ash and air pollution is the lowest use of
                  scrap tires.
Response:
Tires will be combusted at FCCRWTE as permitted by MDE Tire-Derived Fuel Facility
Approval Permit and will meet the permitted air quality emission rates defined by the
MDE Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD)/Air Permit to Construct.


SORBELLO-5: Also, I want to just reiterate, other people have said that due to the
             fact that the proposed incinerator requires approximately 1500 tons
             per day of material, which is almost twice what Frederick and Car-
             roll Counties are currently producing, we will have to import from
             other counties, and probably other states as well. Trash truck traffic
             will cause pollution, clogging our roads and our lungs for decades to
             come.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Please refer to the response to TWIGG-2. Comment noted for the record.

DUNSMORE-1: I would like to call your attention to a website, reutersinternation-

This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal

approaches for separating certain components of the municipal solid waste stream in the
Frederick and Carroll Counties' service areas to make the separated materials available

JUNG-1: The report, the Frederick County MSP report, says that it will burn accepta-
         ble materials, including tires, sludge and perhaps hospital waste. It was not


                                           21              Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
            very detailed on that. Hospital waste and these other sources are all very
            rich sources of dioxins.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Infectious/medical waste is not accepted as a processible waste at
FCCRWTE.


JUNG-2: My concern and question is, how will the Frederick County WTE be moni-
        tored for emissions of dioxins and other toxins into the surrounding envi-
        ronment. Not at the smoke-stack level, but outside. The dioxins can go
        through the process untouched; they can generate dioxins and also in the
        smokestack as they are going out they can be generated.

            They're fat-soluble, so they're readily absorbed and slowly eliminated from
            the body, so long-term exposure is a problem.

            As in the old computer adage Bill Gates might use, garbage in, garbage
            out, and here the question is, dioxin precursors in, how much is coming
            out.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Please refer to the response to TWIGG-4.


JUNG-3: And as the plant is built, I believe that air sampling should be performed by
          an independent agency at designated sites, including schools in the area
          around the plant before the plant becomes operational to establish a base-
          line mode of dioxin and other toxins that will be released by the process,
          and then on a routine basis at times not known to the operators so they can
          manipulate the plant, samples should be taken to monitor revisions, and
          these reports should be made part of the public record to assure citizens of
          Frederick County that they're not being exposed to hazardous levels of tox-
          ins from the plant.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. This comment should be made as part of the MDE PSD/Permit to Con-
struct Air Permit public comment record.




                                           22               Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
BROWN-1: I'm here to support the project, and I applaud Frederick County and Car-
          roll County for bringing the project forward.
Response:
Comment in support of the project noted for the record.


BROWN-2: Listening to a lot of the other comments going on, I feel that Frederick
          and Carroll County have exhaustively studied the project for over five
          years and concluded that this project is both environmentally sound and
          cost-effective.
Response:
Comment in support of the project noted for the record.


BROWN-3: The project will provide significant local spending and jobs in Frederick,
          while increasing recycling and reducing our waste footprint by as much
          as 90 percent.
Response:
Comment in support of the project noted for the record.


BROWN-4: I'm primarily concerned about the environment and future landfill prob-
          lems. The company I work for has worked around our local landfill, and
          I have the realization of what happens when you actually just bury all the
          things that we're talking about, and my feeling is that by burying, it
          doesn't solve the problem.

              Working in the construction industry, I see the extreme amount of waste
              that we end up generating that goes into our landfills, and understanding
              the waste-to-energy possibility, can see that this is a much better option
              than burying things in the landfill, and by burying things, hope they just
              go away forever. That actually is not a fact.
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


FORTIN-1: This plan calls for burning recyclable material at a time when all efforts
           should be directed toward recycling as much as possible. Plans to in-
           crease recycling while sustaining a furnace that requires such an input
           cannot occur without Frederick becoming a local dumping ground for
           trash from every surrounding suburban area, as well as the cities of Bal-
           timore, Washington and beyond. Calling it acceptable material does not


                                           23               Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
               change the fact that it should be recycled, rather than burned. Burning
               recyclables is just plain dumb and should not be part of this plan.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-4.


FORTIN-2: More importantly, there is extremely little in the plan to help us avoid in-
           cineration as much as possible. The plan, as well as the project itself, is
           designed to put the local government into the trash business, at the op-
           position and extreme displeasure of the taxpaying citizens who must
           breathe this air.
Response:
Please refer to the response to DUNSMORE-1.


FORTIN-3: The fact that this plan would burn recyclable generic materials to me is a
           clear indication that this is an irrational approach which is clearly
           geared to make a business opportunity out of what is supposed to be a
           public service.

               The Materials Recovery Plan is yet another attempt to greenwash this
               project and perhaps an attempt to clean up its act by making it sound as
               though recyclables will be sorted at the facility. However, the plan does
               not call for that at all, and instead is more like a laundry list of all the
               good recyclable materials that it sees fit to burn.

               I, for one, must protest and ask that the plan be rewritten so as to make
               every attempt to presort recyclables and send them to a recycling facility.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-4.


SCHMIDT-1: Currently, our solid waste contains a significant proportion of liquid.
            Could you tell us what this proportion is? How is this liquid going to
            be eliminated according to the Material Separation Plan?
Response:
The MSP does not determine acceptable and unacceptable waste; that will be determined
by the air and refuse disposal permits.




                                            24                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
ELMALEH-1: The biggest fault I see in the planning process is a common fault in
            long-term planning that I have been involved with, and that is what I
            would call the fallacy of fixed assumptions.

                 We try to plan ahead, look thirty years, twenty years in advance, and
                 we of course are using assumptions about how things are done today.
                 That is a very dangerous planning position to be in.
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


ELMALEH-2: Specifically, when you look at the kind of waste stream that we have
            today versus what we probably will have thirty years in the future, I
            think we are looking at a dramatically different composition of that
            stream. I think it's completely unrealistic to assume that the manu-
            facturing process that now gives you the percentage breakdowns of
            recyclable, reusable, compostable and nonrecyclable, noncomposta-
            ble, nonreusable percentages are going to stay the same over a thirty-
            year period. Over a thirty-year period. It's simply unrealistic.

                 The manufacturing processes that are going on today, the kind of re-
                 search and development, the kind of work in nanotechnology, biofu-
                 els and all kinds of material engineering, are such that they are going
                 to move in the direction of greater recyclability, greater reusability
                 and less of the kind of composition, the kind of waste composition
                 that this plant basically says it's going to be twenty, thirty years from
                 now. It is absolutely laughable.

                 This is not good science. This is not realistic projection. You have to
                 take into account what is going on in research and development, you
                 have to look at long-term trends, not as they are today, but what
                 they're likely to be in the future.

                 Now, admittedly you cannot always determine what the future is
                 going to look like, but in a highly dynamic environment where we're
                 looking at significant changes in technology, it is foolish to commit
                 yourself to a 19th-century technology.

                 And I have to say, with all due respect to the staff and all the people
                 who support this, you are using static assumptions. And it would be
                 laughable if it weren't so tragic.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-4. Comment noted for the record.




                                           25                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
                     FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY
                 RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

                        MATERIALS SEPARATION PLAN
                         COMMENTS AND RESPONSES
                    WRITTEN COMMENTS RECEIVED
                                 Harvey Alter Letter


ALTER-1: Existing Operations: As described in Chapter 2 of the draft report, Frede-
          rick County currently has an extensive system of recyclables collection
          from households and maintains 11 drop-off locations. I suggest these
          11 locations are problematical because of difficulty in maintaining clean-
          liness and discipline and the success of the single stream collection and
          the recycling operations on Reichs Ford Road.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. Due to the rural nature of the County, the drop-off locations provide a
convenient and effective way to collect recyclables and are an integral part of the solid
waste management program in Frederick County.


ALTER-2: The draft MSP should address that the landfills operating in Frederick
          County are insufficient for the long-term sanitary disposal of MSW. Ap-
          parently, the same is true for Carroll County.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. The purpose of this preliminary Draft MSP is to identify the goals and
approaches for separating certain components of the municipal solid waste stream in the
Frederick and Carroll Counties' service areas to make the separated materials available
for recycling.


ALTER-3: MSW Quantities and Projections: Clearly, MSW generation is proportion-
          al to population. However, the usual practice of quoting per capita gener-
          ation is misleading and often wrong. Such calculations include all MSW
          and mislead lay audiences to think that each person, in each household,
          actually generates that much waste. Franklin & Franklin in their various
          reports and updates to EPA on MSW generation in the United States,
          going back to shortly after passage of RCRA (1976), pointed out that the

                                           26               Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
             household portion of MSW ranges from 45 to 55 weight percent. This
             number is repeated in the most recent update report. Moreover, careful
             reading (and my past conversations with Bill and Marge Franklin) de-
             scribes the methodology for assembling generation numbers. The Fran-
             klins used input-output analyses and reported waste generation as the dif-
             ference between the two. Such numbers have little relation to the waste
             deposited at a disposal facility.

             Moreover, when the input-output data were not available, updates were
             linear extrapolations of past years. From time to time, the Franklins
             checked their estimates by sampling curbside waste or waste brought to
             disposal facilities. However, such analyses provide one datum point on the
             spectrum of time. It is well established, and a subject of textbooks that the
             amount of MSW collected in a community varies with the day of the week
             and the season. In short, a large grain of salt must be used with any re-
             port or projection of quantity or composition.
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


ALTER-4: At the same time, trends over the last decade or so are clear that packaging
          is being light-weighted and decreasing as a fraction of MSW. One reason
          for this is the substitution of flexible packaging for rigid, meaning fewer
          cans and bottles and less weight for recycling. Many flexible packages
          cannot be easily recycled because of too little mass to be economical, dif-
          ficulties in materials handling, and composite materials that cannot be
          separated. Many flexible films are multi-layers of various polymers so as
          to preserve the contents. Many rigid packages are being made with less
          material to reduce cost. These trends will reduce the amount of materials
          sent to disposal and recycling. The draft report makes no mention of these
          trends.
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


ALTER-5: The draft report, page 2-10, plots trends but makes no mention of the as-
          sumptions that were used in constructing the plots. Reference is given to
          the NEMWDA planning model but a reader of the MSP report should not
          have to research and check that model.
Response:
Please refer to the response to CUBIT-2.




                                           27                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
ALTER-6: Materials Separation Plan: Section 3 of the draft plan makes appropriate
          mention, but could stress more, the success of the two Counties in improv-
          ing recycling over the past few years. Frederick County has a balanced
          program (outreach through engineering and sales) that could be the envy
          of any jurisdiction in the nation. Unfortunately, comparisons in recycling
          success cannot be made except within the state because there are no stan-
          dard methods for calculating recycling rates. Nor are there standard me-
          thods for determining if a jurisdiction can meet the highest and best value
          markets.
Response:
Comment noted for the record. The Final Draft MSP will be revised to emphasize this
point.


ALTER-7: The draft MSP plan should be amended to include the recent grant award
          to Frederick County from Keep America Beautiful to expand recycling
          through better marketing. The award was given because of the County's
          advanced data collection systems and aggressive approach toward improv-
          ing recycling.
Response:
Comment noted for the record. A discussion of the grant award from Curbside Value
Partnership (Keep America Beautiful) will be included in the Final Draft MSP.


ALTER-8: The MSP should include more mention of business recycling. This 45-55
          weight percent of the MSW is a treasure trove of recyclable material. Par-
          ticipation (by numbers and weight) are far below households. A different
          logistical system is needed to collect the materials, which should fit well
          into the single stream system used for households. The MSP report should
          make mention of the efforts beginning in the city of Frederick (and envi-
          rons), which has the most to contribute.
Response:
Section 3.2.2.1 and 3.3.4.1 describe the business recycling programs in Frederick and
Carroll Counties. Additional information will be updated in the Final Draft MSP.


ALTER-9: Summary: In my opinion, the summary section of the draft plan could be
          immensely improved by greater stress on the future (become more of a
          plan and less of a report of status quo.). After the WTE plant is con-
          structed and operating, the recycling programs in-place will continue,
          metals from the ash will be added (pointing out that not all metal pieces in
          the waste are separated, as other communities have learned), and the ash

                                           28               Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
             will be beneficially used. The current 44 percent or so recycling and waste
             diversion will increase sharply with the WTE plant. Thus, a recycling plan
             for the Counties must include the WTE plant as an integral part of that
             plan.
Response:
As stated in Sections 3.2.2.8 and 3.3.4.8 of the Preliminary Draft MSP, when FCCRWTE
becomes operational, following combustion, ferrous and nonferrous metals will be sepa-
rated from the bottom ash. Metals recovered at FCCRWTE will be recycled through vari-
ous contracts. A percentage of ash recovered from FCCRWTE will be taken to the ap-
propriate disposal site(s) where it could be used as daily cover in place of soil materials
from other sources. NEA, in cooperation with Frederick and Carroll Counties, will also
investigate other ash recycling options.


The summary section of the Final Draft MSP will be amended to respond to this com-
ment.


ALTER-10: There will be additional; beneficial use which, although not required
           mention in 40 CFR 605, is additional resource recovery. Today there
           are certain products, such as sanitary papers, that are not recyclable as
           materials. These products become fuel rather than landfill and precur-
           sors of leachate.
Response:
NEA concurs with these comments.


ALTER-11: Current recycling operations receive old tires. The MSP might point out
           where these go; market and usage is small or expensive and energy in-
           tensive (shredding). Tires' highest and best use may be as a fuel. The
           same is true for mattresses. Diverting these materials to the WTE plant
           is an alternative to landfill. They cannot be recycled as materials nor
           composted.
Response:
Comments noted for the record.


ALTER-12: The MSP should point out that the Counties have examined alternative
           technologies, which were found wanting. It is essential for the public
           sector not to make risky investments in new approaches with big claims


                                            29                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
              and no experience. The public must know that there are no silver bul-
              lets. Furthermore, the gee-whiz MSW technologies of today are no dif-
              ferent than the gee-whiz technologies of 40 or more years ago. There,
              the literature is clear.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TWIGG-3. Comment noted for the record.


ALTER-13: Comments from the Public Hearing: Only a few of the comments at the
           public hearing were on point of the draft MSP and some of these were
           factually wrong. Some of these comments ignored several truisms of sol-
           id waste management.

              1. We cannot recycle what is not in the waste.
              2. We cannot take something that nobody wants and make it into some-
                 thing else that nobody wants and call it recycling. (Large scale com-
                 posting is a case in point.)
              3. There is no gold in garbage. Recycling costs money. Citizens should
                 know this, and how much, before they are offered more programs.
                 The MSP should point out that it does not address economics but
                 that there are costs.
Response:
NEA concurs with these comments.


ALTER-14: One or more of the people commenting argued that recycling and the
          WTE plant will compete for combustible resources. The MSP should
          point out that this is not necessarily true as long as the materials recy-
          cling programs are maintained.
Response:
The Final Draft MSP will be revised. Please refer to the response to SORBELLO-1.


ALTER-15: In Conclusion: It is my judgment that the draft MSP is realistic and
           achievable. It fulfills the requirements of 40 CFR 605 [60]. It can be im-
           proved through the addition of a bit more material, as described herein.
Response:
Comments noted for the record.

                     FREDERICK/CARROLL COUNTY
                 RENEWABLE WASTE-TO-ENERGY FACILITY

                         MATERIALS SEPARATION PLAN
                          COMMENTS AND RESPONSES

                                   David Rak Letter


RAK Letter-1: General Comments
              1.) Publishing the Material Separation Plan in a format that does not
              allow printing may be legal but seems nefarious. Do not limit public
              access in situations where public input is being requested.
Response:
Please refer to the response to CUBIT-1.


RAK Letter-2: 2.) A material separation plan "identifies both a goal and an
                approach to separate certain components of municipal
                solid waste for a given service area in order to make
                the separated materials available for recycling."
                (from the Code of Federal Regulations)

                Many, if not most, of the combustible materials in a municipal waste
                stream are already recyclable or compostable. So, incineration inhe-
                rently competes with the Federal goal of separating materials for recy-
                cling.

                The competition between incineration and recycling will intensify over
                the projected life of the facility. New markets for recyclable materials
                have developed over the past few decades and this trend will continue
                as energy costs rise. However, taxpayers are contractually obligated to
                feed the facility. The material separation plan should require that no
                recyclable or compostable materials will be incinerated to comply with
                Code of Federal Regulations.
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-4. The MSP complies with the applicable federal
air regulations by complementing the efforts of the Counties to divert recyclable and
compostable materials from the solid waste stream prior to disposal.


RAK Letter-3: Comments on Specific Sections
              3.) Sections 1.1 and 1.2


                                           33                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
                 The Code of Federal Regulations requires that Material Separation
                 Plans identify approaches for separating components of their waste
                 stream. The plan for this facility only describes this for Frederick and
                 Carroll counties. In order to run efficiently the 1,500 ton per day fa-
                 cility requires importing waste from areas outside of Frederick and
                 Carroll counties. The material separation plan must describe how ma-
                 terials will be made available for recycling in the entire area serviced
                 by the incinerator, not just Frederick and Carroll counties.

                 Define all areas that will be serviced by the incinerator and define how
                 materials will be separated for the entire service area.
Response:
Contracts for nonprimary service areas have not been finalized. Energy Recovery
Agreements similar to Frederick and Carroll Counties' agreements would be required for
all other counties delivering waste to FCCRWTE. Please refer to the response to
TOME-4.


RAK Letter-4: 4.) Section 1.2
               The only materials designated for separation before burning are "large
               bulky metal items". All recyclable and compostable materials should
               be recovered before burning.
Response:
Please refer to the response to DYSON-2. As explained in the response to DYSON-2, the
MSP identifies the Frederick and Carroll County material separation programs, which
will successfully remove a relatively high percentage of recyclables and compostable ma-
terials from the solid waste stream prior to disposal.


RAK Letter-5: The plan does not include a centralized mechanical separation system
               or a plastics/rubber recycling unit as outlined in the Code of Federal
               Regulations.
Response:
The Code of Federal Regulations does not require these systems for FCCRWTE. The de-
finition of materials separation plan (40 CFR 60.51b, Definitions) includes: "A materials
separation plan may include elements such as dropoff facilities...or centralized mechani-
cal separation systems..." (emphasis added).




                                             34              Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
The plastics/rubber recycling unit definition is applicable to Subpart AAAA, Small Mu-
nicipal Combustion Units. FCCRWTE is subject to Subpart Eb, Large Municipal Com-
bustion Units.


RAK Letter-6: 5.) Section 2.1
               Change the first sentence from:
                 "The service areas for the MSP described in this doc-
                 ument include all residential, business, industrial,
                 institutional, and commercial waste generators of
                 Frederick and Carroll Counties, Maryland."
                 To:
                 "The primary service area for the MSP described in
                 this document includes all residential, business, in-
                 dustrial, institutional, and commercial waste genera-
                 tors of Frederick and Carroll Counties, Maryland but
                 the facility will serve other areas that are not yet
                 defined."
Response:
The Final Draft MSP will be modified.


RAKLetter-7: 6.) Change the final sentence from: "Additional waste from
                 outside of the primary service area will be accepted
                 to enable the FCCRWTE facility to operate at its de-
                 signed capacity."
                 To:
                 "Additional waste from outside of the primary service
                 area must be accepted to enable the FCCRWTE facility
                 to operate at its designed capacity."
Response:
The Final Draft MSP will be modified as recommended


RAKLetter-8: 7.) Section 2.4
              Figure 2-1 projects Frederick and Carroll counties will generate about
              333 tons of waste annually in 2015 and 364 tons annually in 2025. But
              a 1,500 ton per day facility handles 547 tons per year. This means the
              facility is oversized by two thirds at the outset and half even for the fur-
              thest projection shown. Why is the facility so over-built?
Response:
Please refer to the response to TWIGG-1 . In 2006 and 2007, a team of Frederick and
Carroll County solid waste staff, NEA staff, and an independent engineering consultant


                                           35                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
reviewed a number of proposals for a regional waste-to-energy project. The 1,500-ton-
per-day regional waste=to=energy facility provided the lowest per ton cost for the dis-
posal of Frederick and Carroll County's solid waste.


RAK Letter-9: 2025 is about when our planet reaches peak oil production. Will other
               counties and states still be willing to ship waste to Frederick with in-
               creased fuel costs or will they find local recycling and composting less
               expensive?
Response:
Comment noted for the record.


RAK Letter-10: 8.) Section 3.1
                List combustibles in the waste stream that will fuel the incinerator
                after source reduction and recyclable and compostable materials are
                removed from the waste stream. Will these be available over the life
                of the incinerator? If not, describe how the incinerator will be fed
                while still complying with Federal and Maryland material separation
                objectives.
Response:
Typical municipal solid waste composition varies widely. Table 2 of the "Solid Waste
Modeling Support for Frederick County, Maryland Board of Commissioners" by RTI In-
ternational (2008) lists the postrecovery waste composition. A recent study (Waste Com-
position Sampling & Analysis Study, Montgomery County, MD, Final Report; SCS En-
gineers; 2009) showed that the top three waste material components (organic, paper, and
plastic) are relatively consistent.


It is impossible to predict the composition of municipal solid waste over the life of
FCCRWTE. Comment is noted for the record.


RAK Letter-11: 9.) Section 3.2.2.8
                Recyclable materials should be recovered from the waste stream prior
                to burning. Hazardous materials should be removed from the waste
                stream prior to burning.




                                           36              Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
Response:
Please refer to the response to TOME-4 and RAK Letter-4. Facility permits will prohibit
acceptance of hazardous waste.


RAK Letter-12: 10.) Section 4.1
                The paragraph only describes items from a 2005 report. The material
                separation plan should include the additional solid waste disposal op-
                tions presented in 2009 and 2010 since the newer alternatives better
                fulfill Federal and Maryland material separation goals.
Response:
This comment raises an issue outside of the scope of the MSP requirement in the federal
air regulations. The MSP need not justify the decision to build the facility. The 2005 re-
port (assume reference to the RW Beck report; http://www.frederickcountymd.gov
/index.aspx?NID=3208, last accessed February 2, 2011) is the comprehensive technology
review document used for Frederick County to direct NEA to undertake the procurement
that led to a contract for the design, permitting, construction, operation, and maintenance
of FCCRWTE. There were reports and presentations made to the Frederick County Board
of County Commissioners on various emerging technologies or processes that were re-
viewed by Frederick County staff. After review of the various proposals, the Frederick
County Board of County Commissioners did not take action to redirect the efforts of
NEA as it pertains to FCCRWTE.




                                            37                Y:\GDP-11\WHEEL\MSP-COMRESP.DOCX--020711
ENGINEERING REPORT

        APPENDIX B

   TRAFFIC IMPACT STUDY
      Traffic Impact Study
                       Frederick / Carroll
                Renewable Waste To Energy Facility




Prepared for:       Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority
                    Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.




Prepared by:        Rummel, Klepper & Kahl, LLP



December 22, 2010                                             Revision 0
                                                                                    Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                         Traffic Impact Study       
 
                                                                     SUMMARY
        This report has been updated based on comments provided by Frederick County and SHA on the
Draft Traffic Impact Study dated August 30, 2010, and to reflect additional studies and analysis completed
between August and October, 2010. The comments and responses are provided in a memorandum dated
November 22, 2010, included as Appendix A.

       The Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy (FCWTE) facility site is located at the north end of
Metropolitan Court near the intersection of English Muffin Way and Maryland State Highway 85 (MD 85)
(Buckeystown Pike) in the McKinney Industrial Park in Frederick, Maryland. The facility will be owned by
the Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority and operated by Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc.
Operation of the facility is expected in Spring 2015.

         The facility will process municipal solid waste to generate electricity and will operate 24 hours per
day, 7 days per week. Site traffic is comprised of daytime employees, a few shift employees to maintain
the 24-hour operation, delivery of municipal solid waste, and hauling of ash from the site to the landfill.
The ash may be back-hauled by waste delivery trucks, but to be conservative, this Traffic Impact Analysis
assumes that no ash back-hauling will occur. The total weekday peak hour traffic generated by the
FCWTE site is 49 trips in and 23 trips out in the morning (7-8 AM) peak and 5 trips in and 26 trips out in
the afternoon (5-6 PM) peak.

         The purpose of this Traffic Impact Analysis is to evaluate and suggest mitigation for the traffic
impacts that the FCWTE facility will have on the adjacent roadway network, focusing on the site access
intersection of MD 85 (Buckeystown Pike) and English Muffin Way, and five other key intersection in the
corridor from MD 80 to the south, to the intersections with the I-270 interchange ramps to the north.

         For Existing 2010 conditions, all study area intersections currently operate at Level of Service
(LOS) D or better during both the AM and PM peaks on a weekday based on Critical Lane Volume (CLV).
Based on Highway Capacity Manual (Synchro analyses) methods, all study area intersections operate at
LOS D or better during the AM peak while MD 85 @ Crestwood Blvd. and MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound
Ramps operate at LOS E during the PM peak. The site access intersection currently operates at LOS A
(B) in the AM (PM) peaks.

          Eleven (11) project site developments have been approved by Frederick County which contribute
traffic to the MD 85 corridor. The background traffic from these sites (prorated for the expected 2015
Build-Out levels, per the County's Guidelines) generate a total of 1,940 (2,308) trips in the AM (PM)
peaks, respectively. Summary Table i on the next page provides the operations analyses for the Existing,
Combined Background and Total traffic, using the Critical Lane Analysis method as suggested in the
Guidelines.




                                                                 December 2010                                    Page i of vi
                                                                                                      Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                                           Traffic Impact Study

    Site CLV Contribution:
    I-270 SB Ramps                          597 (A)             1,229 (C)          699 (A)   1,615 (F)   709 (A)     1,625 (F)   1,165 (C)      1,232 (C)
