    I-270 NB Ramps                          953 (A)             1,380 (D)      1,196 (C)     1,861 (F)   1,215 (C)   1,872 (F)   998 (A)        1,299 (C)
    Site CLV Contribution:                    0                     0              0             0          19          11         19              11



          MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound Ramps: Mitigation includes contribution to the existing Escrow
          account (#3259 (21581)) in place to provide an additional northbound left turn lane at this
          intersection. This improvement will be designed to be consistent with the future interchange
          project for MD 85/I-270 by the SHA.

          MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound Ramps: There is an existing Escrow account at this intersection
          (#3258 (21580)) to provide two southbound left turn lanes at this intersection, which would
          provide limited improvement in CLV from 1,625 to 1,552, and a reduction in delay for the critical
          northbound movement of only about 1 second.

          Frederick County DPDR and the State Highway Administration have reviewed this Escrow
          improvement and determined that more benefit is gained by providing a reversible lane system
          for this intersection, of three lanes in the peak direction/one lane in the off-peak direction. This
          improvement would provide some temporary relief until the MD 85/I-270 interchange
          improvements are implemented.

          The County has advised that contribution to the current Escrow account, with the reversible lane
          system as the intended improvement, is preferred.

        In addition to the above mitigation measures, improvements at MD 85 / English Muffin Way are
recommended to accommodate the site traffic. This includes widening the roadway in the northeast
quadrant to provide a larger turning radius for trucks from westbound English Muffin Way to northbound
MD 85. The current turning radius is inadequate for larger trucks, and to make this turn, trucks currently
swing wide into the path of southbound left turning vehicles. With this improvement, trucks could turn right
onto northbound MD 85 without impeding the flow of southbound traffic.

         In compliance with the County's Guidelines for the Preparation of Traffic Impact Analyses for
Development Applications (July 2009), an additional analysis scenario was completed as follows: "If no
constructed improvements would be required to satisfy APFO requirements under (the prorated
background) traffic scenario, a second scenario assuming the accounting of trips from all pipeline and
pending development, regardless of when it would be developed, must be analyzed.". For this scenario,
the site only needs to mitigate its own CLV contribution to any failing intersections.


                                                                            December 2010                                                    Page ii of vi
                                                                                    Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                         Traffic Impact Study       
 
         This scenario applies at MD 85/English Muffin Way in the PM peak and MD 85/Executive Way in
the AM Peak, since the site CLV contribution is greater than 15 for these intersections/peaks, but
mitigation was not required under the first scenario. Based on the results of this second traffic scenario,
Executive Way still operates at Level of Service D or better, but additional mitigation measures are
needed for the intersection of MD 85 / English Muffin Way to mitigate for the site CLVs (19 total). The
following modifications are proposed to provide this mitigation:

        MD 85 @ English Muffin Way: Modify the eastbound lane use to provide one left turn lane, a
        shared left/through lane, and a right turn lane. In addition split phasing is required for the east and
        west approaches with this change.

         This improvement provides mitigation for the heavy traffic volume growth anticipated on the west
approach of English Muffin Way, due to the approved developments of: Russell Property, University Auto
­ Bowman's Plains Lot 2, Wedgewood Wellington Lots 1 & 2, Younkin Farm, Wedgewood Lot 16B and
Wellington Lot 3. With this mitigation measure, the MD 85 / English Muffin Way intersection will operate at
level of service D in the PM peak with a CLV of 1,366. This is a gain of 345 CLVs at the intersection,
which more than mitigates for the site contribution of 19 CLVs.

        The site's Pro-Rata Share for the above mitigation options is detailed in Section VIII of the report.
The total proposed contribution is $ 252,717.

                                                                                     Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                          Traffic Impact Study       
 
I.       Introduction
        The Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy (FCWTE) facility site is located at the north end of
Metropolitan Court near the intersection of English Muffin Way and Maryland State Highway 85
(Buckeystown Pike) within the McKinney Industrial Park in Frederick, Maryland. The facility will be owned
by the Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority (NEA) and operated by Wheelabrator Technologies,
Inc. Operation of the facility is expected in Spring 2015.

         The site is predominately an open field that currently has construction activity associated with the
expansion of the adjacent County wastewater treatment plant. It is bounded by railroad tracks on the
west side, the County's Ballenger Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant on the north side, the Monocacy
River on the east side, and the County's DUSWM Administrative building on the south side.

          The facility will have a capacity of 1,500 tons per day (TPD) and will process municipal solid
waste to generate clean, renewable electricity for sale to the local utility. The location of the site is shown
in Figure 1 and a Site Development Plan (SKC-204) is provided following Figure 1. The future Monocacy
trail is not shown on the site plan; however, NEA understands that the construction of FCWTE facility
should not inhibit the construction of the trail by others.

         The types of traffic that will enter and exit the FCWTE site will be composed of employees (plant
operators and plant staff), maintenance personnel, general delivery vehicles, municipal solid waste
delivery trucks, and ash hauling trucks.

          The purpose of this Traffic Impact Study is to evaluate the potential traffic impacts of the FCWTE
facility on the adjacent roadway network, focusing on the site access intersection of MD 85 (Buckeystown
Pike) and English Muffin Way, and the MD 85 corridor.

II.      2010 Existing Traffic Conditions

      Study Intersections

        The access to the site is via an entrance on English Muffin Way located approximately 1,200 feet
east of MD 85. English Muffin Way is a County roadway; no direct access to the site will be provided from
MD 85. As stipulated by Frederick County Division of Permitting and Development Review, traffic
operations at the following six (6) intersections were included for this study:

         MD 85 at MD 80
         MD 85 at English Muffin Way
         MD 85 at Executive Way
         MD 85 at Crestwood Boulevard/Shockley Drive
         MD 85 at Ramps 6/7 to I-270 Southbound
         MD 85 at Ramps 2/3 to I-270 Northbound

        These intersections are identified in Figure 1. All intersections are signalized except for the MD
85 at MD 80 intersection which is stop controlled along MD 80. Lane use along the approaches at each of
the study intersections and the existing storage bay lengths for left turn and right turn movements are
provided in Figure 2.

      Traffic Volumes

         The FCWTE facility will be in operation 24 hrs a day/7 days per week. However, only a handful of
staff, working in 12-hour shifts, is required to maintain this operation. Because solid waste is primarily
received at the site on weekdays and Saturdays, existing traffic volumes were obtained for the roadway
peak by conducting counts on a weekday from 6AM to 7PM. Historic intersection, ramp and tube counts
are available along MD 85 within the study limits, ranging from Year 2003 to Year 2009 from the State

Highway Administration's Highway Information Services Division (HISD). To supplement this data and
accurately assess traffic conditions in Year 2010, the following data collection was performed by RK&K in
June 2010 before the Frederick County schools closed for the summer:

        13-hour turning movement counts were conducted on Tuesday, June 8, 2010 from 6:00 AM to
        7:00 PM at the below intersections:
            o MD 85 @ MD 80
            o MD 85 @ English Muffin Way
            o MD 85 @ Crestwood Boulevard/Shockley Drive
        13-hour turning movement count was conducted on Thursday, June 10, 2010 from 6:00 AM to
        7:00 PM at the below intersection:
            o MD 85 @ Executive Way
        48-hour machine counts were conducted from Tuesday, June 8, 2010 thru Thursday, June 10,
        2010 for the following I-270 interchange ramps:
            o Ramp 1 (From I-270 Northbound to MD 85 Southbound)
            o Ramp 2 to I-270 Northbound
            o Ramp 6 to I-270 Southbound
            o Ramp 8 (From I-270 Southbound to MD 85 Southbound)

          The source of volumes for Ramp 5 (From I-270 Southbound to MD 85 Northbound) is the MD 85
Corridor Study developed by SHA Travel Forecasting Division in November 2008. The Ramp 4 volumes
(From I-270 Northbound to MD 85 Northbound) were obtained by computing the difference between the
thru volumes at MD 85/Ramp 5 and MD 85/Ramp 2 intersections. These volumes are in line with the
November 2003 48-hour count available as part of the HISD database as well as the 2010 volumes
developed as part of the I-270 Multimodal Corridor Study by the Travel Forecasting Division. The peak
hour turning movement volumes are summarized in Figure 3. The complete turning movement count data
is provided in Appendix B. Photographs of all study area intersections are provided in Appendix C.

         The lane configurations and volumes shown in Figure 2 and Figure 3 include traffic from the I-270
ramps. However, the additional lane along MD 85 and ramp volumes from I-270 were not included in the
CLV calculations at both MD 85/I-270 southbound ramps and MD 85/I-270 northbound ramps
intersections. This is because Ramp 4 at the northbound ramps intersection and Ramp 8 at the
southbound ramps intersection are free-flow movements that are not controlled by the signal so do not
impact the intersection operations. In addition, southbound MD 85 at the southbound ramps intersection
and northbound MD 85 at the northbound ramps intersection are also free-flow movements and not
controlled by the signal.

    Observations

         Based on peak hour field visits on June 10, 2010, the following key observations were noted at
the intersection of MD 85 at English Muffin Way:

        The turn radius in the northeast corner for westbound right turning vehicles from English Muffin
        Way appears inadequate for large trucks.

        The southbound left turns from MD 85 to eastbound English Muffin Way require some adjustment
        (especially large trucks) in their turning path in the instances where there is a vehicle parked
        within 100 feet of the intersection along the south side of English Muffin Way.

        There are existing railroad tracks across English Muffin Way approximately 600 feet east of MD
        85. Based on field observations, there were about 15 train crossings between the hours of 6 AM
        and 7 PM on a typical weekday. The approximate crossing times ranged from 2 to 4 minutes.
        Most of the trains were MARC trains with few freight trains.

        Extended queuing was observed during the PM peak along eastbound Crestwood Boulevard at

        Queue spill back was observed for the entire duration of the PM peak hour for the northbound

    Crash History

        Crash data and rates for the MD 85 study segment and the six key study area intersections was
obtained from SHA for the 4-year period from January 1, 2006 to December 31, 2009.The crash rates
along the MD 85 study segment were compared to the statewide average for similar segments. As shown
in the chart below, the crash rate within the study segment for fatalities, injuries and property damage
crashes is lower than the statewide average for similar facilities.


                                                         MD 85 Study  Segment  Crash Rates
                                                160

                                                140

                                                120
        Crash Rate/Million  VMT




                                                100

                                                    80

                                                    60

                                                    40

                                                    20

                                                    0
                                                          Fatal                     Injury                 Prop. Damage  
                                  Study Segment Rate          1                     86.4                       126.5
                                  Statewide  Rate             1.5                   102.2                      150.9



         Also, SHA's Crash Safety Analysis Team confirmed that neither the MD 85 study segment nor
any of the study area intersections were listed as a priority or secondary Candidate Safety Improvement
Locations for the years 2006-2008 (2009 listing will be available in the first quarter of 2011).

         The intersection crash history was summarized by severity, type and cause to identify any trends.
A total of 51 crashes occurred at all six intersections combined over 4 years (2006-2009). None of these
intersection crashes resulted in a fatality. The most prevalent types of crashes involved left turns (43%)
and rear-ends (25%). The majority of the left-turn crashes involved the southbound left turns at the I-270
Southbound Ramps intersection while the majority of the rear-end crashes occurred along northbound
and southbound MD 85 at the Crestwood Boulevard intersection.

        Grouping the crash trends by cause, there were 2 crashes involving trucks, which represents
about 4% of all crashes at the six key study area intersections. One truck-related crash occurred at
Crestwood Boulevard and one at the I-270 Southbound ramp intersection. The crashes by cause are
shown in the chart below. Please note that the total number of crashes by cause shown in the chart below
does not equal 51 crashes that occurred at all intersections combined for the duration of the study period.
This is because one crash can involve multiple causes; for example, a nighttime crash could have
happened on wet surface.

         Based on the above, it can be concluded that none of the study area intersections experience any
significant safety issues. The crashes by severity and by type are also summarized and shown in
Appendix D along with the detailed crash data.

      Capacity Analyses of Existing Conditions

       Capacity analyses were performed for the 2010 existing traffic using the weekday AM and PM
peak hour traffic volumes shown in Figure 3. The analyses were performed using both the Critical Lane
Volume (CLV) method and Highway Capacity Manual method (Synchro (version 7)).

         The CLV method is a planning-level analysis tool used to compute level of service for signalized
intersections. This analysis is based on lane configurations and hourly traffic volumes at the intersection.
It does not account for pedestrian flows, vehicle mix, signal timing, and other variables. LOS A (critical
lane volume less than or equal to 1,000 vehicles) represents the best possible operating conditions with
virtually no delay per vehicle, whereas LOS F (critical lane volume greater than 1,600 vehicles)
represents congested conditions with relatively high average delay per vehicle. CLV analyses were
performed for all six study intersections mentioned earlier in this report. Although CLV is a widely
accepted methodology for capacity analysis among Maryland's transportation agencies, especially for
planning level analyses, both CLV and HCM/Synchro were completed for this study to fully account for
the trucks associated with the site traffic.

        Synchro version 7.0 was developed by Trafficware, Ltd. using the capacity analysis theories and
methodologies that are provided in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual developed by the Transportation
Research Board. Both signalized and unsignalized intersection capacity is measured in terms of levels of
service (LOS) and delay. LOS A (delay  10 seconds per vehicle (sec/veh)) represents the best possible
operating conditions for both signalized and unsignalized intersections. Whereas LOS F (delay > 80
sec/veh for signalized intersections and delay > 50 sec/veh for unsignalized intersections) represents
congested conditions where the traffic volume has reached or exceeded available capacity, resulting in
excessive delays. Synchro analyses were performed for all six study intersections except MD 80 since


                                                                                               December 2010                                                                                     Page 4 of 21
                                                                                   Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                        Traffic Impact Study        
 
MD 85 at MD 80 is unsignalized and this study assumes that the intersection will not be signalized within
the analysis time frame.

        The key input variables used for Synchro analysis are as follows:

                       Lane widths along MD 85 and all side streets are 12 ft.
                       Transfer trailers are WB-67 vehicles. (Wheelbase (WB) is the distance, in feet,
                       measured between the front wheel axle of a vehicle and its rear most wheel axle. For
                       example, a WB-67 truck has 67 feet between the front and the rear most wheel axle.)
                       Route trucks are 30 feet in length.
                       Prevailing speed along MD 85 is 45 miles per hour (MPH) and along all side streets is 30
                       MPH except for the west leg of Crestwood Blvd. which is 35 MPH.
                       Heavy vehicle percentage values are:
                           o MD 85 (both directions) ­ 22%* between English Muffin Way and Crestwood
                                Blvd.
                           o MD 85 (Both directions) ­ 8% between Crestwood Blvd. and north of I-270
                                Northbound Ramps
                           o English Muffin Way ­ east leg: 70%*; west leg: 50%*
                           o Executive Way ­ east and west legs: 20%
                           o Crestwood Boulevard, Shockley Drive and I-270 ramps: 8%
                      (Truck percentages along MD 85 and I-270 ramps are based on historic class counts
                      while the side street values are based on existing/projected land use)
                      {*The truck percentages along MD 85 in the southern sections could have been lowered
                      to 7% and English Muffin Way to 15% based on RK&K's 24-hr count at MD 85/English
                      Muffin Way conducted on October 20, 2010. However, in order to be conservative, higher
                      percentages were retained for Synchro analyses}
                       The signal timing used for all signalized intersections for existing conditions was
                       provided by SHA and verified with field observations.

        The CLV and Synchro results for existing 2010 conditions are summarized in Table 1 below.

                                                           Table 1
                                              Summary of Analyses Results
                                  using the Critical Lane Volume Method & Synchro HCM
                                                     2010 Existing Traffic
                                                       AM Peak Hour                PM Peak Hour
                        Intersection                              Synchro                   Synchro
                                                 CLV (LOS)       HCM Delay*   CLV (LOS)    HCM Delay*
                                                                    (LOS)                    (LOS)
                    MD 85 @ MD 80^                             671 (A)          -           666 (A)            -

         MD 85 @ English Muffin Way                            580 (A)       8.6 (A)        663 (A)        11.4 (B)

             MD 85 @ Executive Way                             620 (A)       14.4 (B)       722 (A)        21.9 (C)
             MD 85 @ Crestwood
                                                               837 (A)       21.8 (C)      1,248 (C)       60.5 (E)
              Blvd./Shockley Dr.
           MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound
                                                               597 (A)       1.0 (A)       1,229 (C)        9.6 (A)
                    Ramps
           MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound
                                                               953 (A)       7.2 (A)       1,380 (D)       64.7 (E)
                    Ramps
        *Synchro delay is in seconds per vehicle
        ^Unsignalized intersection not included in Synchro

      As shown in Table 1, all study area intersections currently operate at LOS D or better during both
the AM and PM peak periods on a weekday based on CLV analyses. However, with the Synchro


                                                                December 2010                                      Page 5 of 21
                                                                                      Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                           Traffic Impact Study       
 
analysis, MD 85 @ Crestwood Blvd and MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound Ramps operate at LOS E during the
PM peak hour.

       The difference between CLV and Synchro LOS especially for the intersections with I-270 ramps is
because CLV LOS is based solely on the "critical" movement's capacity while the Synchro LOS is based
on average delay experienced by all approaches.

        The worksheets for all the 2010 Existing Capacity Analyses (Critical Lane Method and Synchro)
are provided in Appendix E. The Synchro output also includes timing diagrams for all signalized
intersections.

III.      2015 Background Traffic Conditions

       Regional Growth

          The background traffic developed for these analyses is a combination of regional growth and the
traffic generated by the approved but un-built developments in the vicinity of the FCWTE site, as provided
by the Frederick County Division of Permitting and Development Review (DPDR). As recommended by
the County, a 1% compounded annual growth rate was applied as the regional growth rate. The County
recommended this rate because actual growth has been flat in recent years, and nearly all of the
background traffic along MD 85 is from the developments in the pipeline, which are included individually.
The County does not believe that there is much additional growth, if any, anticipated for the area, other
than what is included in the Background Development traffic volumes.

         The minutes from a May 21, 2010 meeting that was held with staff from the Frederick County
DPDR and Comprehensive Planning is included as Appendix F. The minutes include the discussion
about the growth rate that was agreed upon and the basis for the background developments that were
identified to be included in the study. Since operation of the FCWTE facility is anticipated by 2015, the
existing through traffic volumes shown in Figure 3 were increased by 1% per year compounded for five
(5) years. The 2015 Base Peak Hour Volumes are shown in Figure 4.

       Background Developments

        As per direction from the Frederick County Division of Permitting and Development Review, the
following development sites were included in the background traffic for the study:

   I. Russell Property (484,000 SF General Light Industrial) located on the west side of MD 85 near
      Marcie's Choice Lane.
  II. University Auto ­ Bowman's Plains Lot 2 (8,000 SF Auto Parts) located in the southwest quadrant
      of MD 85 and English Muffin Way (closer to Wedgewood Blvd).
 III. Wedgewood Wellington Lots 1 & 2 (170,940 SF Warehousing) located in the southeast quadrant of
      English Muffin Way and New Design Road.
 IV. Danac Remainder (Building A ­ 42,000 SF General Office; 23,000 SF Medical Office; Building B ­
      65,000 SF General Office; 130,000 SF Office) located in the northeast quadrant of New Design
      Road and Crestwood Boulevard (west side of I-270).
  V. Westview South (1,626,550 SF Combined) located on the west side of MD 85 near Executive Way.
 VI. Center at Monocacy Phase II (15,925 SF General Office; 5,200 SF High Turnover; 10,725 SF
      Shopping Center; 126 Hotel Rooms; 3,800 SF High Turnover) located in the northeast quadrant of
      MD 85 and Executive Way.
VII. Westview III (43,200 SF General Office) located in the southwest quadrant of Corporate Drive and
      Crestwood Boulevard (on the west side of MD 85).
VIII. Frederick Athletic Club Expansion (23,015 SF Athletic Club Expansion) located in the northwest
      quadrant of MD 85 and Crestwood Boulevard (closer to the I-270 Southbound ramps).
 IX. Younkin Farm (300,060 SF Warehouse; 300,060 SF Manufacturing; 76,070 SF Retail) located in
      the northwest quadrant of New Design Road and Elmer Derr Road.

      Prorated Background Traffic Volumes

          The trips generated by each of the above developments were provided by the County and are
summarized in Table 2. Per Frederick County's Guidelines for the Preparation of Traffic Impact Analyses
for Development Applications, July 2009 (TIA Guidelines) and as recommended by the County Division of
Permitting and Development Review, the background traffic volumes were prorated to include only the
amount to be constructed by year 2015. It is assumed that all background developments listed above
except for developments II and IX will be phased over at least 10 years. At the assumed rate of 10% per
year beginning in year 2010, only 50% of the background development traffic will be in place by 2015 for
all listed developments except for II and X which are assumed to be complete by year 2015.

         For all developments, the trip distribution was assumed as 70 - 90% to/from the north and 10 -
30% to/from the south for both entering and exiting traffic. The combined background development (base
plus all background developments) traffic volumes under prorated scenario for a typical weekday are
shown in Figure 5.

    Prorated Background Capacity Analyses

          The 2015 background traffic condition for the weekday AM and PM peak hours was developed by
adding the volumes shown in Figures 4 (background growth) and 5 (approved/prorated development
traffic) and summarized in Figure 6 (combined background traffic). The capacity analyses of the 2015
combined background traffic conditions were performed using the weekday AM and PM peak hour traffic
volumes in Figure 6 with both CLV and Synchro. The results for 2015 combined background conditions
are summarized in Table 3. For Synchro analysis, the signal timings were the same as existing.

                                                                   Table 3

                        Intersection                                          Synchro                       Synchro

                    MD 85 @ MD 80^                             900 (A)            -           852 (A)            -

       Based on CLV analyses, during the AM peak hour, all of the six study intersections operate at
LOS D or better. During the PM peak hour, three of the six study area intersections operate at an
acceptable LOS D or better while the other three operate at LOS F.

        Based on Synchro analyses, during the AM peak hour, four of the five signalized intersections
operate at LOS D or better while MD 85 @ Crestwood Blvd. operates at LOS E. During the PM peak
hour, four of the five signalized intersections operate at LOS E or F while MD 85 @ I-270 southbound
ramps operates at LOS D.

        The worksheets for all the background capacity analyses (Critical Lane Method and Synchro) are
provided in Appendix H.

    Planned Improvements

        As noted in Table 3 above, MD 85 @ Crestwood Blvd., MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound Ramps and
MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound Ramps operate at a failing LOS either in the AM or PM or both peaks under
2015 combined background conditions. However, the SHA has an active project planning study to
upgrade MD 85 to a multi-lane divided highway from south of English Muffin Way to north of Grove Road.
The MD 85 Phase I interchange project is the first of three projects included in the "MD 85 Planning
Study". The project includes a new interchange at MD 85 and I-270, along with roadway improvements to
MD 85 between Spectrum Drive and Crestwood Boulevard. Phase 2 of the Planning Study extends
southward from Crestwood Boulevard to English Muffin Way, and includes the replacement of the bridge
over Ballenger Creek. Phase 3 extends from Spectrum Drive northward to tie-in with the recently-
completed improvements near the MD 85/MD 355 intersection. The MD 85 Project Planning Study details
are provided in Appendix I.

                                                                                       NOT TO SCALE
                                                                                                                                                                      2010
                                                                         Copyright ADC The Map People
                                                                         Permitted Use No. 21003214
                                                                         Expiration: 03/31/11                                                                        Figure 6
                                                                                     Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                          Traffic Impact Study       
 
        Phase I of the project includes upgrading the MD 85 interchange at I-270 and the tie-ins required
at Spectrum Drive and Crestwood Boulevard. The interchange design will need to be compatible with
long-term improvements proposed as part of the I-270/US 15 Multimodal Study. The two I-270 bridges
over MD 85 will be removed and replaced with a longer, wider structure that can accommodate the
additional lanes required on MD 85 for the design year traffic (2030). Northbound MD 85 will expand from
the existing two lane section under the bridge to five lanes: A double-left that exits to I-270 North, two
through lanes, and an acceleration/deceleration lane for the loop ramps. Southbound MD 85 will expand
to four lanes: A double-left that exits to I-270 South and two through lanes. Additional space will be
included for future expansion of MD 85.

        This additional capacity will significantly improve the LOS at the three failing intersections cited
above. Phase I of the MD 85 study is currently funded for design only. Because no funding is currently
available for construction, these improvements were not included in the analyses of the 2015 combined
background conditions.

IV.      Site Generated Traffic
         The types of traffic that will enter and exit the FCWTE site are as follows:

                        Employees (plant operators and plant staff)
                        Maintenance personnel
                        General delivery vehicles
                        Municipal Solid Waste delivery trucks (including transfer trailers)
                        Ash Hauling trucks

        Refuse delivery vehicles will enter the facility site from Metropolitan Court through a security gate
and travel along the facility access road to the weighing scale. After the trucks are weighed on the scales,
the vehicles will be directed to the facility's enclosed receiving hall. After unloading, the empty trucks will
be weighed again, if needed, on the truck scale before exiting the facility.

          A 75 space parking lot is located on-site for employees, maintenance workers, deliveries, and
visitors/tours.

      Weekday Site Trips

         The trip generation for the site on a typical weekday includes the following:

         There will be a total of 51 employees on-site per day
              o Plant operators will work from either 6 AM to 6 PM or 7 AM to 7 PM in five rotating shifts
                  of five employees each for a total of 25 operators per day.
              o Plant staff of 26 will work a daytime schedule from 8 AM ­ 5 PM Monday thru Friday.
         There will be an average of 4 delivery trucks per week which will be weekday off-peak arrivals.
         Daily Truck Traffic carrying municipal solid waste (MSW) will be composed of arrivals from
         Frederick County, Carroll County and other municipalities (Howard and Washington Counties).
         The trucks are composed of self-unloading route trucks and transfer trailers bringing in MSW as
         well as transfer trailer ash trucks hauling ash back to their respective counties. However, it should
         be noted that not all incoming MSW transfer trailers will backhaul ash. To be conservative in the
         trip generation estimate, this report assumes that ash will not be backhauled by MSW trucks, but
         will be hauled in separate ash trucks.
         The truck trip generation is based on MSW throughput of 1,650 tons per day (even though the
         plant capacity is 1,500 tons per day), to be conservative in the site trip generation.

        The trip generation for the site was provided by the NEA, the owner of this site, and was
developed specifically for this facility for the functions that will be operating there. The NEA owns several
other facilities in Maryland, including the Baltimore Refuse Energy Systems Company (BRESCO), which


                                                                  December 2010                                    Page 9 of 21
                                                                                                                                                      Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                                                                                           Traffic Impact Study                                          
 
produces energy from 2,250 tons per day of municipal solid waste from Baltimore City, Baltimore County
and other areas in Maryland. The trips generated by the site are summarized in Table 4.

                                                                                                                    Table 4
                                                                                                           FCWTE Site Trip Generation^
                                                                                                                        AM Peak Hour                                              PM Peak Hour
                                                                                                           In               Out      Total                                In          Out      Total

                                                 Site Employee/Service                                    26                      0                  26                   5                 26                   31

                                                     MSW Daily Trucks                                     23                      23                 46                   0                  0                   0

                                                                 Total                                    49                      23                 72                   5                 26                   31
                                            ^Trip generation for the site was provided by the Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority (Appendix J)

The trip distribution for the site is as follows and is shown in Figure 7:

Trucks:
 47% to/from MD 85 north of I-270
 33% to/from the north/west on I-270
 9% to/from the south/east on I-270
 6% to/from MD 80
 5% to/from MD 85 south of MD 80
The truck trip distributions were provided by the NEA and were developed from a review of the waste
collection coverage area for the proposed site and the haul routes from other collection sites.

Employees:
 30% to/from MD 85 north of I-270
 40% to/from the north/west on I-270
 15% to/from the south/east on I-270
 2% to/from Crestwood Boulevard to the west of MD 85
 1% to/from Executive Way to the west of MD 85
 2% to/from English Muffin Way to the west of MD 85
 5% to/from MD 80
 5% to/from MD 85 south of MD 80
The employee trip distributions were provided by the County DPDR and are based on existing travel
patterns, with some adjustments to these patterns to account for approved development in the area.

V.                                            2015 Total Build-Out Traffic Conditions
         The 2015 total build-out traffic for the weekday AM and PM peak hours was developed by adding
the volumes in Figures 6 and 7 and is summarized in Figure 8. The capacity analyses of the total build-
out traffic conditions were performed for the weekday AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes shown in
Figure 8 using the Critical Lane Volume method and Synchro. The results are summarized in Table 5.
Existing signal timings were used for the Synchro analyses.

        Based on Synchro analyses, during the AM peak hour, four of the five signalized intersections
operate at LOS D or better while MD 85 @ Crestwood Blvd. operated at LOS E. During the PM peak
hour, four of the five signalized intersections operate at LOS E or F while MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound
Ramps operates at LOS D with existing timings.

       The worksheets for all the total build-out capacity analyses without mitigation (Critical Lane
Method and Synchro) are provided in Appendix K.

    Planned Improvements

        As mentioned in Table 5 above, MD 85 @ Crestwood Blvd., MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound Ramps
and MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound Ramps operate at a failing LOS either in the AM or PM or both peaks
under 2015 total build-out conditions. However, as explained in Section III earlier, it should be noted that
SHA has an active project planning study to upgrade MD 85 to a multi-lane divided highway from south of
English Muffin Way to north of Grove Road. The additional capacity proposed under Phase I of this
project would significantly improve the LOS at the three failing intersections cited above. Phase I of the
MD 85 study is currently funded for design only. Hence, these improvements were not included in the
analyses of the 2015 total build-out conditions.

    Mitigation for Total Build-Out Traffic

        The TIA Guidelines require that mitigation options be explored for any intersection operating at
level of service E or F with the Critical Lane Analysis method. The following mitigation options were
analyzed to improve overall traffic flows along MD 85 at these locations:

        MD 85 @ Crestwood Boulevard/Shockley Drive: Several Escrow accounts are in place for
        proposed or previously constructed improvements at this intersection as follows:

               o       #3257 (21555): Third southbound mainline lane on MD 85 between I-270 and Crestwood
                           Cost: $148,000 (basis); $296,000 (inflated)
                           Status: Constructed

               o       #3279 (21584): Added westbound acceleration lane on Crestwood Blvd. to accommodate
                       southbound MD 85 free right turn
                            Cost: $103,870
                            Status: Constructed

               o       #3280 (21585): Exclusive northbound right turn lane on MD 85
                           Cost: $251,339
                           Status: $30,666 accrued; Not constructed

               o       #3281 (21586): Restripe westbound Shockley Drive for an exclusive left turn lane
                           Cost: $77,960
                           Status: $9,512 accrued; Not constructed

               o       #3282: Provide 4th northbound through lane on MD 85
                           Cost: $1,158,300
                           Status: $83,558 accrued; Not constructed

        MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound Ramps: An existing escrow is in place to provide an additional
        northbound left turn lane at this intersection. This improvement will be designed to be consistent
        with the future interchange project for MD 85/I-270 by the SHA.

               o       #3259 (21581): Additional northbound MD 85 left turn and ramp receiving lane
                           Cost: $753,600
                           Status: $105,562 accrued; Not constructed

                                                                 December 2010                                   Page 12 of 21
                                                                                    Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                         Traffic Impact Study       
 
        MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound Ramps: The addition of a second southbound left turn lane at the
        MD 85/I-270 SB Ramps intersection (per Escrow #3258 (21580)) would improve the CLV at this
        intersection from 1,625 to 1,552 at an estimated cost of $753,600 (Escrow amount).

        However, implementation of the proposed SHA interchange design would later remove most of
        the pavement constructed from this improvement.

        The southbound double left would provide minimal improvement to the critical movement (the
        northbound through traffic) ­ a reduction in delay of about 1 second per vehicle.

        Frederick County DPDR and the State Highway Administration have reviewed this Escrow
        improvement and determined that more benefit is gained by providing a reversible lane system
        for this intersection, of three lanes in the peak direction/one lane in the off-peak direction. This
        improvement would provide some temporary relief until the MD 85/I-270 interchange
        improvements are implemented.

        The County has advised that contribution to the current Escrow account, with the reversible lane
        system as the intended improvement, is preferred.

               o       #3258 (21580): Reversible lane system on MD 83
                           Cost: $753,600
                           Status: $102,964 accrued; Not constructed

        In addition to the above mitigation measures, improvements at MD 85 / English Muffin Way are
recommended to accommodate the site traffic. This includes widening the roadway in the northeast
quadrant to provide a larger turning radius for trucks from westbound English Muffin Way to northbound
MD 85. The current turning radius is inadequate for larger trucks, and to make this turn, trucks currently
swing wide into the path of southbound left turning vehicles. With this improvement, trucks could turn right
onto northbound MD 85 without impeding the flow of southbound traffic.

        The proposed improvements are shown in Figure 9.

       The capacity analyses of the total build-out traffic conditions with the above proposed
improvements were performed using the Critical Lane Volume method and Synchro. The results are
summarized in Table 6. For Synchro analysis, the signal timings were optimized with the proposed
improvements in place to reflect future conditions with improvements.

         Based on CLV analyses, during both the AM and PM peak hours, the four intersections where
mitigation measures were considered operate at LOS D or better.

        Based on Synchro analyses, during the AM peak hour, MD 85 @ English Muffin Way, I-270
Southbound Ramps and I-270 Northbound Ramps intersections continue to operate at LOS D or better
while MD 85 @ Crestwood Boulevard continues to operate at LOS E. During the PM peak hour, MD 85 @
English Muffin Way continues to operate at LOS E, MD 85 @ Crestwood Boulevard and MD 85 @ I-270
Northbound Ramps improve to LOS D or better, and I-270 Southbound Ramps intersection improves to
LOS A.

       The worksheets for all total build-out capacity analyses with mitigation (Critical Lane Method and
Synchro) are provided in Appendix L.

VI.       100% Background Traffic Scenario
         The current TIA Guidelines state that: "If no constructed improvements would be required to
satisfy APFO requirements under (the prorated background) traffic scenario, a second scenario assuming
the accounting of trips from all pipeline and pending development, regardless of when it would be
developed, must be analyzed.". For this scenario, the site only needs to mitigate its own CLV contribution
to any failing intersections. Table 7 below provides the site CLV contributions for each intersection for
which mitigation is not already being provided under the previous scenario:

                                                                     Table 7
                                               Site Critical Lane Volume (CLV) Contributions and
                                               Corresponding Intersection Levels of Service (LOS)
                                                                               AM Peak Hour                             PM Peak Hour
              Intersection
                                                                Site Traffic             2015 Total Build-    Site Traffic    2015 Total Build-
                                                                   CLVs                     Out LOS^             CLVs            Out LOS^
           MD 85 @ MD 80                                             5                          A                  2                   A

    MD 85 @ English Muffin Way                                       3                          A                 19                   C

       MD 85 @ Executive Way                                        25                          A                 13                   C

        MD 85 @ Crestwood
                                                                                     Mitigation Provided under Previous Scenario
         Blvd./Shockley Dr.
    MD 85 @ I-270 Southbound
                                                                                     Mitigation Provided under Previous Scenario
             Ramps
      MD 85 @ I-270 Northbound
                                                                                     Mitigation Provided under Previous Scenario
               Ramps


        Based on the information above, the second analysis scenario (with 100% Background traffic)
applies at the following intersections and peaks, where the site adds more than 15 CLVs (per APFO):

          MD 85 / English Muffin Way ­ PM Peak
          MD 85 / Executive Way ­ AM Peak

         For the second scenario, 100% of all background developments listed were considered. The trip
generation is shown in Table 8 and the trip distribution is the same as under the prorated traffic scenario.
The combined background development (base plus all background developments) traffic volumes for a
typical weekday are shown in Figure 10.

          MD 85 @ English Muffin Way: Modify the eastbound lane use to provide one left turn lane, a
          shared left/through lane, and a right turn lane. In addition split phasing is required for the east and
          west approaches with this change.

                 o Cost: $16,500 (estimated ­ see appendix N)
        This improvement provides mitigation for the heavy traffic volume growth anticipated on the west
approach of English Muffin Way, due to the approved developments of: Russell Property, University Auto
­ Bowman's Plains Lot 2, Wedgewood Wellington Lots 1 & 2, Younkin Farm, Wedgewood Lot 16B and
Wellington Lot 3.

        With this mitigation measure, the MD 85 / English Muffin Way intersection will operate at level of
service D in the PM peak with a CLV of 1,366. This is a gain of 345 CLVs at the intersection, which more
than mitigates for the site contribution of 19 CLVs.

          The Critical Lane Method worksheets for total build-out capacity analyses with 100% background
traffic and mitigation for intersections in Table 9 are provided in Appendix O.

VII.      Traffic Operations along MD 85

       Truck Traffic

         Since the MD 85 study area segment has a significant amount of truck traffic in the existing
condition, and the site traffic contributes additional trucks to the corridor, the increase in truck traffic along
MD 85 was evaluated. Table 10 shows the projected 2015 AADT as well as truck percentage along MD
85 at three critical locations. The 2015 AADT is based on a 3% per year growth* on the 2010 AADT at the
three locations along MD 85. The 2010 AADT is based on SHA's Traffic Volume maps and the existing
truck percentages are based on SHA's Truck Volume maps for year 2009.

         As shown in Table 10, the increase in the truck percentage along MD 85 near English Muffin Way
with the proposed site traffic is about 3%, and near the I-270 interchange the increase is about 1%.

                                                                        Table 10
                                                                 2015 Truck Percentages
                                                                                               Truck Percentage
                              Location                          2015 AADT       2015 Without      2015 With
                                                                                                                  Increase
                                                                                    Site             Site
            MD 85 North of English
                                                                   17,411          22.0%            24.6%          2.6%
            Muffin Way
            MD 85 South of I-270 Ramps                             49,785          8.0%             8.9%           0.9%
            MD 85 North of Spectrum
                                                                   26,197          8.0%             8.9%           0.9%
            Drive
*A comparison of the traffic volumes between 2010 Existing and 2015 Combined background Traffic indicates that the growth in
traffic along MD 85 is about 10% near English Muffin Way and about 6% near I-270 Ramps. Hence, the 3% growth that was utilized
to calculate the site truck percentage can be considered conservative.

        In addition, RK&K collected 24-hrs of video at the MD 85 and English Muffin Way intersection on
a October 20, 2010 to better understand the truck percentages along MD 85 during off-peak and midnight
hours. The chart below provides the diurnal truck percentages for this location, which vary from as low as
9% during late evening hours to 36% during early morning hours. Even though there are 12 site trucks
accessing the site during 4:00-5:00PM, the number is close to 0% when compared to overall traffic at the
intersection. As seen in the chart below, the site trucks add a minimal 1 to 3% to the existing truck traffic
at the MD 85 / English Muffin Way intersection.

    Corridor Delay Estimates with Site Traffic

         The Synchro analysis delay totals were reviewed for each of the study area intersections to
determine the site impact on vehicle delay. The FCWTE site traffic does not increase the delay at any of
the study area intersections, either during the AM peak or during the PM peak, except the northbound left
turn at I-270 Northbound Ramps intersection which has an increase in delay of about 14 seconds/vehicle
during the AM peak and about 5 seconds/vehicle during the PM peak. The delay experienced by vehicles
at each of the study area intersections under 2010 existing, 2015 combined background and 2015 total-
build out conditions are shown in the charts below.


                                                                                                      Synchro Delay Comparison  AM Peak Hour

                                 300

                                                                                             (80 sec/veh)
                                 150

                                 100

                                  50

                                   0

                                                Way                                                                                                                                                                           Blvd./Shockley Dr.                                                                                 Southbound Ramps                                                                                  Northbound Ramps

       It can be seen from the charts that the increase in delay primarily occurs under the 2015
combined background conditions and moreover, the increase in intersection delay between 2015
combined background and 2015 total build-out is very small.

    Truck Turn Radius at English Muffin Way

         As mentioned in Section II under Observations and acknowledged under mitigation under Section
V, the turn radius in the northeast corner for westbound right turning vehicles from English Muffin Way
appears inadequate for large trucks. This could be an issue for the larger size transfer trailers that will
access the FCWTE facility. As mentioned in Section II under Capacity Analyses, WB-67 is considered the
design vehicle for the FCWTE facility. Hence, turn radii evaluation was performed for the westbound right
turn and southbound left turn movements at MD 85 and English Muffin Way using WB-67 as the design
vehicle. The evaluation was performed in Auto-Turn, a CAD-based program, which allows analysis and
evaluation of vehicle maneuvers for projects such as intersections, roundabouts, bus terminals, loading
bays or any on/off-street assignments involving access, clearance, and maneuverability checks. The
westbound right turns and southbound left turns for WB-67 are shown in Figures 12A thru 12D.

    Traffic Queues at Key Intersections

        As explained under Section IV, the FCWTE site traffic contributes additional trucks to the corridor.
A queuing analyses was performed with Synchro to determine the impacts on the queues with the
additional site traffic. Site trucks contribute traffic to the following turn lanes:

        Southbound left turn lane along MD 85 at English Muffin Way
        Westbound right turn along English Muffin Way at MD 85
        Northbound right turns along MD 85 at I-270 Southbound Ramps
        Northbound left turns along MD 85 at I-270 Northbound Ramps

       The northbound right turns along MD 85 at I-270 Southbound Ramps have an exclusive turn lane
and a channelized free movement, so this movement was excluded from the queuing analysis. The
queuing experienced by vehicles in the remaining turn lanes under 2010 existing, 2015 combined
background, and 2015 total-build out conditions are shown in the charts below.

        As can be seen on the charts, the site traffic does not result in a substantial increase in the queue
lengths at any of these locations. The queuing reports for the MD 85 @ English Muffin Way intersection

    Railroad Crossing on English Muffin Way

        As mentioned earlier under Section II: Existing Conditions, there is an existing railroad crossing
across English Muffin Way approximately 600 feet east of MD 85. The impact of the train crossings
(approximately one per hour) on queuing along eastbound English Muffin Way was determined, due to its
close proximity to MD 85. Synchro/SimTraffic was utilized to analyze the impact of a 4-minute train
crossing event (maximum crossing time observed during field observations in June 2010).

          Two scenarios were analyzed under 2015 Total Build-Out conditions. One was during the non-
site traffic peak (AM peak: 7:00 ­ 8:00 AM) and the other was during site traffic peak (mid-day peak:
12:00 ­ 1:00 PM). Refer to the chart below that shows the site and non-site traffic along eastbound
English Muffin Way between MD 85 and the railroad crossing between the hours of 6:00 AM and 5:00
PM. It should be noted from the chart that the non-site traffic is at its peak when the site traffic is not and
vice versa.


                                                                                2015 Total BuildOut:
                                                               Site vs NonSite Traffic along Eastbound English Muffin 
                                                                       Way Between MD 85 & Railroad Crossing
                                       140


                                       120


                                       100
                    No.  of Vehicles




                                       80


                                       60


                                       40


                                       20


                                         0
                                                                                                                                     10:00  11:00  AM
                                             6:00   7:00  AM



                                                                   7:00   8:00  AM



                                                                                     8:00   9:00  AM




                                                                                                                                                                                       12:00   1:00  PM
                                                                                                       9:00  10:00  AM




                                                                                                                                                            11:00 AM  12:00  PM




                                                                                                                                                                                                          1:00  2:00 PM



                                                                                                                                                                                                                          2:00  3:00 PM



                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          3:00  4:00 PM



                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          4:00  5:00 PM



                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          5:00  6:00 PM




                                                                                                                              Site  Traffic                                       NonSite  Traffic



         Based on SimTraffic simulation, for a 4-minute crossing event, the maximum queue along
eastbound English Muffin Way, east of MD 85 is approximately 450 ft. during 7:30-8:30AM when the non-
site traffic along eastbound English Muffin way is at its peak. Similarly, the maximum queue is
approximately 550 ft. during 12:00 ­ 1:00PM when the site traffic along eastbound English Muffin Way is
at its peak. In either case, the queue does not spill back onto MD 85. In addition, during any given hour,
the delay experienced by the site traffic (4 vehicles at most during any given crossing event) is an
additional 4 minutes.

VIII.   Pro-Rata Share Analysis
A Pro-Rata share analysis was completed to determine the reasonable improvement share for the
Frederick-Carroll Waste to Energy site. This was completed in accordance with the TIA Guidelines for
calculating these contributions for site traffic mitigation. The pro-rata shares were calculated using the
formula in the guidelines as follows:


                                                                                                                            December 2010                                                                                                                                                 Page 20 of 21
                                                                                             Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility 
                                                                                                                  Traffic Impact Study       
 

      "The calculation of the pro-rata share contribution, whether it is for future or previously built
      improvements, is based on the proportion of the development's impact to the capacity created by the
      improvement. For instance, if a site adds 10 CLV's to an intersection's LOS and the identified
      improvement required to achieve adequacy improves the intersection by 200 CLV's, the pro-rate
      share of the improvement cost would be 5% or 0.05 times the cost in total fee." Chapter 13, Page 19

The proposed mitigation measures, estimated cost, and CLV gain are provided below:

      1. MD 85 / English Muffin Way:
             Improvement/s:
                    o Add Traffic Signal (already constructed) - $73,176
                    o Modify eastbound approach to provide left, shared left/through, and right turn
                         lane - $16,500
                    o Rebuild northeast corner to provide for WB-67 trucks - $134,000
             Intersection CLV gain with mitigation: 1,711-1,366 = 345
             Site CLV Contribution: 19
             Pro-rata Share = (19/345)x73,176+16,500+134,000 = $154,530

      2. MD 85 / Crestwood Boulevard / Shockley Drive:
             Improvement/s:
                    o Provide free right turn for SB approach (already constructed) - $103,870
                    o Provide additional SB through lane (already constructed) - $296,000
                    o Modify WB lane use to provide exclusive left turn lane - $77,960
                    o Provide additional NB through lane - $1,158,300
                    o Provide exclusive NB right turn lane on MD 85 - $251,339
             Intersection CLV gain with mitigation: 1,681-1,397 = 284
             Site CLV Contribution: 9
             Pro-rata Share = (9/284) x 1,887,469 = $59,814

      3. MD 85 / I-270 Southbound Ramp Intersection:
             Improvement/s:
                     o Provide reversible lane system on MD 85 (3 lanes/1 lane in the peak hours/peak
                        direction)
             Intersection CLV gain with mitigation: 393
             Site CLV Contribution: 10
             Pro-rata Share = $19,176

      4. MD 85 / I-270 Northbound Ramp Intersection:
             Improvement/s:
                     o Provide additional northbound left turn lane - $1,000,000 (est.)
             Intersection CLV gain with mitigation: 1,872 ­ 1,299 = 573
             Site CLV Contribution: 11
             Pro-rata Share = (11/573) x $1,000,000 = $19,197

Total Pro-Rata Share for the Site:                               = $ 252,717.

Subject :           Accident Data / Analysis

Location ( s ) :

County : Frederick                                                  Town / Place :             Buckeystown

 Route : MD 85 Corridor                                             Log Mile (s) :             Multiple

           X      at      MD 80, English Muffin Way (Co 978), Executive Way (Co 1335),
                          Crestwood Blvd (Co 1179) & Shockley Dr (Co 1242) and I-270 Ramp #3 & #7.

           X    from      MD 80                                                  to            Spectrum Drive (Co1272)



Attached is the accident data/analysis you requested in your e-mail of:                                10/18/2010 .

Specifically, we are providing the following data for the subject location:




           X     Accident Summary                 X         Accident History               X      Accident Rates

           X     Study Worksheet                  X     Collision/Line Diagram             X       Other

                No reported Accidents             X    01/01/2006        to   12/31/2009   X      Combined


Comments:Attached        are .PDF file's of the accident studies you requested. Those categories
               calculated to be significantly higher than the statewide average are indicated as
               such with an asterisk (*) on the study worksheet; which would be Heavy Truck
               Related Accidents. Please note that even though this study may appear to contain
               12 months of data for the 2009 study year, Maryland State Police has not yet closed
               out the data year, additional information may appear in the near future.



Should you have any questions, please contact me at (410) 787 - 5842.

                                                               Appendix F
                                             Scoping Agreement Meeting Minutes




                                                             December 2010                                     Page F of P
81 Mosher Street
Baltimore, MD 21217
Phone 410.728.2900
Fax 410.383.3270

Date:          May 24, 2010
To:            Mark Reuss, Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc.
From:          Barb Hoage, RK&K
               Raj Basavaraju, RK&K

Reference:     Frederick County/Carroll County Resource Recovery Facility   McKinney Site

Subject:       Frederick County DPDR May 21, 2010 Meeting Minutes


A meeting was held with staff from the Frederick County Division of Permitting and Development
Review (DPDR) and Comprehensive Planning on May 21, 2010 to discuss the scope of a traffic
study for the Frederick County/Carroll County Resource Recovery Facility    McKinney Site to be
located in Frederick County, Maryland. The following people were in attendance:

                    Ron Burns, Frederick County Development Review
                    Betsy Smith, Frederick County Development Review
                    John Thomas, Frederick County Comprehensive Planning
                    Mark Reuss, Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc.
                    Richard Moitoza, Burns & Roe Enterprises, Inc.
                    Mark Carney, e3rm, llc
                    Barbara Hoage, RK&K
                    Raj Basavaraju, RK&K

Ron Burns opened the meeting by emphasizing that the Frederick Carroll Waste to Energy Facility
does not fall within the APFO guidelines because it is a public facilities improvement. As such, this
site is not subject to impact fees, like a typical private development in the County. This was a
reiteration of Ron's email to Barbara Hoage prior to the meeting, with verification of this from the
County's attorney. As indicated in that email, "Water, sewer and solid waste projects come under §2-
13-3 of the Frederick County Public Local Laws, and "shall not be subject" to subdivision, zoning or
APFO approvals. Public local laws are enacted by the General Assembly, and supersede County
laws." Although the site does not fall under the APFO requirements, Ron, Betsy and John provided
feedback in the meeting as if we are following the standard APFO process for a private development.

The Facility

Mark Reuss provided an introduction of the project including details related to site design and
operations on-site. He indicated that Northeast Maryland Waste Disposal Authority (Authority) is the
"developer". He also indicated that Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) is the primary material that will be
handled at the site. He reiterated that the only access into and out of the site will be along English
Muffin Way on the east side of MD 85.

                                                                                          1|Page
Frederick County/Carroll County Resource Recovery Facility
Frederick County DPDR May 21, 2010 Meeting Minutes
_______________________________________________________________________________

Betsy Smith indicated that the removal of cul-de-sac at the end of Metropolitan Court is already
approved. The approval was conditioned on providing a way for traffic to turn around before the
entrance of the WTE facility.

John Thomas expressed concern about impacts to the future Monocacy River Trail that is planned
along the river and adjacent to the subject facility. John indicated that, if possible, there should be a
25 foot buffer from edge of floodplain for the 10 foot paved trail. Mark Reuss stated that a good
alignment for the trail may be along the old utility access road east of the rip rap along the eastern
edge of the site, although this would place it in the floodplain. John said that it may be possible,
although not necessarily desirable, to locate the trail within the floodplain, and also stated that this
section of the trail is not funded within the next 6 years. The County would like to see the floodplain
identified on any site drawings submitted for this study.

Betsy inquired about the implementation timeline for the facility. Mark R. responded that permitting
started in January 2010 which could last about 2 years followed by a 3 year engineering and
construction period. Mark Carney confirmed the timeframe for the State permitting process.

Site Traffic

Barbara Hoage provided an overview of the site traffic patterns and distributions. She provided
handouts to all attendees that included site employee/service traffic, and the MSW daily truck traffic
for various scenarios under year 2015 and year 2046. Mark R. indicated that the truck traffic
projected for Howard and Washington Counties is only as an interim until the Frederick and Carroll
County truck traffic provides 100% of the projected daily MSW capacity for the facility. Mark R. also
indicated that there has been no agreement yet with Howard and Washington Counties.

Barb indicated that the arrivals and departures cited in the site traffic analysis indicated 7-8 AM and
5-6 PM as the peak hours. Ron indicated that the PM peak along MD 85 between I-270 and I-70 is a
"non-traditional" 12-1 PM while south of I-270 is more of a "traditional" 4:30-5:30 PM, so these site
peak hours are appropriate for MD 85 south of the I-270 interchange.

With respect to distribution of traffic along MD 85, there was general agreement among the attendees
that a larger percentage of the traffic, including the transfer trucks, will access the site to/from the
north on MD 85. Ron agreed with Barbara's assumption that there will be some traffic (about 15%)
that will access the site from the south through the MD 85/MD 80 intersection. Ron indicated that
there will be concerns from the Village of Buckeystown about impacts from the truck traffic. Everyone
agreed that trucks from the south will all be route/collection trucks.

Scope

With respect to the number of intersections that need to be included in the scope of the Traffic Impact
Study, Ron indicated that including MD 85/MD 80 intersection may help answer any questions about
traffic impact from residents of Buckeystown. He confirmed that the intersection operates well today.
Ron indicated that the two ramp terminals at the I-270/MD 85 interchange should be included since
the majority of the site traffic will access MD 85 via these ramp terminals. Ron stated that no mainline
I-270 or ramp merge/diverge analysis is needed.




                                                                                             2|Page
Frederick County/Carroll County Resource Recovery Facility
Frederick County DPDR May 21, 2010 Meeting Minutes
_______________________________________________________________________________

Ron shared with Barbara a Traffic Impact Study report that was done recently for another
development along this corridor that included all the background developments relevant for the
subject Traffic Impact Study. (Barbara is copying the report and will send the original back to Ron as
soon as possible).

Traffic Analysis

Ron suggested that, from the County's perspective, only a Year 2015 traffic analysis is needed. If a
future year analysis is desired, Ron indicated that the traffic should be projected for a 20 year period
(to 2030 and not 2046). Ron also indicated that a link analysis for the MD 85 north of English Muffin
Way would be helpful.

Ron indicated that assuming 100% build-out for all relevant background developments by opening
year is not realistic. Hence, he suggested that a prorated approach should be adopted in calculating
the trips generated by the background developments. For example, West View South development
along Executive Way is a 2 million SF office development phased out over 10 years. Nothing has
been built yet and any construction will likely be at a slow pace due to the economy. Hence, a
prorated build for background development trip generation is acceptable in the County APFO
process and would be a more reasonable approach for this study as well.

Barbara indicated that she compared a 2007 turning movement count at MD 85/English Muffin Way
and a 2009 tube count along MD 85 just north of English Muffin Way, which showed that the 2009
volumes were lower than the 2007 volumes. Ron and Betsy confirmed that there has been a drop in
traffic along MD 85 in recent years due to the upgrades performed along a parallel road west of MD
85 (New Design Road).

Barbara inquired whether any additional counts should be obtained. Ron suggested that re-counting
the volumes along MD 85 intersections would be a good idea, since the new counts are likely to
show less traffic than the 2007 data.

Ron also suggested that the study could use either 1% compounded growth or 3% non-compounded
growth for traffic projections, whichever yields a lower result.

Ron and John indicated that the MARC line that cuts across English Muffin Way just east of MD 85
carries 1 freight train as well as few commuter trains per day.

Mitigation

Ron and Betsy speculated that the construction of I-270/MD 85 interchange will not happen until year
2015. Barbara indicated that RK&K has contacted SHA and obtained the plans for improvements to
the interchange, as well as the travel demand forecasts and Synchro model for the improvements.
RK&K will include the I-270 ramp intersections on MD 85 in the Site Traffic Study, even though
mitigation is not anticipated or required for this project to proceed.

The County handles mitigation by requiring private developers to contribute a prorated amount to an
escrow fund established for the intersection or roadway to be mitigated. Ron and Betsy indicated that
there are existing escrow accounts at MD 85/Crestwood Blvd and MD 85/English Muffin Way. If the
Authority proceeds with any improvements at MD 85/English Muffin Way to better accommodate site
traffic, the escrow money for that intersection could potentially be contributed toward the
improvements.

                                                                                            3|Page
Frederick County/Carroll County Resource Recovery Facility
Frederick County DPDR May 21, 2010 Meeting Minutes
_______________________________________________________________________________

If you have any questions regarding the above minutes, please contact Barbara Hoage at
410.462.9278 or bhoage@rkk.com. If no comments are received by June 4, 2010, these minutes will
be considered final.
