Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.      v               Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                                                          1.0 INTRODUCTION


This operations and maintenance (O&M) plan describes the proper handling, storage, and
disposal of wastes at the Frederick/Carroll County Renewable Waste-to-Energy Facility
(Facility or FCCRWTE). Furthermore, it addresses wastes brought to FCCRWTE as fuel
and covers wastes generated onsite such as ash, used oil, and used batteries.


The requirements described herein are derived from applicable laws and regulations, as
well as from FCCRWTE and Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc.'s (WTI's) company poli-
cies. Employees will use this plan as a reference whenever questions regarding wastes
arise. This O&M plan addresses the applicable requirements of the Code of Maryland
Regulations (COMAR), Title 26.04.07.25 B(6) and D. Specifically, this O&M plan iden-
tifies the operation activities.


In addition to O&M procedures described herein, FCCRWTE will develop and imple-
ment, prior to commencement of operations, the following Facility-specific additional
procedures, directives, and policies:
                        Tipping floor safety rules and procedures.
                        Load observation procedures.
                        Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC)-containing appliance management plan.
                        Environmental regulatory requirements procedures.
                        Suspected infectious waste deliveries procedures.
                        Radiation protection, action, and monitoring procedures.
                        Environmental, health, and safety standard operating procedures for han-
                        dling radioactive loads.
                        Special wastes evaluation/acceptance procedures.
                        Pit management strategy procedures.
                        Third-party waste transport and disposal directive.
                        Procedures for characterizing new wastes generated at FCCRWTE.
                        Ash policy and handling procedures.
                        Small-quantity generator hazardous waste policy and handling procedures.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.         1-1           Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        Guidelines on FCCRWTE's third-party waste services provider identifica-
                        tion and use policy.
                        Emergency preparedness plan.
                        Fire control and emergency evacuation plan.
                        Spill prevention, control, and countermeasure and stormwater pollution pre-
                        vention plans.


1.1        REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS
FCCRWTE can only take in wastes deemed acceptable under environmental regulations
and permits. Regulations and permits also detail how wastes must be managed after they
are accepted. Self-generated wastes must also be handled and disposed of in accordance
with regulatory requirements. The following regulations and permits apply to
FCCRWTE:
                        State and federal solid waste regulations (COMAR 26.04.07; Volume 40 of
                        the Code of Federal Regulations [CFR], Part 240).
                        State and federal hazardous waste regulations (COMAR 26.13; 40 CFR 260
                        through 279).
                        State         and         federal   universal   waste   regulations   (COMAR 26.13.10;
                        40 CFR 273).
                        State and federal used oil regulations (COMAR 26.13.10; 40 CFR 279).
                        State and federal air regulations (COMAR 26.11; 40 CFR 50 through 86).
                        Refuse disposal permit (issued by the Maryland Department of the Envi-
                        ronment [MDE]).
                        Sewage sludge utilization permit (issued by MDE).
                        Scrap tire solid waste acceptance facility approval (issued by MDE).
                        Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD)/Permit to Construct air permit
                        (issued by MDE)
                        Title V air permit (issued by MDE).


It is the strict policy of FCCRWTE to operate in accordance with applicable regulations
and within permit conditions.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.           1-2                     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
1.2        PERSONNEL
1.2.1           AUTHORITY AND RESPONSIBILITY
FCCRWTE personnel are responsible for:
                        Properly managing and disposing of wastes generated onsite, such as
                        used/waste oil or universal wastes.
                        Ensuring that only authorized wastes are accepted at FCCRWTE for dispos-
                        al.
                        Reviewing and following the O&M plan.


The environmental health and safety (EH&S) manager is additionally responsible for:
                        Developing and implementing the O&M plan.
                        Employee training.
                        Ensuring shipping papers and manifests are complete and correct.
                        Recordkeeping.


The operations manager is additionally responsible for:
                        Ensuring that periodic load observations (refer to Subsection 2.2.2) are per-
                        formed by the tipping floor loader operator.
                        Ensuring proper forms and logs are completed.
                        Ensuring wastes are properly managed on the tipping floor and throughout
                        FCCRWTE.


The maintenance manager is additionally responsible for observations of universal waste
storage areas.


Appendix A contains a description of the reporting structure.


1.2.2           TRAINING
O&M personnel participate in annual O&M plan training, and training records are main-
tained by the EH&S manager. The training program teaches employees how to perform


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   1-3                 Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
their duties in accordance with this O&M plan. FCCRWTE's EH&S manager directs the
training program.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   1-4   Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                2.0 WASTES DELIVERED TO THE FACILITY FROM OFFSITE


2.1        ACCEPTABLE WASTE VERSUS UNACCEPTABLE WASTE
Acceptable waste means materials and substances discarded or rejected as being spent,
useless, worthless, or in excess to the owners at the time of such discard or rejection, in-
cluding, without limitation, waste, garbage, trash, rubbish, and refuse normally disposed
of by, and collected from, residential, commercial, industrial, governmental, or institu-
tional establishments. Acceptable and processible solid waste will include sewage sludge,
witness burn documents, and tires. The following wastes are considered acceptable by
FCCRWTE:
                        Unacceptable recycled materials such as contaminated paper, cardboard,
                        cartons, boxes, plastics, etc.
                        Automobile and truck tires as permitted.
                        Rags, cloth, wood, and leather.
                        Baled or compacted garbage/waste.
                        Beds, mattresses, carpets/carpeting, and sofas.
                        Garbage, trash, waste, and rubbish.
                        Small quantities of comingled branches, grass, leaves, plant cuttings, and
                        twigs.
                        Commercial and industrial waste materials or debris that may be combusted.
                        Sewage sludge (as approved by Frederick and Carroll Counties and permit).
                        Trees and lumber; trees and lumber are acceptable if no more than 4 feet (ft)
                        long or 6 inches in diameter or width.
                        Other materials, including special handling wastes such as witness burn
                        documents/items.


The following wastes are considered unacceptable by FCCRWTE other than small quan-
tities that are commingled and/or mixed with other processible waste and that cannot be
safely removed from the waste stream:
                        Infectious/medical waste.
                        Hazardous materials, including radioactive substances/material.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-1                 Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        Contained gaseous waste and compressed gas cylinders.
                        Dirt, concrete, and other noncombustible construction material and demoli-
                        tion debris.
                        Refrigerators, washing machines, large appliances, and similar white goods.
                        Large items of machinery, equipment, and mechanical parts, such as motor
                        vehicles and major components thereof, agricultural equipment, trailers, ma-
                        rine vessels, or other large items of waste.
                        Sludge (except for acceptable sewage sludge); sewage; wastewater and sep-
                        tic waste; cesspool; or human, animal, offal, and liquid waste, including an-
                        imal carcasses.
                        Incinerator residue, ashes, foundry sands, and large volumes of plastics dis-
                        posed of as waste.
                        Offsite petroleum spill cleanup materials (unless approved by permit).
                        Transformers and other bulk electrical equipment.
                        Oil, paints (liquid), acids, caustics, poisons, asbestos, bulk chemicals, explo-
                        sives or highly ignitable substances, and ordnance materials including bulk
                        liquid waste in amounts greater than 55 gallons.
                        Other materials, the receipt and combustion of which is likely to cause dam-
                        age to or otherwise materially and adversely affect the operation of
                        FCCRWTE, constitute a material threat to health or safety, or violate or
                        cause the violation of any applicable law or any governmental approval.
                        Source-separated yard waste (grass, leaves, branches, twigs, and brush).
                        Acceptable recyclable material collected as part of any recycling program in
                        the solid waste management collection areas.
                        Bulk loads of construction and demolition waste.


FCCRWTE will not knowingly accept hazardous substances as defined in
COMAR 26.13.01.03B (10-1) or any other waste deemed to pose a hazard to operating
personnel or equipment.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-2                   Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
2.2        WASTE RECEIVING, LOAD OBSERVATION, AND TRAFFIC
Waste receiving must be done safely in accordance with FCCRWTE's tipping floor safe-
ty rules and procedures. The waste receiving process is described in the following subsec-
tions.


2.2.1          WASTE RECEIVING
The waste receiving and handling system is designed to maintain a steady flow of waste
into the plant for burning in the combustor and provide an opportunity to inspect the in-
coming waste and remove unacceptable wastes. The waste receiving system consists of
the following components:
                          Platform truck scales.                   Radiation detectors.
                          Tipping floor.                           Front-end loader.
                          Solid waste storage pit.                 Overhead solid waste cranes.
                          Combustor charging hoppers.              Video cameras.


2.2.1.1              Commercial Waste Vehicles
FCCRWTE has been designed to receive on average of 100 to 150 waste vehicles per
day. Commercial vehicles accessing FCCRWTE enter the site from the south at the main
entrance (located on proposed site plan) from the access road. Commercial vehicles must
first pass through a closed-circuit television (CCTV)-monitored gate and security barrier,
then be weighed and proceed to the western side of FCCRWTE following signage direct-
ing disposal vehicles to the receiving building. At the receiving building, self-unloading
vehicles drive onto the floor, turn, and back into the tipping bay to discharge their solid
waste directly onto the tipping floor or directly into the solid waste storage pit. Following
disposal of their waste, vehicles typically exit the tipping floor area and proceed back to
the outbound scale for weight measurement and then proceed back through the security
barrier gate and exit to the access road. Alternate routes may be used for vehicles that do
not need to be reweighed.


2.2.1.2              Platform Truck Scales
There are two platform truck scales, one for incoming trucks and one for exiting trucks.
They are located on the east side of the plant on the entrance road. The scales are elec-

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-3               Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
tronic, load-cell-type platform scales. Scale house instrumentation provides information
regarding the gross, known tare, or net weight of a truck on the scale. The scale is auto-
matically operated with a remote station in the plant.


FCCRWTE is designed to operate 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.


2.2.1.3              Truck Turnaround Time
Waste delivery vehicles entering the site are managed in an efficient manner to prevent
undue wait times. There are six tipping bays in the waste receiving building that can ac-
cept vehicles. In most practical situations, there can be multiple vehicles on the tipping
floor offloading waste, provided that safety protocols are being followed. There is also a
truck tipper located in the receiving area where trailers can be offloaded. FCCRWTE de-
sign includes multilane entry and exit from the receiving floor to help mitigate any surges
in traffic flow. Traffic is controlled at the truck scales, and high traffic flows are queued
on the delivery road prior to the receiving floor entrance. This should reduce traffic back-
up at the entrance to the tipping floor for vehicles entering or exiting the tipping floor. As
a contingency to prevent truck traffic backing up past the entrance in the event of multi-
ple vehicles arriving at the same time, trucks can queue on the plant perimeter road, start-
ing at the entrance to the tipping building. The perimeter road is designed to be three
lanes wide to accommodate queuing without interfering with other plant traffic. The max-
imum expected total number of trucks that could queue on the site's perimeter road is
70 route collection trucks or 39 tractor trailers with a wheelbase of 67 ft between the front
and rearmost axle (WB-67). The length of outside inward lane from the main entrance
gate to the entry door of the tipping floor building is 1,920 ft. Using the middle lane and
beginning at a point south of the scales, there is an additional roadway of 1,597 ft. A
combination of route collection and tractor trailers can be safely accommodated onsite.
These efforts and design characteristics support an efficient waste receiving area to keep
traffic moving in a timely manner.


FCCRWTE's roadways are designed specifically to handle the largest trucks that will be
delivering the solid waste (i.e., transfer trailers). All other vehicles are smaller and should
be able to navigate the roadway geometrics. According to the traffic impact study con-

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-4          Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
ducted by Rummel, Klepper & Kahl, LLP, peak nondelivery vehicles will be 26 per hour,
which coincides with work shift changes. Average hour volume for nonwaste delivery
vehicles is less than one per hour. The roadways are designed to handle the deliveries of
reagents and chemicals as well as access to all building parking areas and entrances. Stop
signs are used at entrances to the perimeter road to control entering traffic without dis-
rupting the main traffic flow. The perimeter road from the entrance to the scale can hold
from 5 to 10 trucks, depending on the mix of collection trucks and transfer trailer trucks.
This is more than adequate to keep traffic flowing toward the tipping floor, because the
weighing process takes approximately 1 minute.


Although safety of tipping floor operations is the primary concern and must be main-
tained at all times, proper untarping and dumping procedures of vehicles differs by type
of vehicle. Large vehicles with walking floors will take longer to complete a dumping
cycle then an automated truck due to the very nature and operation of the vehicle. The
goal of FCCRWTE is to process waste trucks as quickly as can be safely accomplished,
with a target of 30 minutes or less. Frederick and Carroll Counties have been requested to
stage delivery of vehicles to the extent practical to minimize congestion at FCCRWTE.


2.2.1.4              Noise
Noise generated at FCCRWTE results from operation of the various facilities, process
components, and the operation of vehicles on the site during fuel delivery, loading, and
related operations. Specific sources of noise include:
                        Trucking of municipal solid waste (MSW) to the site.
                        Loading and unloading at the site, including maintenance vehicles maneu-
                        vering within the enclosed tipping floor area and the ash/metal recovery
                        building.
                        Forced and induced draft fans and associated motors in the combustion sys-
                        tem.
                        Building ventilation systems.
                        Material handling (ash, lime, and carbon-based sorbent) equipment (includ-
                        ing air pollution control equipment) throughout the site.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-5                  Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        Tipping bay, solid waste storage pit, combustor/boiler, air quality control
                        system (AQCS), warehouse/maintenance, ash/metal recovery, and tur-
                        bine/generator buildings with miscellaneous internal equipment.
                        Mechanical draft cooling towers (three cells).
                        Switchyard, transformers and other electrical equipment throughout the site.


If excessive noise is noted at FCCRWTE, the shift supervisor or control room is notified
immediately. Facility personnel will attempt to determine the source of the noise without
risking the health and safety of plant personnel and determine whether or not it is coming
from FCCRWTE. If the noise is determined to be coming from FCCRWTE, the shift su-
pervisor is to make every attempt to eliminate the noise. The need for additional noise
control is determined by the shift supervisor on an as-needed basis. If this is not possible,
the operations manager and EH&S manager are then notified immediately.


There are currently systems in place to prevent noise while venting steam. The combus-
tor/boiler operation startup and shutdown procedures are used to ensure the emergency
relief valves (outfitted with silencers) are operated to minimize noise caused from venting
steam. Safety valves, used to protect from overpressure of the steam system and vessels,
are typically only used during emergency situations. Testing of this safety system will be
coordinated with local officials.


2.2.1.5              Odor
Odor control in the tipping bay building, sewage sludge building, and solid waste storage
pit areas will be achieved by maintaining these areas under negative pressure using the
combustor/boilers' primary air system. The combustor/boilers' primary air system will
thermally destroy any odors created in these areas. FCCRWTE also works to minimize
odor propagation by continually rotating the pit inventory so older waste is disposed of as
quickly as practical. If excessive odor is noted at the FCCRWTE property line, the shift
supervisor or control room is notified immediately. Facility personnel will attempt to de-
termine the source of the odor without risking the health and safety of Facility personnel
and determine whether or not the odor is coming from FCCRWTE. Wind direction,
weather, and use of a confined space meter may be used to determine if the smell is haz-

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-6                 Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
ardous or not. If the odor is determined to be coming from FCCRWTE, the shift supervi-
sor will make every attempt to remove the odor by closing doors where possible. Control
of odor needs to be determined by the shift supervisor on an as-needed basis. In the event
there is a persistent excessive odor at FCCRWTE property line that cannot be resolved by
the shift supervisor, the operations manager and EH&S manager are notified immediate-
ly.


2.2.1.6              Vector Control
Pests and vermin will be controlled by keeping waste contained in the solid waste storage
pit as much as possible and following the standard procedure of constantly mixing the
waste in the solid waste storage pit with the overhead crane. Consistent and efficient op-
eration of the boiler is important to successful long-term plant operations. To achieve this
goal, a waste storage management plan will be followed that will rotate the waste in the
solid waste storage pit. Each day operating personnel will stack the incoming waste from
the trucks in designated areas of the solid waste storage pit and feed waste from other ar-
eas of the solid waste storage pit. This waste storage/rotation plan is followed from shift
to shift and is coordinated with the management team at the Facility. This allows time for
a better mix of waste prior to feeding and provides drainage time for any wet solid waste
that is entering the Facility. Rotating the solid waste storage pit inventory on a consistent
basis reduces pests and contributes to more consistent boiler operations. In addition, a
local licensed pest control company will be retained for scheduled monthly treatments to
maintain pest control.


A high standard for housekeeping is a strong element of the facility's pest control pro-
gram. Appropriate disposal containers will be stationed throughout the facility to assist in
maintaining the cleanliness within the plant. These will be closed lid wherever possible to
reduce the opportunity for proliferation of pests.


The tipping floor is maintained in a clean manner each day with the use of the front-end
loader equipped with a rubber blade on the bucket to protect the floor from excessive
wear.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-7        Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
All vehicles exiting the tipping hall will be visually observed by the traffic controller to
ensure no waste is dragged from the building by the vehicle itself. It is the responsibility
of each driver using the site to ensure that their vehicle is clean and clear of detritus upon
exiting the facility. These procedures will be provided to all drivers during their site in-
duction. Procedures will also ensure that no food or drink is left outside onsite to help
minimize pests and vermin.


2.2.1.7              Fire, Explosion, or Other Emergency
If a major fire, explosion, or other emergency occurs, personnel will immediately notify
the control room/shift supervisor of the incident. The emergency evacuation alarm is
sounded (both audible and visual alarms) when instructed by the shift supervisor.
Nonshift personnel truck drivers, contractors, and visitors, are to evacuate the building at
that time. Non-Facility personnel will muster at a clearly marked location. On-duty shift
personnel are required to muster at the primary evacuation location unless otherwise in-
structed by the shift supervisor and become the incipient response team. The situation
status is reported to the control room by the response team leader. The responders are
then to adhere to their appropriate responsibilities. The shift supervisor ensures that the
plant manager and operations manager are notified and apprised of the situation. Appro-
priate fire department personnel are contacted as determined by the shift supervisor based
on the on-scene conditions.


2.2.1.8              Radiation Detectors
A radiation meter is installed at the scale house to detect radiation sources in the incom-
ing waste. An alarm is sounded in the scale house and control room on detection of radia-
tion. The truck is then detained, and the appropriate state agencies are notified, as neces-
sary.


2.2.1.9              Tipping Floor
The tipping floor provides ample space for solid waste trucks to unload waste, pull out,
and exit the receiving building. Operations on the tipping floor will be conducted in man-
ner such that a truck may be directed to an area near the solid waste storage pit, but sepa-
rate from the ongoing unloading operations, for the observation of the load. There is a

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-8         Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
tipper in the tipping building to allow tipping of transfer trailers that are not self-
unloading.


2.2.1.10             Front-End Loader
The front-end loader operator (tipping floor loader operator) directs the tipping floor op-
erations. His job is to minimize truck unloading and turnaround times. The tipping floor
loader operator observes the waste as it is unloaded into the tipping floor. During these
observations, the tipping floor loader operator looks for wastes that are banned by regula-
tion or permit or that can cause operational problems. Unacceptable wastes are removed
for offsite disposal before the waste is pushed into the solid waste storae pit, as further
described in Section 3.0. In the event that unacceptable waste is not discovered on the
tipping floor and finds its way to the pit, the tipping floor employees will contact the shift
supervisor. The shift supervisor is to consider safety ramifications when determining the
best course of action. The front-end loader is also used to clean the tipping floor of waste.


The primary loader, used for the tipping operation, is stored in the tipping bay building
when not in service. A secondary loader, used as backup to the primary loader and also
used in the ash building operation to load/move recovered materials, is stored in the ash
and metals recover building. Routine loader preventive maintenance is conducted in-
doors. When major repairs are required, the primary or secondary loader is sent offsite to
a service center. Other mobile support equipment, including fork lift trucks and small
front-end loaders (Bobcat or similar), is stored and maintained indoors in designated are-
as of the process or maintenance building. The facility small pickup truck is parked in a
facility parking spot when not in use.


2.2.1.11             Solid Waste Storage Pit
The dimensions of the solid waste storage pit are 150 ft long, 70 ft wide, and 38 ft deep
from the tipping floor to the bottom of the pit. The solid waste storage storage pit is sized
for a nominal 1,500-tpd solid waste storage delivery. The pit will provide 5 days of stor-
age at 1,500 tpd if the solid waste storage is stacked in accordance with the specification
requirement (minimum of two-thirds of the total storage volume to be below the tipping
floor and not more than one-third of the total volume above the pit to the level of the

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-9         Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
charging hoppers). A solid waste storage density of 700 pounds per cubic yard is ex-
pected and was used to size the pit.


2.2.1.12             Overhead Solid Waste Cranes
Two overhead cranes provide a means of transporting the waste from the storage pit to
the combustor charging hoppers. Both cranes are located above the solid waste storage
pit. These are track-mounted cranes (gantry cranes) equipped with orange peel grapples.
The solid waste cranes are also used to sort/remove any oversize bulky waste from the
pit. The cranes will transfer waste from the solid waste storage pit to the combustor feed
hoppers. The cranes will also be used to redistribute and fluff the waste to create a more
optimum mixture for combustion. From the feed hoppers, the waste falls onto a feeder
table, and a hydraulic ram pushes the waste onto the combustor grates.


The crane control area is located on the east side of the solid waste storage pit inside the
crane control room. The crane control room windows offer operators an unobstructed
view of the entire pit area. A video monitor provides a view of the receiving bay doors.
Remote video cameras are strategically located above the solid waste feed hoppers and
service bays to assist the crane operators in positioning the grapples.


The crane operators use a two-way communication system to alert the main control room
operators of an upset condition or to receive instructions on feeding the charging hoppers
during an emergency.


2.2.1.13             Combustor Charging Hoppers
The combustor charging hoppers are used to supply waste into the furnace for combus-
tion. There are two charging hoppers, one for each combustor. Each of the hoppers is
supplied with waste from either of the two overhead cranes.


In addition to keeping the charging hoppers filled with trash, crane operators also monitor
the feed hoppers for a bridge condition that blocks flow of trash feed to the combustor. If
this condition occurs, the crane operators can activate a hydraulic swing gate in the feed
hopper chute.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-10       Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
2.2.1.14             Video Cameras
Video cameras provide monitoring for hopper feeding, receiving area fire prevention, and
truck traffic safety. The crane operators share responsibility for tipping floor monitoring
with the tipping floor loader operator. Video cameras provide the crane and control room
operators with a means to monitor areas of the plant not directly in their eyesight. The
crane operator has video cameras that monitor the level within the combustor charging
hoppers for feeding purposes and allow constant monitoring of the tipping floor.


The video cameras operate continuously. Cameras located at the entrance and exit of the
plant are used to pan the entire area. Cameras over the charging hoppers show the level of
the charging hopper.


2.2.2           LOAD OBSERVATION PROCEDURES
At least four times per shift, a random load observation is performed by plant personnel
to screen loads delivered to the tipping floor for unacceptable materials. Load observa-
tions are performed by trained personnel, generally the tipping floor loader operator.


2.2.3           RECORDKEEPING
Load observation training documentation will be kept on file in the EH&S manager's of-
fice. Records of load observations will be maintained by the EH&S manager.


Records will be electronically stored in a central database. If a hardcopy is required on-
site, it will be stored and protected from loss, deterioration, and damage. When space
does not permit onsite retention, records will be stored offsite or stored electronically af-
ter scanning and processing. Records will be maintained for a minimum of 7 years except
as required by specific governing plans or procedures. All records will be available for
review in accordance with contracts or regulatory requirements. Records will include, but
will not be limited to:
                        Plant operating statistics and logs.
                        Compliance reporting associated with Title V and refuse disposal permits'
                        requirements.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-11             Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) records.
                        Employee training records.
                        Waste load inspections.
                        Spill management records.
                        Stormwater and groundwater monitoring plans.
                        Environmental policy and plans.
                        Facility permits, including state and local regulatory requirements.


2.2.4           OTHER TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT
2.2.4.1              Commercial Delivery Vehicles
Bottom ash, fly ash, and metal recovery vehicles and lime and carbon-based sorbent de-
livery vehicles enter the FCCRWTE site using the same route as the waste delivery vehi-
cles and, after being weighed, will turn westerly following the road toward the ash and
metal recovery building or their respective material unloading areas. Once load-
ed/unloaded, the vehicles return through the scales and exit FCCRWTE through the main
entrance.


Service vehicles may access FCCRWTE by turning left after passing the scale. The ser-
vice vehicle road follows the perimeter access road system. Service vehicles leaving
FCCRWTE follow the service vehicle access road past the scale before exiting.


After the ash trucks have been loaded, they are to pass through the wheel wash and then
exit the building on the south side. The wheel wash station wastewater, one of the miscel-
laneous services water uses shown on the water balance diagram depicted in Figure 4-11
of the engineering report. This water balance shows how water within FCCRWTE is used
and includes contact water. Water that comes in contract with the ash will be collected
and managed in the contact water system as depicted on the drawing and will not be dis-
charged into the stormwater collection system.


The wheel wash station will be located at the southwest corner of the ash and metal re-
covery building. Trucks will enter the ash and metal recovery building at the northwest


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-12                 Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
corner of the building and proceed directly to the wheel wash station after loading. The
wheel wash station consists of a concrete pad with trench drains, sump pit, pumps, buffer
tank, photo eyes, and spinner nozzle sprayers. The concrete pad will be sloped toward the
trench drains to collect all wash water from the station. Nozzle sprays will direct spray
wash water in a northerly direction (toward the interior of the ash and metal recovery
building) as the truck travels in a southerly direction through the station. Water and sedi-
ment will be collected in the trench drain and flow to a sump pit. All trench drain and
sump pit covers will be removable so as to provide maintenance access to the trenches,
sump pit, and sump pumps. Water and sediment collected in the sump pit will be pumped
directly to the contact water treatment building.


2.2.4.2              Employee and Visitor Parking
Visitors and administrative personnel accessing FCCRWTE proceed through the first en-
try way from the access road following signs to the visitor parking area and administra-
tion building. These visitors park and then proceed to the administration offices located in
the main building via the walkway from the parking area to the building. A CCTV system
monitors the staff and visitor entrance, and a gate is provided as a security barrier after
normal business hours to prevent vehicles from proceeding past the administration build-
ing.


Facility personnel parking is located east of the administration building as well as the
north and west sides of the plant. FCCRWTE personnel park in any of these three areas
and proceed into the Facility via the walkway from the Facility personnel parking lots to
FCCRWTE.


2.2.4.3              Maintenance Outage Traffic
During scheduled maintenance outages, FCCRWTE visitor parking areas can accommo-
date an additional 20 to 30 vehicles per day for contractors.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   2-13      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                              3.0 MANAGEMENT OF SPECIFIC WASTE TYPES


The text to follow discusses the management of the following specific waste types:
             ·          Bulky wastes.                       ·   Compressed gas cylinders.
             ·          CFC-containing appliances.          ·   Other unacceptable wastes, including
             ·          Hot/smoldering loads.                   suspected hazardous wastes.
             ·          Infectious waste.                   ·   Special wastes.
             ·          Radioactive loads.


3.1        BULKY WASTE PROCEDURES
Because of the combustor feed chute width, FCCRWTE does not accept articles larger
than 6 ft in any dimension. However, the tipping floor operator can use discretion and
accept particular large items, such as sofas, that can be easily broken up with the loader
or crane. Rejected bulky wastes should be reloaded onto the delivery truck, if possible.
Bulky wastes discovered after the delivery truck has left should be placed in the bulky
waste roll-off or stored in a safe location on the tipping floor. Large metal objects such as
water heaters will be placed into the metals roll-off. Rejected bulky wastes will be dis-
posed of offsite. CFC-containing appliances will be handled and disposed of in accord-
ance with FCCRWTE CFC-containing appliance procedures.


3.2        CFC-CONTAINING APPLIANCE HANDLING PROCEDURES
CFCs are gasses that are in a liquid state when under pressure in an appliance. They are
generally colorless and odorless. CFCs were used as refrigerants in air conditioners,
freezers, refrigerators, heat pumps, water coolers, vending machines, and similar devices.
CFCs that escape into the atmosphere are harmful because they deplete the stratospheric
ozone layer. Although CFC production ceased on January 1, 1996, many CFC-containing
appliances are still in use.


Disposal of these appliances is controlled by environmental regulations to prevent CFC
releases. Strict compliance with this plan will insure FCCRWTE operates in accordance
with environmental regulations. The highlights of this plan are summarized in the follow-
ing subsections.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-1                     Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--062212
3.2.1           HANDLING CFC-CONTAINING APPLIANCES
Handle CFC-containing appliances as if they were undamaged and contained a full CFC
charge. Careful handling applies to all CFC-containing appliances, even appliances that
are damaged, have cut or punctured lines, or are missing refrigerant parts. If possible,
CFC-containing appliances should be carefully reloaded onto the delivery truck. If re-
loading the appliance is not possible, the appliance must be handled as follows:
                        The appliance is carefully moved to a secure area on or near the tipping
                        floor in a manner that protects the appliance's pressure parts (generally the
                        back or bottom) from further damage.
                        Careful handling may include the following:
                        o          Using a hand truck.
                        o          Gently pushing the appliance on its side or front with a front-end load-
                                   er bucket.
                        o          Carrying the appliance in the front-end loader bucket and unloading
                                   the bucket by hand or by gently tipping the bucket.


3.2.2           ONSITE CFC RECOVERY AND OFFSITE FINAL DISPOSAL
A U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)-certified technician using EPA-certified
equipment is used to inspect CFC-containing appliances and recover CFCs. Inspection
records and CFC recovery certificates are obtained from the CFC recovery technician
during each site visit.


FCCRWTE personnel ensure that the CFC recovery technician places a sticker on the
appliance confirming that it is free of CFCs. Placing a sticker on the appliances does not
replace the requirement for keeping the inspection and recovery records.


After obtaining inspection and recovery records certifying that the appliance is free of
CFCs, the appliance is placed in FCCRWTE's scrap metal bin. Careful handling re-
quirements no longer apply after the CFCs have been recovered, and crushing is permit-
ted.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.    3-2                      Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
Environmental regulations impose several recordkeeping requirements that will be ad-
dressed in a CFC management plan.


3.3        HOT LOAD PROCEDURES
The shift supervisor is immediately notified upon discovery of a truck with a load that is
smoldering, smoking, or burning. The shift supervisor instructs the control room operator
to call 911. The shift supervisor instructs the scale operator to have the driver of the hot
load drive off the scale and wait for further instructions. The tipping floor loader operator
begins to clear the tipping floor of any trucks and MSW as quickly as possible. The fol-
lowing information should be made available to the 911 operator:
                        Exact location of the emergency.
                        Telephone number from which the call is being made.
                        Caller's name.
                        Nature of the emergency (for example, a hot load has arrived at the plant).
                        MSW truck size and type.
                        Injuries (if any).
                        What the plant is doing to address the situation.
                        Other organizations FCCRWTE has notified.


A qualified person is designated to stand by at the front gate to assist in traffic control of
incoming and outgoing MSW trucks, maintaining a clear route for the fire trucks to the
tipping floor.


The shift supervisor instructs qualified firefighting personnel to suit-up in firefighting
turn-out gear and self-contained breathing apparatuses. Firefighting personnel will as-
semble outside the tipping floor on the access road.


The shift supervisor charges the tipping floor fire hose stations and has the firefighting
team lay out fire hose from the hose stations. The lead mechanic oversees the fire pump.
Once the tipping floor is clear of trucks and MSW, the hot load is directed to the tipping
floor.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-3                 Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
Depending on the severity of the hot load, the container of the truck may be doused with
a fog spray. The fuel tanks, oil tanks, hydraulic lines, tires, and parts of the truck needed
to keep it operational are monitored.


Once the fire department is on the site, all information is communicated to the onsite fire
department commander.


3.4        INFECTIOUS WASTE HANDLING PROCEDURES
FCCRWTE procedures for responding to suspected infectious waste deliveries are found
in the Facility exposure control plan for bloodborne pathogens, which also includes a pro-
tocol for handling discovered medical waste. Infectious waste must also be handled in
accordance with the state's infectious waste regulations. The following paragraphs pro-
vide an overview of policy and regulatory requirements.


An employee who discovers suspected infectious waste on the tipping floor must imme-
diately notify the shift supervisor. Suspected infectious waste includes bags from com-
mercial or institutional sources containing:
                        Syringes, bandages, culture dishes, etc.
                        Red bags.
                        Bags marked with the international biohazard symbol.


Bags marked with the biohazard symbol are presumed to be infectious wastes and must
be managed in accordance with FCCRWTE's bloodborne pathogens plan. Red bags or
other trash bags suspected of containing infectious wastes are investigated by the shift
supervisor to determine if they actually contain regulated infectious wastes. The tipping
floor loader operator and other hourly employees are not authorized to open bags of sus-
pected infectious wastes.


When conducting the investigation, the shift supervisor must wear the personal protective
equipment (PPE) specified under the exposure control plan for bloodborne pathogens
(i.e., rubber gloves, leather gloves, dust mask, uniform, safety boots, Tyvek® suit, safety

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-4                  Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
vest). Supervisors must not open bags with their hands. They will instead use tools, such
as rakes and barbeque tongs, to open bags and examine their contents.


If the bag(s) is marked with the biohazard symbol or if the shift supervisor determines
that the bag(s) is likely infectious wastes, then the bag(s) must be immediately placed in
the designated infectious waste bin on the tipping floor. Infectious waste is not to be re-
loaded into the garbage truck. Suspected infectious wastes are not to be handled with bare
hands. Tools that contact suspected infectious wastes must be decontaminated with
bleach after use, pursuant to the suspected infectious waste deliveries procedure.


Attempts must be made to determine the source of the infectious waste, either by inspec-
tion of other wastes in the bag, questioning the driver that delivered the waste, or both. If
identified, the generator must be contacted so they can retrieve the infectious wastes. If
the generator cannot be identified, the wastes should be disposed of through a registered,
licensed infectious waste disposal company.


3.5        RADIOACTIVE LOAD PROCEDURES
FCCRWTE is equipped with radiation detectors at the scale house to ensure radioactive
wastes are not accepted for disposal. The most likely radioactive materials present in the
MSW are medical radionuclides (e.g., in adult diapers). Loads that trigger the scale house
radiation alarm must be handled in accordance with FCCRWTE's radiation protection,
action, and monitoring plan. The following paragraphs briefly discuss the contents of the
plan. If a truck triggers the radiation alarm, FCCRWTE employees should consult the
radiation plan for detailed instructions.


In the event that a delivery triggers the radiation alarm, the following steps are taken:
                        Immediately notify the control room, which will notify the shift supervisor.
                        The shift supervisor must notify the operations manager and the EH&S
                        manager.
                        The shift supervisor (or designee) will direct the truck to approach the scale
                        again to insure the alarm was not false. The shift supervisor may also screen
                        the truck with a hand held detector.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-5                  Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        If the alarm is confirmed, the truck is directed to park in a designated, isolat-
                        ed holding area. The truck is not allowed on the tipping floor.
                        The driver is informed of the radiation alarm and asked to get out of the
                        truck to limit their potential radiation exposure.
                        The driver is informed that the truck must stay parked until the radioactive
                        material is recovered or the load is deemed not a threat. The driver is further
                        informed that the police will be called if attempt is made to exit the site be-
                        fore clearance is obtained.


The shift supervisor (or designee) will record the following information (as available) on
FCCRWTE's radiation detection report form:
                        Driver's name.
                        Trucking company name (or community).
                        Truck's license plate number.
                        Truck number assigned by FCCRWTE (decal number).
                        Time and date the load arrived at FCCRWTE.
                        Origin of the load.
                        Radiation detector reading(s).


The EH&S manager will notify the MDE Radiological Health Department and Solid
Waste Administration of the radioactive load per EH&S standard operating proce-
dure 0004. If the EH&S manager is unavailable, the notification will be made by the
plant manager, operations manager, or shift supervisor, who will provide the information
recorded by the shift supervisor.


3.6        COMPRESSED GAS CYLINDERS HANDLING PROCEDURES
Small propane tanks of the type used for barbeque grills are the most common type of
compressed gas cylinders found in MSW. Compressed gas bottles from households are
not considered hazardous wastes. Nevertheless, the cylinders might explode when heated
in the combustor/boiler and can potentially damage FCCRWTE equipment. Efforts must
be made to identify and remove compressed gas cylinders from the waste. If possible,


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-6                    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
compressed gas cylinders should be reloaded onto the delivery truck. If the delivery truck
cannot be identified, the cylinder should be securely stored to prevent damage. The cyl-
inder must be disposed of offsite.


However, other cylinders are also occasionally encountered. Compressed gas bottles from
commercial or institutional sources are potentially hazardous waste. These bottles must
be removed from the waste and, if possible, reloaded onto the truck that delivered them.
If the commercial or institutional generator cannot be determined, FCCRWTE may need
to manage the bottle as a hazardous waste. If this situation arises, FCCRWTE's EH&S
manager is contacted immediately.


3.7        SUSPECTED HAZARDOUS WASTES AND OTHER UNACCEPTABLE
           WASTES HANDLING PROCEDURES
In addition to the unacceptable wastes previously described, Facility permits and envi-
ronmental regulations also prevent FCCRWTE from accepting unburnable demolition
debris, motor vehicle parts, and hazardous wastes.


Usually the tipping floor loader operator can easily identify unacceptable waste. Occa-
sionally, suspicious waste may arrive on the tipping floor that is difficult to categorize.
Determining whether a particular waste is a hazardous waste can be especially difficult.
In these cases, the tipping floor loader operator is to consult with the EH&S manager
and/or shift supervisor to determine whether the waste will be accepted.


In general, rejected wastes are reloaded onto the delivery truck of origin. If the delivery
vehicle or generator cannot be identified, FCCRWTE takes possession of the waste and
must manage it properly. The unacceptable waste is removed to the designated area on
the tipping floor. The tipping floor loader operator immediately informs the shift supervi-
sor of the situation. If the rejected waste is a suspected hazardous waste, the shift supervi-
sor immediately notifies the EH&S manager. Notification of the Northeast Maryland
Waste Disposal Authority (NEA) will also be made.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-7         Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
Hazardous wastes are to be properly labeled, stored, and disposed. The EH&S manager
will advise operators on the requirements specific to the type of waste rejected. The event
is recorded into FCCRWTE's operating record or waste issues log, and MDE is notified
as appropriate.


MDE will be notified if an unacceptable solid waste is found to have been accepted at
FCCRWTE. MDE will be contacted immediately (within 24 hours) at (410) 337-3315, or
(866) 633-4868 after working hours, of all incidents of discovery of any unacceptable
solid wastes in a load of solid waste. MDE will be notified with a written report within
5 working days following discovery. If the source of waste is unknown, the written report
will include the circumstances of the discovery, a description of efforts to secure and con-
trol the solid waste and any release of pollutants from the solid waste, and current loca-
tion and final disposition of the solid waste.


3.8        SPECIAL WASTES HANDLING PROCEDURES
Special wastes are typically loads of a single waste type from a single source. Examples
of special waste include a truckload of off-specification consumer goods from a manufac-
turer or a drug burn for the local police department. FCCRWTE can only accept wastes
that are allowable under environmental regulations, FCCRWTE's permits, and the com-
pany's contract with the owner of the Facility. Special wastes might also pose handling
challenges. This O&M plan includes FCCRWTE's procedures for ensuring that banned
wastes are not accepted and special wastes are properly handled.


3.8.1           SPECIAL WASTES GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
Special wastes that meet the following criteria can be processed at FCCRWTE:
                        Waste must be compatible with FCCRWTE's equipment.
                        Waste must be capable of being safely processed and must not create a haz-
                        ard or nuisance on the tipping floor (e.g., waste that is too large for the com-
                        bustor feed chute).
                        Waste must be processible under environmental regulations and
                        FCCRWTE's permits.
                        Waste must not significantly affect air quality or ash content.

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-8                   Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
Special wastes must go through a formal evaluation before they are accepted at
FCCRWTE.


3.8.2          SPECIAL WASTES DELIVERY SCHEDULING
An approved special waste type code is assigned to each special waste customer, and the
customer uses this code to schedule loads. The special waste code allows FCCRWTE to
match each particular special waste to that waste's approval profile and also ensures
proper billing. Special waste shipments are to be scheduled with FCCRWTE before de-
livery using the Facility's preshipment notification document. After a delivery schedule is
established, the customer is to provide a list of the specific wastes that will be delivered.
This customer's list is checked against the wastes that FCCRWTE agrees to accept. The
waste is also inspected upon delivery to verify that the wastes have been previously ap-
proved by FCCRWTE.


3.8.3          SPECIAL WASTES CONTAINERS
FCCRWTE can typically accept bulk waste in roll-off containers, dump trailers, or box
trailers. Waste loads requiring direct feed are to be palletized and, if possible, delivered in
walking floor trailers. Waste delivery personnel are to comply with the tipping floor re-
quirements, and these requirements are to be discussed with delivery personnel before
they enter the tipping floor.


3.8.4          SPECIAL WASTES LOAD VERIFICATION
Waste delivered in roll-off containers and dump trailers is usually dumped into the tip-
ping floor for observation before being pushed into the pit. Visual observations are made,
and samples may be taken to verify the delivered waste conforms to the profile. If a waste
sample is taken, FCCRWTE does not typically wait for the results of the analysis before
disposing of the waste in the pit. Waste observations are documented on FCCRWTE's
random waste/special waste observation form.


Certain wastes, such as pharmaceuticals, may require more labor-intensive quality assur-
ance/quality control (QA/QC). Typically, a portion or all of the waste from such loads is

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-9          Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
directly fed into the combustor/boiler feed hopper and not pushed into the pit. The service
elevator or an auxiliary crane hoist may be used to deliver the waste to the combus-
tor/boiler feed hopper. Part of the QA/QC process is to identify each individually profiled
waste on the truck and handle them accordingly. This requires that nonbulk wastes be
properly labeled so they are readily identifiable during the unloading process.


3.8.5           NONCONFORMING SPECIAL WASTES
Special wastes that do not conform to their approved profile are rejected and sent back to
the customer. Every attempt is made to determine if the waste conforms with the profile
before the delivery vehicle is sent back. If the delivery vehicle has left FCCRWTE, the
customer may be required to arrange for a truck to return to FCCRWTE to pick up the
nonconforming wastes.


3.8.6           ASSURED DESTRUCTION PROCEDURES
There are two levels of assurance for special waste deliveries that require assured de-
struction. First, for less sensitive wastes, the generator may accept delivery of the waste
into the solid waste storage pit as verification of assured destruction. Second, for wastes
where a higher certainty of immediate destruction is required, the wastes can be lifted
from the tipping floor or carried through FCCRWTE and placed directly into the solid
waste feed hoppers. If the generator's representative requires visual confirmation that the
wastes have been fed into the combustor, they can be taken to the crane control room to
observe. If the generator or their designee needs to observe a lock or seal on the waste
shipment, then they must comply with tipping floor requirements.


3.8.7           SPECIAL WASTES RECORDKEEPING PROCEDURES
For special wastes accepted by FCCRWTE, the following records of each shipment are
kept for at least 5 years:
                        Waste profile sheet and supporting documentation.
                        Delivery date.
                        Waste generator's company name and address.
                        Waste description.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-10              Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        Weight of waste.
                        Additional information required by permit or regulatory approval.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   3-11               Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                                 4.0 MSW STORAGE AND PIT MANAGEMENT


4.1        NORMAL OPERATIONS
FCCRWTE's pit management strategy maintains the following objectives:
                        Plan for flow, control, and storage of incoming waste.
                        Provide adequate mixing of fuel feed to the boilers so fuel quality is as con-
                        sistent as possible.
                        Provide for safe operation by minimizing the risk of fire in the solid waste
                        storage pit and minimizing dust and overhead hazard exposures.
                        Provide for consistency in operations by standardizing methods of pit man-
                        agement among different operators.


Waste is normally stored in the pit only. During special or unusual circumstances, includ-
ing but not limited to, an unscheduled boiler outage or spring cleanups, waste deliveries
may exceed waste processing capacity and, therefore, will require storage of some waste
on the tipping floor. At least one bay is to be maintained open for waste receiving either
by depositing into the pit directly or in front of the pit for the loader to push the material
into the pit.


Waste may be stored on the tipping floor on a short-term basis as allowed FCCRWTE's
refuse disposal permit. During normal operation, waste may be present on the tipping
floor until room is available in the pit for the tipping floor loader operator to push it in.
Facility personnel ensure at all times that the temporary storage poses neither a threat to
health and safety nor the environment.


The waste in the pit is rotated on a biweekly basis. Therefore, on alternate weekends, the
waste in each end of the pit is to be mixed and managed for fuel feeding to prevent the
aging and decomposition of the waste within the storage pit. Control of the pit inventory
is required to ensure adequate rotation of the waste.


Tires that are contained in the MSW received or received as exclusive loads of tires are
dumped into the solid waste storage pit in the same fashion as other MSW received. In

Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-1                    Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
the event of multiple tires in a specific load, the tipping floor loader operator is to com-
municate with the crane operator to ensure there is a plan to bring tires to the top of the
receiving pile and mix them across the pile so as not to collect large stockpiles of tires in
the solid waste storage pit. Tires are then mixed in with the waste being fed to the com-
bustors in the course of normal operations.


Ash is taken to properly permitted landfills. The permits associated with these landfills
are to be modified by the landfill operators if required to allow the acceptance of the ash.
Appendix B includes a list of these permitted facilities.


Water from housekeeping and maintenance activities is collected in a building sump and
pumped back to the solid waste storage pit.


4.2        EMERGENCY OPERATIONS
Normally FCCRWTE has sufficient processing capacity to avoid extended storage of
waste on the tipping floor. However, emergency events may occur that severely limit
FCCRWTE's ability to process waste. Examples of this situation include:
                        Extended facilitywide power failure.
                        Early shutdown of a boiler prior to a cold iron event (i.e., a planned shut-
                        down of both boilers).
                        Extended shutdown of a boiler during a cold iron event.


Under these circumstances, the following steps are taken, as appropriate for the specific
situation, to ensure compliance with the short-term refuse storage limitations established
by FCCRWTE's refuse disposal permit:
                        An assessment is made of FCCRWTE's capacity to process and store MSW
                        within the limits established by its refuse disposal permit. Factors included
                        in this assessment include:
                        o          Current pit level.
                        o          Expected waste deliveries.
                        o          Expected duration of the emergency event.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   4-2                  Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        A determination is made if FCCRWTE can continue to operate within any
                        short-term storage limits without regulatory relief or implementing emer-
                        gency measures.
                        If it is determined that regulatory relief or emergency measures are neces-
                        sary, actions will be taken as follows:
                        o          A request is made to MDE in writing for an extension of the short-
                                   term storage limit.
                        o          If an extension is not granted, waste is then diverted using the follow-
                                   ing priority system:
                                             First: third-party deliveries.
                                             Second: municipalities.
                        The amount of waste diverted is to be based on the specific parameters of
                        the emergency (e.g., duration, if known).
                        Emergency measures are to remain in place until such time that FCCRWTE
                        can operate in compliance with the short-term storage limit.
                        Immediate steps are to be taken to abate the emergency conditions.


Short-term emergency diversion of solid waste is to be to other MSW disposal facilities,
as necessary. This includes other facilities under contract to or operated by the NEA,
Waste Management, or others.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.          4-3                Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                     5.0 SAFETY AND EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS PLANS


WTI has a corporate compliance program for safety and health, which each of its facili-
ties is required to implement to ensure compliance with applicable state and federal regu-
lations. These safety and health programs are customized based on the state in which the
facility operates. The corporate safety and health compliance programs are spelled out in
WTI's Corporate Health and Safety Plan, which includes sections on personal protective
equipment, hearing conservation, and respiratory projection (Appendix C).


FCCRWTE has implemented site-specific safety, emergency action and fire prevention,
and other emergency preparedness plans consistent with applicable federal and state
regulations. Since WTI already owns and operates a waste-to-energy facility in the state
of Maryland, the emergency action and fire prevention plan for FCCRWTE is expected to
be similar to the one for the existing WTI Baltimore facility. Requirements of local coun-
ty codes and ordinances will be incorporated into the plan.


The emergency preparedness plan for FCCRWTE addresses certain emergencies and
minimizes their impact on employees, the Facility, and Frederick County. The plan ad-
dresses various crises that may occur and the appropriate response to be taken. Emergen-
cy actions and mobilization procedures, chain of command for corrective action, outside
agency contact for assistance, and rapid response and deployment of needed resources
will all be addressed in the plan. The emergency preparedness plan contains the follow-
ing:
                        Scope of plan.
                        Basic policy.
                        Declaration of critical event and call list.
                        Response actions.
                        Handling of inquiries.
                        Personnel responsibilities.
                        General procedures.
                        Specific emergency procedures.


Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   5-1          Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
                        Fire, evacuation, and emergency telephone list.
                        Hurricane, flood, lightning, tornado, and other natural disasters.
                        Bomb threats.
                        Medical emergencies.
                        Demonstrations.


The emergency preparedness plan, coupled with the fire control and emergency evacua-
tion plan, will specify the roles and responsibilities for emergency situations and contin-
gencies. Employee preparedness is the key to successfully responding to emergency situ-
ations. Therefore, drills on the emergency situations will be practiced at least annually by
each FCCRWTE shift. Emergency drills will be scheduled. Records will be maintained
by the EH&S manager at FCCRWTE as required.


At this time, FCCRWTE's emergency contact information is:
             Mr. Jim Connolly
             Senior Manager, Environmental Permitting
             Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.
             4 Liberty Lane West
             Hampton, New Hampshire 03842
             Telephone: (603) 929-3267
             Mobile: (603) 686-1685
             www.wheelabratortechnologies.com




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   5-2                   Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
 OPERATIONS AND
MAINTENANCE PLAN

         APPENDIX A

FACILITY REPORTING STRUCTURE
                                                     APPENDIX A
                                           FACILITY REPORTING STRUCTURE


The operations manager and maintenance manager will report to the plant manager, who
is responsible for the overall operation and maintenance of the facility. In the absence of
the plant manager, the operations manager assumes plant manager duties. Health, safety,
and environmental issues are the responsibility of the health, safety manager and the en-
vironmental compliance manager, who will report to the group environmental health and
safety director and will be responsible for regular interaction with the plant manager and
operations team. the plant controller also reports to the plant manager.


MANAGEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION STAFFING
The plant manager will have overall responsibility for facility management and opera-
tions, regulatory compliance, contract obligations, health and safety, budgeting, capital
planning, personnel management, company reporting, customer and community relations,
long-range planning, and emergency response. The plant manager reports directly to
Wheelabrator's Regional Vice President.


The operations manager oversees team leaders to ensure reliable day-to-day operation in
a safe working environment: training, OSHA compliance, consistent facility perfor-
mance, and equipment operating requirements. Continuing education and training and
demonstration of technical competence will be part of the operations manager's job du-
ties.


The maintenance manager directs preventive maintenance protocols, equipment repairs,
and the computerized maintenance management system. Using the computerized mainte-
nance management system, the maintenance manager can monitor work orders, manage
mechanics and electrical and instrumentation personnel, perform contractor oversight
during outages, and perform QA/QC for scheduled and unscheduled maintenance.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   A-1             Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
The plant controller provides accounting, invoicing, and financial records oversight and
is responsible for assisting the plant manager with duties that include preparing and main-
taining all facility financial statements and coordinating the facility accounting functions.


The plant accounting and administrative support persons provide accounting and admin-
istrative support duties, which include general accounting support, accounts reconcilia-
tion, benefits administration, and office management along with other administrative
support functions such as completing reporting duties to NEA.


OPERATIONS STAFFING
Rotating shifts will be used to allow for continuous operations of the facility. The use of
rotating shifts has proven to be successful in allowing the employees to become familiar
with conditions on all shifts.


Shift operations for the plant will consist of six shifts. Each shift will be comprised of one
team leader, one plant operator, and two field operators. The six-shift rotation allows for
flexibility in scheduling where the fifth shift is used for relief coverage, preventive
maintenance and training.


Reporting to the operations manager, each team leader will be responsible for the safe,
continuous, proper operation of the plant. The team leader responds to situations ranging
from standard operating procedures to emergency response. They provide technical train-
ing, guidance, and direction to operations personnel; initiate work order requests to the
maintenance groups; perform emergency troubleshooting and repair of plant equipment;
and act as liaison between management and plant operations personnel.


Working under the direction of each team leader will be a plant operator. It will be the
plant operator's responsibility to operate the entire facility from the main control room
and direct the other operators in their daily tasks and in emergency situations. The plant
operator will have the qualifications to substitute for the team leader in the event of ill-
ness or other circumstances.



Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   A-2         Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
Each shift will have two field operators (FO). The FOs' responsibilities will include close
observation and operation of the boilers and auxiliaries, turbine generator, and auxiliaries.
FOs will also be responsible for operation of air pollution control equipment, ash han-
dling and dust control equipment, as well as crane operation. The purpose of having two
FOs is to allow for flexibility and maximize development potential of the operators. As
experience is gained in the field, the FOs will also be trained as relief control room opera-
tors.


In addition to the shift operators, there will be additional day staff to support the shift in
routine repairs, preventive maintenance, and continuous operations. These teams will
have full complements to handle relief coverage, ash house load-out, and weighbridge
operations duties to ensure only authorized vehicles are permitted across the weighbridge.
They are fully involved in the day-to-day operations as well as outage support. During
the busiest time of the refuse receiving hours, the FOs will be assigned to the second
crane to maintain a clear dumping area in the pit accommodating incoming truck traffic.


The loader operators maintain a clear tipping floor area, moving trash for identifying and
segregating nonprocessible waste for subsequent disposal. The loader operator also di-
rects the refuse trucks as to where to dump their loads and screens out unacceptable waste
from the waste stream.


MAINTENANCE STAFFING
The maintenance staff, working under the direction of the maintenance manager, consists
of electrical and instrumentation (E&I) technicians and mechanics. These groups are co-
ordinated to conduct the day-to-day routine and emergency maintenance work required to
operate the facility continuously.


The maintenance team performs most equipment repair, preventive maintenance, and
outage work, such as turbine/generator overhaul and major equipment replacement, and
will direct supplemental maintenance contractor and specialty contractor assistance.




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   A-3         Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912
The E&I group reports to the maintenance manager. E&I technicians perform routine and
emergency repairs, as well as preventive maintenance, on electrical equipment and in-
strumentation.


There are mechanics that will work day shift in conjunction with the shift personnel and
report to the maintenance manager. Mechanics perform routine and emergency repairs as
well as preventive maintenance on all mechanical and piping systems.


The operational staffing structure described herein provides for holiday, vacation, and
sick time coverage of operating staff personnel. Maintenance policies ensure that person-
nel are identified and scheduled to be on-call in the case of plant emergencies or off-
hours maintenance requirements.


EMERGENCY CONTACTS
Emergency contact names of facility management and telephone numbers will be deter-
mined when the plant is constructed and these positions are filled. A table of emergency
contact information will be prepared and made available prior to the plant start-up.


At this time, FCCRWTE's emergency contact information is:
             Mr. Jim Connolly
             Senior Manager, Environmental Permitting
             Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.
             4 Liberty Lane West
             Hampton, New Hampshire 03842
             Telephone: (603) 929-3267
             Mobile: (603) 686-1685
             www.wheelabratortechnologies.com




Printed on FSC 100-percent postconsumer recycled paper.   A-4       Y:\GDP-12\WHEEL\O&M.DOCX--061912

1.         PURPOSE
            This procedure is designed to ensure the protection of all wn employees from
            respiratory hazards by reducing their exposure to occupational air contaminants and
            oxygen deficiency through proper selection and use of respirators. This program is in
            accordance with the requirements of OS II A 29 CFR 1910.134 and 1926.103.

            o    Air-Purifying                       A respirator with an air-purifying filter, cartridge, or
                 Respirator                          canister that removes specific air contaminants by pass-
                                                     ing ambient air through the air-purifying element
            o    Assigned Protection                 The workplace lcvel of respiratory protection that a
                 Factor (APF)                        respirator or class ofrespirators is expected to provide to

                                                     tion of these items, which removes specific contaminants
                                                     from the air passed through the container.
            o    End-Of-Scrvice-Lifc                 A system that warns the respirator user of the approach
                 Indicator (ESU)                     of the cnd of adequate respiratory protection, for
                                                     example, that the sorbent is approaching saturation or is
                                                     no longer effective.
            o    Filtering Face picce                A negative pressure particulate respirator with a filter as
                 (Dust Mask)                         an integral part of the face piece or with the entire face
                                                     piece composed of the filtering medium.
            o    Fit Factor                          A quantitative estimate of the fit of a particular respirator
                                                     to a specific individual, and typically estimates the ratio
                                                     of the concentration of a substance in ambient air to its
                                                     concentration inside the respirator when worn.
            o    Fit Test                            The use of a protocol to qualitatively or quantitatively
                                                     evaluate the fit of a respirator on an individuaL (See also
                                                     Qualitative fit test and Quantitative fit test.)

                 Particulate Air                     monodisperse particles of 0.3 micrometers in diameter.
                 (HEPA) filter                       The equivalent NIOSH 42 CFR 84 particulate filters arc
                                                     the Nl 00, RIOO, and PlOD filters.

                 Dangerous To Life Or                would cause irreversible adverse health effects, or would
                 Health (JD LH)                      impair an individual's ability to escape from a dangerous
                                                     atmosphere.
