4.          RESPONSIBILITmS
                4.1   Plant Manager
                      4.1.1       Has primary responsibility for the execution of the Respiratory Protection
                                  Program within the facility.
                      4.1.2       Ensure employees are trained m the hazards and requirements of the
                                  Respiratory Protection Prognllll.
                      4.1.3Notify OHS Management of any changes in chemicals, controls,
                           environment or processes that would necessitate reevaluation of the
                           Respiratory Protection Program.
                4.2   OHS Management

                      4.2.1       Has Primary responsibility as the identified program administrator for
                                  establishment, implementation and maintenance of the Respiratory
                                  Protection Program.
                      4.2.2       The duties of Program Administrator include at minimum thosc listed
                                  below:

                                           ·   Responsible for development of the Respiratory Protection
                                               Program, including contaminant identification and measurement,
                                               ensuring the availability of technical support, air sampling, and
                                               laboratory analysis, selection, issuance, training and fit testing of
                                               respirators, and record keeping.

                                           ·   Has authority to make necessary decisions to ensure success of the
                                               program, including hiring vendors and purchasing equipmcnt
                                               necessary to implement and operate the program.

                      4.3.1      Modify JHAs where necessary, as Industrial Hygiene results are obtained.

                             materials, evaluating procedures and observing employee work practices
                             to ensure the respiratory program is being effectively implemented.
             4.4      Supervisors

                      4.4.1      Direct and evaluate employees in the implementation of the respiratory
                                 protection program.


5.          PROCEDURE
            5.1       INTRODUCTION
                      While this procedure describes respirator usage in detail, as a general principle
                      respirators are to be used only:
                          · When engineering control of respiratory hazards or work practices are not
                              feasible to reduce exposures;
                          · While engineering controls are being installed; or
                          · In emergencies.

            5.2       EXPOSURE ASSESSMENTS

                      5.2.1      To ensure proper respirator selection, exposure assessments will be
                                 conducted for each employee or representative employee job classification,
                                 initially before first exposure and periodically thereafter, to identify tasks
                                 and areas with potential respiratory exposures and associated exposure
                                 levels, particularly those with exposures above the PEL.

                  1                            Respiratory Protection Program                                                         6 of 23

                      5.2.2      Exposure          assessments           shall      be     conducted          in     accordance           with

                                 Exposure assessment data is maintained in the Corp Med Db.
                      5.2.3      bppcnclix B- When to wear a respiratory at a WTI plant, reflects the
                                 requirements identified based upon industrial hygiene sampling and the
                                 resulting exposure assessment conducted by the company.
                      5.2.4      Exposures shall be re-evaluated when:

                                           ·   There is a change in the process, materials, equipment, personnel,
                                               work practices, or control methods that may result in new or
                                               additional cxposures.

                                           ·   As required by OSHA substance specific standards.

                                           ·   At least annually.
                      5.2.5      If after the exposure re-evaluation, respiratory protection is still required,
                                 respirator selections will also be reviewed to assure their continued
                                 suitability.

            5.3       MEDICAL SURVEILLANCE EVALUATIONS

                      5.3.1      All non-administrative Whcclabrator employees shall participate in the
                                 Medical Surveillance Program as described in the Occupational Health
                                 and Medical Program Manual.
                      5.3.2      Medical surveillance, evaluations and respirator approvals shall be
                                 conducted as specitied in the WTI Medical Survcillance Program.
                      5.3.3      Employees may not wear required respiratory protection without a current
                                 respirator approval as identified in the Corp Med db.

            5.4       RESPIRATOR SELECTION

                      5.4.1      Respiratory protection is provided at no cost to the employees.
                      5.4.2      The following criteria are used in selecting respiratory protection:
                                           ·   Respirators are selected and provided based on the respiratory
                                               hazard(s) to which a worker is exposed, and workplace and user
                                               factors that affect respirator performance and reliability. The
                                               selection is based upon the physical and chemical properties of the
                                               air contaminants and the concentration level likely to be
                                               encountered by the employee.

                                                                    C-6
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                           Page #:

                1                             Respiratory Protection Program                                                        7 of 23

                                          ·   All respirators shall be NIOSH-certified.
                                          ·   Type and manufacturer of respiratory protection shall be
                                              pre-approved by OBS Management prior to purchase.
                                          ·   Respiratory hazard( s) are identified and evaluated in the
                                              workplace, including a reasonable estimate of employee exposures
                                              to respiratory hazard(s) and an identification of the contaminant's
                                              chemical state and physical form. If the exposure levels cannot be
                                              identified or reasonably estimated, the atmosphere shall be
                                              considered to be immediately dangerous to life or health (IDLH).
                                          ·   Respirators shall be selected from a sufficient number of respirator
                                              models and sizes so that the respirator is acceptable to, and
                                              correctly fits, the user.
                                          ·   Respirators selected for use with potential high temperature
                                              exposure such as fire or are flash shall be NFP A 1971 rated by the
                                              manufacturer.
                                          ·   See L1.!2.!lcndix B When to Wear a Respirator for list ofrespiratory
                                              selection requirements.
                                                ·   Contact OBS Management for areas not covered.
                      5.4.3      General Requirements
                                 Routine Use
                                          ·   Only NIOSH-certified respirators are selected and used. Where
                                              practicable, the respirators will be assigned to individual workers
                                              for their exclusive use.
                                          ·   Respirators assigned to higher protection factor (APF) classes may
                                              be used for lower class exposures.
                                          ·   A full-face respirator is required when a potential eye irritation
                                              hazard exists.
                                          ·   Corrective lens inserts are required for persons needing vision
                                              correction.
                                          ·   Supplied air respirators arc required when:
                                                  o A gas or vapor has an odor threshold below the PEL/TL V
                                                  o Welding, cutting or heating beryllium in an enclosed space
                                 Emergency Use
                                          ·   Only self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) which can be
                                              operated in the pressure-demand mode are acceptable for
                                              emergency usc.
                                          ·   All SCBAs within a facility should be of the same type to avoid
                                              employee confusion and equipment incompatibility problems
                                              during emergency situations.

                1                             Respiratory Protection Program                                                          8 of 23

                                          ·   Facility SCBAs should be of the same manufacturer as those used
                                              by the local fIre department to avoid equipment incompatibility
                                              problems during emergency situations.
                                          o   SCBA options should be considered based upon intended use, as
                                              described below:
                                                  o Type C airline connections or high-pressure (4500 psi 60-
                                                      minute) cylinders for extended operations
                                                  o Buddy-breathing comlcctions for extended escape pathways
                                                  o Fill-on-the-fly connections for refilling cylinders without
                                                      the need to remove the face piece or go through
                                                      decontamination to change cylinders
                                                  o Composite cylinders (light weight) for reduced physical
                                                      strain and improved maneuverability
                                                  o Communications gear (voice amplifiers or radio
                                                      microphones) for improved verbal communications

                      5.4.4      Requircments for IDLH Atmospheres
                                 The following respiratory protection shall be provided for !DLH
                                 atmospheres:
                                    o Full face piece pressure demand self-contained breathing apparatus
                                        (SCBA) certified by NIOSH for a minimum service life of thirty
                                        minutes, or
                                    o A combination full face piece pressure demand supplied-air
                                        respirator.
                                    o Self-contained breathing apparatus (SAR) with auxiliary self·
                                        contained air supply.
                                    o NIOSH-certified respirators for escape (when they are used only
                                        for escape fromlDLH atmospheres).
                                    · All oxygen-deficient atmospheres shall be considered to be IDLH.

                      5.4.5      Requirements for Non-IDLH Atmospheres
                                 The following respiratory protection shall be provided for non-IDLH
                                 atmospheres:
                                    o Respirators shall be adequate to protect the health of the employee
                                       and ensure compliance with all other OSHA statutory and
                                       regulatory requirements, under routine and reasonably foreseeable
                                       emergency situations.

                                                                    C-8
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                            Page #:

                  1                           Respiratory Protection Program                                                         9 of 23

                                          ·   Respirators shall meet or exceed the required level of employee
                                              protection by using the assigned protection factors (APFs) listed in
                                              19J 0. 134 Table I" Sec AppcndilLC -Assigned Protection Factors.
                                                  o For combination respirators (e.g., airline respirators with an
                                                      air-purifyiug filter) the APF must be appropriate to the
                                                      mode of operation in which the respirator is being used.
                                          ·   Respirators shall maintain the employee's exposure to the
                                              hazardous substance at or below the maximum use concentration
                                              (MUC), when measured outside the respirator.
                                                  o MUCs shall be not be applied to conditions that are
                                                      immediately dangerous to life or health (IDLH); instead
                                                      respirators shall be used that are listed for ID LIf conditions.
                                                  o MUCs shall be set at the lower limit when the calculatcd
                                                      MUC exceeds the IDLH level for a hazardous substance or
                                                      the performance limits of the eartridge or canister.
                                          ·   Respirators shall be appropriate for the chemieal state and physical
                                              form of the contaminant
                                 For protection against gases and vapors, provide:
                                          ·   An atmosphere-supplying respirator, or
                                          ·   An air-purifying respirator, provided that:
                                                 o The respirator is equipped with an end-of-service-life
                                                     indicator (ESLI) certified by NIOSH for the contaminant;
                                                     or
                                                 o If there is no ESLI appropriate for conditions in our
                                                     workplace, implement a change schedule for canisters and
                                                     cartridges that is based on objective information or data that
                                                     will ensure that cani sters and cartridges are changed beiore
                                                     the end of their service life.
                                          ·   Sec Appendix D End Of Service Life and Cartridge Change
                                              Schedule.
                                For protection against particulates, provide:
                                          ·   An atmosphere-snpplying respirator; or
                                          ·   An air-purifying respirator equipped with a filter certified by
                                              NIOSH as a high efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filter, or an air-
                                              purifying respirator equipped with a filter certified for particulates
                                              by NIOSH under 12 Cf~R 84; or
                                          ·   For contaminants consisting primarily of particles with mass
                                              median aerodynamic diameters (MMAD) of at least 2 micrometers,
                                              an air-purifying respirator equipped with any filter certified for
                                              particulates by NIOSH.

                  1                           Respiratory Protection Program                                                           10      of   23
            5.5       CARTRIDGE/FILTER SELECTION

                      5.5.1      Cartridges shall be chosen that are specifically rated for all anticipated
                                 substances that have an assigned PEL (i.e., a PEL of 50 ug/m3 or higher).
                                 In cases where protection from multiple contaminants is necessary, be sure
                                 the cartridge or filter is rated for each contaminant and can handle the
                                 maximum anticipated concentration of each substance.
                      5.5.2      Ensure that all filters, cartridges and canisters used in the workplace are
                                 labeled and color-coded with the NIOSH approval label and that the label
                                 is not removed and remains legible.

            5.6       FIT TESTING
                      Fit testing is performed to ensure respiratory protection fits properly and provides
                      effective protection. Quantitative fit testing is required annually unless authorized
                      by OHS Management. Fit testing records are maintained in the Corp Med Db and
                      are entered by the facility for each respirator assigned to the cmployee.
                      5.6.1      The test shall not be conducted if there is any hair growth between the skin
                                 and the face piece scaling surface, such as stubblc beard growth, beard,
                                 mustache or sideburns which cross the respirator sealing surface. Any type
                                 of apparel which interferes with a satisfactory fit shall be altered or
                                 removed.                   - Facial Hair Guidance.
                      5.6.2      Employees shall be fit tested with the same make, model, style, and size of
                                 respirator that will be worn. Fit testing shall be conducted at the followiug
                                 frequencies:
                                          ·   Before employees are required to use any respirator with a negative
                                              or positive pressure tight-fitting face piece.
                                          ·   Whenever a different respirator face piece (size, style, model, or
                                              make) is used.
                                          ·   Whenever the employee reports, or when a physician, other
                                              licensed health care professional, or site management makes visual
                                              observations of changes in the employee's physical condition that
                                              could affect respirator fit. Such conditions include, but are not
                                              limited to, facial scarring, dental changes, cosmetic surgery, or an
                                              obvious ehange in body weight.
                                          ·   When the employee, subsequently after passing a QLFT or QNFT,
                                              reports that the fit of the respirator is unacceptable. That employee
                                              shall be re-tested with a different respirator face piece.
                                          ·   At least annually.

                                                                   C-10
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                            Page #:

                  1                           Respiratory Protection Program                                                         11 of 23

                      5.6.3      Employees shall pass one of the following lit test types that follow the
                                 protocols and procedures contained in £!~C!S~Ul'.c.!c2±m1illTh'l'Lii:
                                          ·   Quantitative Fit testing (QNFT) -- TSI PortaCount is the preferred
                                              method for all testing. May be used to fit test a tight-fitting half
                                              face piece respirator that must achieve a fit factor of 100 or greater
                                              OR a tight-fitting full face piece respirator that must achieve a fit
                                              factor of 500 or greater OR tight-fitting atmosphere-supplying
                                              respirators and tight-fitting powered air-purifying respirators if
                                              tested in the negative pressure mode.
                                          ·   Qualitative Fit Testing (QLFT) -- Bitrex is the recommended
                                              method. Only used to fit test negative pressure air-purifying
                                              respirators that must achieve a fit factor of 100 or less. May be
                                              used to test tight-fitting atmosphere-supplying respirators and tight-
                                              fitting powered air-purifying respirators if tested in the negative
                                              pressure mode.

            5.7       PROPER USE PROCEDURE
                      Once the respirator has been properly selected and litted, its protection efficiency
                      must be maintained by proper usc.

                      5.7.1      General Requirements

                                 All work involving airborne hazards shall be conducted in accordance with
                                 the Respiratory Protection Program.
                                 Respirators shall be wom:
                                          ·   Regnlated areas and tasks are those areas and tasks listed in
                                              Appendix B, that have been identified as having a reasonable
                                              potential to exceed OSHA permissible exposure limits (PELs)
                                              (such as Lead, Inorganic Arsenic, Cadmium or Chrome(VI) ) based
                                              on exposure detenninations consisting of IH monitoring, biological
                                              monitoring and medical surveiIlance.
                                          ·   As per the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) or mannfacturers'
                                              recommendations
                                          ·   As per JHAs and whenever instructed by supervisors
                                 All personnel required to wear a respirator shall not have any facial hair or
                                 allow any other condition including correetive glasses or other personal
                                 protective equipment that will interfere with the skin-to-respirator sealing
                                 surface contact or interfere with the inhalation or exhalation valve
                                 operation.

                1                             Respiratory Protection Program                                                         12 of 23
                                 Defective respirators, cartridges or filters shall not be used,
                                 Respirators shall never be taken off in hazardous environments,
                                 Users of tight-fitting respirators shall perfonn a user seal check each time
                                 they put on the respirator using the procedures in 29 eFR 19lO,134
                                                                                   (for easy reference these
                                 procedures are replicated in Appendix E of this Respiratory Protection
                                 Program document),
                                 Employees shall leave a respirator-required area or task and notify their
                                 Supervisor under any of the following conditions:
                                          ·   Upon malfunction of the respirator
                                          ·   Upon detection of leakage of contaminant into the respirator
                                          ·   If increased breathing resistance of the respirator is noted
                                          ·   If severe discomfort or physical stress in wearing the respirator is
                                              detected
                                          ·   Upon illness of the respirator wearer, including: sensation of
                                              dizziness, nausea, weakness, breathing difficulty, coughing,
                                              sneezing, vomiting, fever and chills
                                          ·   To wash face to prevent skin irritation
                                          ·   To change filter/cartridge elements or replace respirators whenever
                                              they detect the warning properties of the contaminant or increased
                                              breathing resistance

                      5,7,2      Procedures for IDLH Atmospheres
                                 One "standby" employee using the Buddy System or, when needed, more
                                 than one employee shall be located outside the IDLH atmosphere,
                                 Visual, voice, or signal line communication shall be maintained between
                                 the employee(s) in the IDLH atmosphere and the employee(s) located
                                 outside the IDLH atmosphere,
                                 The employee(s) located outside the IDLH atmosphere shall be trained and
                                 equipped to provide effective emergency rescue,
                                 The employer or designee shall be notified before the employee(s) located
                                 outside the IDLH atmosphere enter the IDLH atmosphere to provide
                                 emergency rescue,
                                 The employer or designee authorized to do so by the company, once
                                 notified, provides necessary assistance appropriate to the situation,

                 1                             Respiratory Protection Program                                                          13      of 23

                                  Standby cmployee(s) located outside the IDLH atmospheres shall be
                                  equipped with pressure demand or other positive pressure self-contained
                                  breathing apparatuses (SCBAs), or a pressure demand or other positive
                                  pressure supplied-air respirator with auxiliary SCBA; and either:
                                           ·   Appropriate retrieval equipment for removing the employee(s) who
                                               enter(s) these hazardous atmospheres; or
                                           ·   Equivalent means for rescue where retrieval equipment would not
                                               contribute to the rescue of the employee(s) and would increase the
                                               overall risk resulting from entry.
                                  Interior Structural Firefighting
                                           ·   In addition to the requirements set forth above for procedures for
                                               IDLH atmospheres, when trained fire brigade members respond to
                                               interior structural fires:
                                                   o At least two employees shall enter the IDLH atmosphere
                                                       and remain in visual or voice contact with one another at all
                                                       times;
                                                   o At least two employees shall be located outside the IDLH
                                                       atmosphere; and
                                                   o All employees engaged in interior structural firetighting
                                                       shall usc SCBAs.
                                           ·   One of the two individuals located outside the IDLI-I atmosphere
                                               may be assigned to an additional role, such as incident commander
                                               in charge of the emergency or safety officer, so long as this
                                               individual is able to perfonn assistance or rescue activities without
                                               jeopardizing the safety or health of any firefighter working at the
                                               incident.
                                           ·   Nothing in this section is meant to preclude firefighters from
                                               perfonning emergency rescue activities before an entire team has
                                               assembled.
                                           ·   Fire- and chemical-resistant harnesses (i.e., Nomex, Kevlar, PBI)
                                               are required for use in areas where these hazards will be
                                               encountered.
                                       ·       A minimum of one spare cylinder per SCBA shall be available.
                                       ·       Nose cups installed in face pieces prevent ice fogging of faee piece
                                               lenses and are required when specified by the manufacturers'
                                               SCBAs ifused below 32°F.

            5.8       MAINTENANCE AND CARE PROCEDURES

                      Respirators shall be inspected, cleaned, stored, and maintained in accordance with
                      the manufacturers' requirements and at the frequencies noted below in order to
                      maintain their effectivencss.

                      5.8 J      Inspection
                                 In order to assure the continned reliability of respiratory equipment, it
                                 must be inspected on a regular basis. The frequency of inspection is related
                                 to thfi
                                      e requency ot'   R
                                                      use.    '
                                                            eSplrators shllb'
                                                                         a e mspected as fll  0 ows:

                                     Respirator type ~~ Inspection Frequencies
                                     All types used in                   Before each usc and during cleaning by users.
                                     routine situations                  Monthly by supervisors.
                                     (except filtering
                                     face pieces/dust                    (Filtering face pieces/dust masks _. before use
                                     masks                               only)
                                     Respirators                         At least monthly and in accordance with the
                                     maintained for use                  manufacturer's recommendations, and checked
                                     in emergency                        for proper function before and after each use
                                     situations

                      5.8.2      Cleaning & Disinfecting
                                 Each respirator user shall ensure the respirator is clean, sanitary, and in
                                 good working order before use. The respirators shall be cleaned and
                                 disinfected in accordance with the manufacturer's requirements and as
                                 follows'
                                     Respirator type                     Cleaned and disinfected at the following
                                                                         intervals
                                     Issued for the                      As often as necessary to be maintained in a
                                     exclusive use of an                 sanitary condition
                                     employee
                                     Issued to more than                 Before being worn by different individuals
                                     one employee
                                     Maintained for                      After each use
                                     emergency use
                                     Used in fit testing                 After each use
                                     and training

                      5.8.3      Storage
                                 Respirators shall be stored in sealed bags or containers to ensure that the
                                 respirator is protected to prevent defonnation of the face piece and
                                 exhalation valve, and not subject to environmental conditions that may
                                 cause deterioration including damage, contamination, dust, sunlight,
                                 extreme temperatures, excessive moisture, and damaging chemicals.
                                 Emergency respirators shall be kept accessibl e to the work area; stored in
                                 compartments and covers that are clearly marked as containing emergency
                                 respirators; and in accordance with any applicable mauufacturer
                                 instructions.
                      5.8.4      Repairs
                                 Repairs or adjustments to respirators are to be made only by persons
                                 appropriately trained to perfonTI such operations and only with the
                                 rcspirator manufacturer's NIOSH-approved parts designed for the
                                 respirator. Repairs shall be made according to the manufacturer's
                                 recommendations and speci fications for the type and extent of repairs to be
                                 perfonned.
                                 Adjustment or repair of reducing and admission valves, regulators, or
                                 alanns shall only be perfonned by the manufacturer.
                      5.8.5      Discarding of Respirators
                                 Respirators that fail an inspection or are otherwise found to be defective
                                 shall be removed from service, and tagged as "Defective-Do Not Use" or
                                 similar wording. Respirators shall then be discarded, repaired, or adj usted
                                 as detcnnined by supervision.
                                 Discarded respirators or dust masks (filtering face pieces) shall not be
                                 thrown on the floor or otherwise improperly discarded and shall
                                 immediately be disposed of by placement in a trash receptacle.

            5.9       AIR QUALITY PROCEDURES
                      When atmosphere-supplying respirators are being used to protect employees it is
                      essential to ensure that the air being breathed is of sufficiently high quality. The
                      following requirements ensure adequate air quality, quantity, and flow of
                      breathing air for atmosphere-supplying respirators.
                      5.9.1      Compressed Air, Compressed Oxygen, Liquid Air, and Liquid Oxygen
                                 Used for Respirators
                                 Compressed and liquid oxygen shall meet the United                                                   States
                                 Phannacopoeia requirements for medical or breathing oxygen.


                  HARD COPY IS co;\'smER[n f{[fERE:"CE O:\LY, 'VERiFY REVISiO:\ I,\: O-BOX BEFORE CSE

proprietary and all rights are reserved. Any submission is in a spirit of confidence and acceptance is deemed to be an acknowledgment of the
confidential relationship. fnfonnation contained hereon not lawfully obtained from another source shaH not be released, duplicated, used or
disclosed in whole or in part for any procurement or manufacturing purpose without the prior wTitten pennission of the president, \Vheelabrator

Revision:                        Title:                                                                                            Page #:

                 1                            Respiratory Protection Program                                                         16      of   23
                                 Compressed breathing air shall meet at least the requirements for Grade D
                                 breathing air described in ANSI/Compressed Gas Association Commodity
                                 Specification for Air, G-7.1, to include:
                                          ·   Oxygen content (v/v) of 19.5-23.5%
                                          ·   Hydrocarbon (condensed) content of 5 milligrams per cubic meter
                                              of air or less
                                          ·   Carbon monoxide (CO) content of 10 parts per million (ppm) or
                                              less
                                          ·   Carbon dioxide content of 1,000 ppm or less
                                          ·   Lack of a noticeable odor
                                 Ensure that compressed oxygen is not used in atmosphere-supplying
                                 respirators that have previously used compressed air.
                                 Ensure that oxygen concentrations greater than 23.S% are used only in
                                 equipment designed for oxygen service or distributiou.

                      S.9.2      Cylinders Used to Supply Breathing Air to Respirators
                                 Cylinders shall be tested and maintained as prescribed in the Shipping
                                 Container Specification Regulations of the Department of Transportation
                                 \=.201..-'.c.c'-'''- and 171\).

                                 Cylinders containing breathing air shall be refilled or purchased from
                                 approved vendors only, and shall have a certificate of analysis JI'om the
                                 supplier that the breathing air for those cylinders meets the requirements
                                 for Grade D breathing air.
                                 The moisture content in the cylinder shall not exceed a dew point of -so
                                 deg. F (-4S.6 deg. C) at I atmosphere pressure.
                      S.9.3      Compressors
                                 Ensure that compressors used to supply breathing air to respirators are
                                 constructed and situated so as to:
                                          ·   Prevent entry of contaminated air into the air-supply system
                                          ·   Minimize moisture content so that the dew point at I atmosphere
                                              pressure is 10 degrees F (S.S6 deg. C) below the ambient
                                              temperature
                                          ·   Have suitable in-line air-purifYing sorbent beds and filters to
                                              further ensure breathing air quality. Sorbcnt beds and filters shall
                                              be maintained and replaced or refurbished periodically following
                                              the manufacturer's instructions

                                 Air supplied from an air compressor system will be tested/certified
                                 quarterly to assure that Grade D breathing air requirements are met.
                                 Carbon Monoxide monitors on breather boxes must be calibrated monthly
                                 or as required by manufacturer.
                                 For compressors that are not oil-lubricated, ensure that carbon monoxide
                                 levels in the breathing air do not exceed 10 ppm.
                                 For oil-lubricated compressors, use a high-temperature or carbon
                                 monoxide alarm, or both, to monitor carbon monoxide levels. If only high-
                                 temperature alarms are used, the air supply shall be monitored at intervals
                                 sufficient to prevent carbon monoxide in the breathing air trom exceeding
                                 10 ppm.
                      5.9.4      Breathing Air Couplings
                                 Ensure that breathing air couplings are incompatible with outlets for non-
                                 repairable worksite air or other gas systems. No asphyxiating substance
                                 shall be introduced into breathing air lines.
                      5.9.5      Breathing Gas Containers
                                 Use breathing gas containers marked in accordance with the NIOSH
                                 respirator certification standard, "",_"''--'''-..'1.:!'

APPENDIXJ;J .... WHENTOWEAR Ii.. RESPIRATOR
                       (MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS)
OVERVIEW
1)     Always obey Supervisors instructions and postings.
2)     Inhalation of all respiratory hazards, including particulates, dusts, fumes, mists, gases, and vapors should be avoided. Use local
       ventilation whenever possible.
3)     Consult your Supervisor with questions on requirements not identified below, such as Powered Air Purifying Respirators (PAPRs) and
       Supplied Air Respirators (SARs)
4)     Consult MSDSs, manufacturer's instructions, JHAs, or your supervisor for respiratory protection requirements when working with specific
       products or materials.
5)     You must be fit·tested to use filtering facepleces (dust masks) if conducting REGULATED TASKS or working in REGULATED AREAS
       listed below, (Areas where exposure to airborne concentrations of hazardous substances such as lead, cadmium, inorganic arsenic,
       chromium VI, or silica do, or can reasonably be expected to exceed an OSHA PEL)
6)     DO NOT USE NIRlP-95 or NfRlP-99 rated respirators for conducting for any of the REGULATED AREAS or TASKS listed below:
7)     These are minimum requirements - there may be additional or more stringent site-specific requirements based on IH monitoring data or
       management determinations as identified by task specific JHAs.
               Additional requirements in accordance with WOHS«1910,Subpart-Z L IA C CR Exposure Control, exposure control plan, WTI safety
               rules book and JHAs are also required including:
                           Protective apparel
                            PPE
                           Postings
                           Restricted Access
                           Persona! hygiene (hand and face washing, showering)
                           Safe work practice
8)     Regulated areas and tasks as identified below shall be posted in accordance with WOHS-1910.Subpart·Z L fA C CR Exposure Control
       section 5.5.3.
               Regulated areas include entrances to:
                           ESP
                           Baghouses
                           Boilers, flue gas duct work
               Regulated tasks
                           Hot work on chromium containing materials including stainless steel



             FULL-FACE
      1)     Working in any Electrostatic Precipitator (ESP) or bag house
      2)     Working in any unwashed/un-cleaned boiler or associated flue gas duct work (Does not apply to "inspec-
             tion-only" activities)
      3)     Performing Hot Work (welding, cutting, grinding or brazing} in an MSW boiler, MSW associated ductwork,
             or MSW ash area
Use Combination Multi-gas iVapor AND , . ,                                        ,I',       I      "
'Includes Organic vapors and particulates, chlorine, hydrogen chloride, sulfur dioxide, chlorine dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, ammonia, methylamine, formaldehyde or hydro.
gen fluoride
      1)     When exposed to potential splash hazards while unloading or supervising the unloading of the following
             bulk liquid chemical deliveries (tanker trucks or totes}:
                  a, Acid, including sulfuric and phosphoric
                  b, Caustic (Sodium Hydroxide)
                  c. Bleach (Sodium Hypochlorite)
                  d. Ammonia
      2)     For spills, releases, and emergencies where fumes, vapors, or mists are being generated follow the respira-
             tory protection requirements as described in the site's approved spill prevention plan or use SCBAs if condi-
             tions are unknown

Assigned Protection Factors (APFs). Use the assigned protection factors listed in Table I to
select a respirator that meets or exceeds the required level of employee protection. When using a
combination respirator (e.g., airline respirators with an air-purifying filter), employers must
ensure that the assigned protection factor is appropriate to the mode of operation in which the
respirator is being used.

Notes:
1. Employers may select respirators assigned for use in higher workplace concentrations of a
hazardous substance for use at lower concentrations of that substance, or when required
respirator use is independent of concentration.
2. The assigned protection factors in Table I are only effective when the employer implements a
continuing, effective respirator program as required by this section (29 CFR 1910.134), including
training, fit testing, maintenance, and use requirements.
3. This APF category includes filtering face pieces, and half masks with elastomeric face pieces.
4. The employer must have evidence provided by the respirator manufacturer that testing of these
respirators demonstrates performance at a level of protection of 1,000 or greater to receive an
APF of 1,000. This level of performance can best be demonstrated by performing a WPF or
SWPF study or equivalent testing. Absent such testing, all other PAPRs and SARs with
helmetslhoods are to be treated as loose-fitting face piece respirators, and receive an APF of25.
5. These APFs do not apply to respirators used solely for escape. For escape respirators used in
association with specific substances covered by ~2J;·FR...!21Q suQrutILl., employers must refer to
the appropriate substance-specific standards in that subpart. Escape respirators for other IDLH
atmospheres are specified by ~9 CFR 1910.134 ((!}(]}[ill.

  APPENDIX [j..,.. END QFSERVICE UFEAND CARTRIDGE CHANGE SCHEDULE
  Cartridge Change Out Policy
  Cartridges for gases and vapors with manufacturer-provided End of Service Life Indicators (ESLls) may
  be used until it is indicated that the cartridge has expired and needs to be replaced. Where cartridges do
  not have ESLls, cartridges may only be used a single time ~ after use, cartridges shall be discarded.

  Employees must also replace cartridges if they experience odor, taste or a sense of irritation when
  wearing an air-purifying respirator. Additionally, particulate and mist cartridges must be changed if the
  breathing resistance increases significantly.

  Cartridge End of Service Life Estimation
  As noted above, some cartridges used for gases and vapors (such as ammonia and hydrochloric
  acid/hydrogen chloride) may not have End Of Service Life indicators. However, based on expected
  exposure levels and known work activities, the above Change Out Policy can serve as an alternate
  method to ensure employee protection when using those organic vapor cartridges.

  As an extra measure) cartridge life can also be estimated using cartridge manufacturer computer
  programs (if available) to estimate service life of each type of cartridge used when exposure is equal to
  IDLH concentrations. This is a very protective approach, since air-purifying respirators are not allowed
  to be worn in IDLH atmospheres. However, even at an IDLH concentration, employee tasks generally do
  not 1ast longer tIJan t h       I

APPENDIXE- USERSEALCHECK PROCEDURES
User Seal Check Procedurcs. The individual who uses a tight-fitting respirator is to perform a
user seal check to ensure that an adequate seal is achieved each time the respirator is put on.
Either the positive and negative pressure checks listed in this appendix. or the respirator
manufacturers recommended user seal check method shall be used. User seal checks are not
substitutes for qualitative or quantitative fit tests.

I.   Face piece Positive and/or Negative Pressure Checks

     A. Positive pressure check. Close off the exhalation valve and exhale gently into the face
     piece. The face fit is considered satisfactory if a slight positive pressure can be built up inside
     the face piece without any evidence of outward leakage of air at the seaL For most respirators
     this mcthod of leak testing requires the wearer to first remove the exhalation valve cover
     before closing off the exhalation valve and then carefully replacing it after the tcst

     B. Negative pressure check. Close ofI the inlet opening of the canister or cartridge(s) by
     covering with the palm of the hand(s) or by replacing the filter seal(s). inhale gently so that
     the face piece collapses slightly, and hold the breath for ten seconds. The design of the inlet
     opcning of some cartridges cannot be effectively covered with the palm of the hand. The test
     can be performed by covering the inlet opening of the cartridge with a thin latex or nitrile
     glove. If the face piece remains in its slightly collapsed condition and no inward leakage of
     air is detected, the tightness of the respirator is considered satisfactory.

II. Manufacturer's Recommended User Seal Check Procedures

     The respirator manufacturer's recommended procedures lor performing a user seal check may
     be used instead of the positive and/or negative pressure check procedures provided that the
     employer demonstrates that the manufacturer's procedures are equally effective.

          ..                                       REF.ERENCE DOCUMENTS
      Document Number                                                             Document Title
      OSHA 2.YCFRL91095                    Occupational Noise Exposure
                       Documents referenced Tn thzs procedure are applzcahle 10 the extent .specijlcd herem.
                                                                                                               ..

1.              PURPOSE
                The purpose of this procedure is to establish, implement, and maintain an effective
                hearing protection program. This program meets the requirements of the OSHA
                Standard.

2.              SCOPE
                This procedure applies to all sites operated by Wheelabrator Technologies Inc, to the
                extent applicable.

3.              DEFINITIONS AND ACRONYMS
                ·    ACGm                       American Conferencc of Governmental Industrial Hygienists

                ·    AIMS                       Accident and Injury Management System. WM electronic
                                                record keeping database accessible through WMVisor.

                ·    NRR                       Noise Reduction Rating




                     HARD COPY is CO;-,;SIDEH£,D REf'ERE"CF: O:'\'LV, VERIFY IlEViSfO:" f:" 0-30:"1: BEFORE CSF.

                    PROPRIETARY DATA NOTICE TO ALL RECENING THIS DOCUMENT
The infonnation contained in this document was developed at the private expense of Vv'heelabrator Technologies, Inc. The contents are deemed
proprietary and all rights are reserved, Any submission is in a spirit of confidence and acceptance is deemed to be an acknowledgment of the
confidential relationship. Infonnation contained hereon not lawfully obtained from another source shall not be released, duplicated, used or
disclosed in whole or in part for any procurement or manufacturing purpose without the prior \vntten penllissiol1 of the president, Whee1abrator
teclmologies, Inc


                                                                   C-24
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                            Page #:
                   1                        Hearing Conservation Program                                                             2   of   14

            ·      STS                         Standard Threshold Shift. A Standard Threshold Shift is
                                               defined as a change in hearing levels when compared with the
                                               baseline audiogram of an average of 10dB or more at 2000,
                                               3000 and 4000 Hz in either ear. A Standard Threshold Shift
                                               that is determined to be work-related is an OSHA-Recordable
                                               illness, provided there is a 25dB loss in the affected ear or
                                               ears.
4.          RESPONSIBILITIES
            4.1.       Plant Manager
                       4.1.1. Has primary responsibility for the execution of the Hearing Conservation
                              Program within the facility.
                       4.1.2. Ensure employees are trained in the hazards and requirements of the Hear-
                              ing Conservation Program.
                       4.1.3. Notify OHS Management of any changes in controls, environment or
                              process that would necessitate reevaluation of the noise levels and hearing
                              protection requirements.
            4.2.       OHS Management
                       4.2.1. Primary responsibility for establishment, implementation and maintenance
                              of the Hearing Conservation Program.
                       4.2.2. Enter sound level meter data and dosimetry into the corporate medical da-
                              tabase.
                       4.2.3. Evaluate and identify hearing protection that provides for most effective
                              attenuation.
                       4.2.4. Post a copy of the OSHA Occupational Noise Exposure Standard
                                  29 erR 1.910.95 or equivalent state plan program in the workplace avail-
                                 able to all employees.
                       4.2.5. Provide copies of records upon request by employees.
            4.3.       Operations / Maintenance Manager
                       4.3.1. Modify JHAs where necessary, as sound level meter data and dosimetry
                              results arc obtained.
                       4.3.2. Identify employees to participate in the noisc measurement programs
                       4.3.3. Responsible for conducting routine inspections of equipment and mate-
                              rials, evaluating procedures and observing employee work practices to en-
                              sure that appropriate hearing protection is being used.

5.          PROCEI)URE
            5.1        NOISE LEVEL SURVEYS
                       5.1.1    Noise Level Surveys shall be conducted by a qualified Industrial Hygiene
                                Consultant for the purpose of establishing area and task-specific hearing
                                protection requirements.
                       5.!'2    Noise Level Survey results shall be documented by the IH Consultant and
                                submitted to OHS Management in accordance with the scope of work.
                       5.!.3    The Noise Level Survey Report shall contain at a minimum the following
                                criteria:
                                         ·   Location of the noise measurement (e.g., elevation 46 @ fan
                                             motor)
                                         ·   The distance the measurement was taken from the noise source
                                             (e.g., measurement collected 5 feet from the fan motor)
                                         ·   The height of the measurement in relation to the noise source
                                             (collect samples at a height of approximately 5 feet; the direction
                                             of the sound level meter microphone must point toward the noise
                                             sonrce)
                                         ·   Describe what activities arc occurring in the plant that could
                                             influence the noise level measurements (e.g., dnring sound level
                                             measurements, boiler 2 was down, grinding operations were
                                             occurring 5 fect away from where sound level measnrements were
                                             collected)

                       5.1.4    Areas or specific tasks without Noise Level Survey data shall be
                                considered as Hearing Protection Required.
                       5.1.5    All Noise Level Surveys shall be conducted using a sound level meter
                                meeting the standards and settings listed below:
                                         ·   ANSI S 1.4 standards for a Type 1 or 2 sound level meter
                                         ·   An A-weighted network
                                         ·   A slow meter response setting

                       5.1.6    At a minimum, areas and tasks with noise levels over 95dBA shall be
                                evaluated for the feasibility of noise reduction.

            5.2       SURVEY FREQUENCY AND AREA SCOPE
                      Once the Noise Level Survey has been completed, it need not be repeated unless a
                      change to equipment or operations occurs. For each Noise Level Survey, survey at
                      least the following areas and pieces of equipment:
                          · Boiler and Turbine/Generator Buildings and Structures.
                          · Auxiliary Areas and Related Equipment, including Tipping Floors and
                              Fuel Yards, Metals Recovery and Ash Loading/Unloading Areas, Water
                              Treatment Facilities, etc.
                          · Stationary Diesel-Fired Equipment.
                          · "Yellow Iron" and other Mobile Eqnipment.
                          · Ash Monolllls and Transfer Stations, including related equipment.

            5.3       SURVEYING SPECIFIC TASKS
                      Noise Level Surveys shall include testing of specific noise-generating tasks,
                      particularly when those tasks are performed in otherwise exempted Hearing
                      Protection Areas (sec Exempt Hearing Protection Areas) for determination of
                      Hearing Protection and Double Hearing Protection requirements. Typical
                      examples include jack-hammering, electric-arc cutting, using vacuum truck hose
                      (squeals), working within 25 feet of operating yellow iron equipment, working
                      around operating safety pressure relief valves, working in the vicinity of steam
                      blows and when performing other noise-generating activities where you must raise
                      your voice to be heard.

            5.4       HEARING PROTECTION DESIGNATIONS
                      Based on Noise Level Surveys, areas and tasks shall be designated as described
                      below.

                      5.4.1. Hearing protection with a mInimum protection rating of 29 NRR
                             (noise rednction rating) shall be worn AT ALL TIMES by persons
                             working on Wheelabrator sites. A posting at the entrance to the site shall
                             inform entrants of this mandatory requirement. Certain areas within the
                             site may be exempted as described in section 5.4.4 below.
                      5.4.2. Douhle Hearing Protection Required Areas: Areas with noise levels
                             above 95dBA shall be posted at the entrance to the areas as Double
                             Hearing Protection Required areas.
                      5.4.3. Douhle Hearing Protection Required Tasks: Specific tasks with noise
                             levels above 95dBA shall be designated as Double Hearing Protection
                             Required tasks.

            5.5       NOISE DOSIMETRY SURVEYS

                      Noise Dosimetry Surveys shall be performed by a qnalified Industrial Hygiene
                      Consultant. The Surveys shall be:
                      5.5.1      Perfonned for each non-administrative job classification including the
                                 Operations Manager, Maintenance Manager and Shift Supervisor during
                                 normal operating conditions. Nonnal operations represent 95% or more of
                                 the actual conditions and therefore are representative of typical noise
                                 exposure in the workplace.
                      5.5.2      Used for purposes of comparison with rq,'Ulatory standards to determine
                                 participation in audiometric testing and training programs.
                      5.5.3      Conducted for representative period of the employee's nomlal work-shift.
                      5.5.4      Condueted using dosimeters meeting ANSI S 1.25 standards, programmed
                                 as specified by the manufacturer for OSHA compliance monitoring and
                                 calibrated before use.
                      5.5.5      Noise Dosimetry Survey results shall be:
                                          ·   Noise Dosimetry results shall be documented by the IH Consultant
                                              and submitted to OHS Management in accordance with the scope
                                              of work.
                                          ·   Communicated to employees individually within 30 days after
                                              sampling has occurred.
                                          ·   Entered into the Medical Records database after receipt of the final
                                              Noise Dosimetry Report.

                                 their hearing protection.

                                          ·   12 hour TWA at or above 83 dBA

                      5.7.2      Employees included in the hearing conservation program will complete an
                                 annual audiogram in accordance with the Medical Surveillance Program.
                                 It is the responsibility of each facility to schedule the annual audiograms.
                                 The audiograms shall be provided at no cost to the employee. An
                                 audiologist will review and interpret all baseline and annual audiograms.

            5.8       EVALUATION OF AUDIOGRAMS AND OSHA STS RECORDABILITY

                      5.8.1      An OSHA Significant Threshold Shift (STS) occurs when the employee
                                 has experienced an STS in one or both ears AND the employee has an
                                 average hearing level of 25 decibels (dB) at the frequency level of 2000,
                                 3000, and 4000 Hertz (Hz).
                      5.8.2      An employee who sustains a significant threshold shift as defined by
                                 OSHA will be referred to the contract medical provider or an audiologist
                                 for a repeat audiogram within 30 days to confirm or deny the STS. For
                                 further processing detail, see section 5.8.4.
                      5.8.3      If the repeat hearing tcst confirms an OSHA STS, then the employee will
                                 be referred to an audiologist for a comprehensive hearing evaluation to
                                 determine if the shift in hearing is considered work related. The OSHA
                                 significant threshold shift will be recorded manually into AIMS as an
                                 OSHA Recordable []]ness when it is the audiologist's opinion that the
                                 change in hearing conld possibly be related to noise exposure at work.
                      5.S.4      All audiograms shall be processed in the following manner:
                                          ·   An audiologist reviews audiograms.
                                          ·   Employees with an OSHA STS are referred for a repeat audiogram
                                              within 30 days of the initial audiogram. If the employee fails to
                                              complete a repeat hearing test within the 30-day period, the STS
                                              must be manually entered into AIMS.
                                          ·   If the retest does not confim1 an OSHA STS, then no further action
                                              is required. If the retest confirms an OSHA STS.
                                          ·   A confirmed OSHA STS must be manually entered into AIMS as a
                                              "Non-OSHA Recordable, Noise Induced Hearing Loss Illness".
                                              Note: "OSHA Recordable" is not selected in AIMS until an
                                              audiologist determines that the hearing loss is related to work.
                                          ·   The Wheelabrator Medical Department refers the employee to a
                                              local audiologist for a comprehensive hearing evaluation as
                                              required by OSHA.

APPENOIXA - HEARING CON$ERVATIONTRAININ.G OUTLINE

TRAINING CONTENTS

Each Plant's training will include the following infom1ation:
   · Explanation of the occupational noise standard
   · Effects of noise on hearing
   · Purpose and procedures of audiometric testing
   · Purpose, advantages, disadvantages and attenuation of various types of hearing protectors
       as well as information on sci ection, fitting, usc and care
   · Discussion of non-occupational and recreational hearing loss and effect of aging

NOISE LEVEL MEASUREMENTS

Noise level measurements surveys are made with a sound level meter or dosimeter for the
purpose of:
   · Identifying areas or tasks where additional hearing protection is required
   · Measuring employee exposure to noise during an average work day
   · Assisting in selecting appropriate hearing protection
   · Identifying work areas that exceed the action level and reduce these levels with
       engineering controls, equipment maintenance or modification

Describe "Hearing Protection" (Ear Plugs OR Ear MutTs) and Double Hearing Protection (Ear
Plugs AND Ear Muffs)

Review noise level maps of the facility and identify areas where Double Hearing Protection is
required.

Discuss why Double Hearing Protection Areas are posted with signs.

Identify job classifications and tasks that require hearing protection to be wom at all times.

AUDIOMETRIC TESTS

     ·      The purpose of audiometric testing is to identify the progression of occupational hearing
            loss so that steps ean be taken to stop it The best approach is to identify a temporary
            hearing loss before it becomes permanent,
     ·      Baseline audio grams will be performed within 6 months of employment.
     ·      Annual audiograms will be performed when an employee is exposed to noise exceeding:
                o 8-hr TWA at nr above 85dBA OR
                o 12-hr TWA at or above 83dBA
     ·      Annual audiograms will be compared to the employee's baseline audiogram. Ifthe annual
            audiogram shows a standard threshold shift, a retest will be performed within 30 days,
            The Audiologist will review the audiogram and determine whether there is a need lor
            further evaluation. If the comparison of the tests confirms a standard threshold shift, the
            employee shall be infonned in writing within 2 I days of the determination.

To prevent hearing loss, it is critical that hearing protection is worn when exposed to high
noise levels - on and off the job. Don't forget to wear hearing protection at home when:
    · Working with power tools or other lond equipment
    · Mowing the lawn or using weed trimmers, chain saws, etc.
   · Using ATV's, dirt bikes, when at race tracks, while on motor boats
   · Practicing with your band
    · Participating in shooting sports

APPENDIX B,.. NOISE REDUCTION RATING,ATTENUATION, AND DE-RATING

NOISE REDUCTION RATING (NRR)
Manufacturers of hearing protection assign a Noise Reduction Rating (NRR) to each type of
hearing protector. The NRR is an indication of the relative level of protection providcd by the
plug or muff. The higher the NRR, the more protection the equipment provides. The NRR is
determiued under ideal laboratory conditions and should not be nsed as a direct measurement of
the protection that each wearer will receive.

ATTENUA nON

Attenuation indicates the amount of noise reduction obtained by wearing a protector. In other
words, attenuation means the amount of sound that will be absorbed or repelled by the protective
device being worn. Judging the relative amount of noise reduction or attenuation provided by
insert and semi-insert hearing protection devices can be achieved by inserting the devices and
listening to the volume level of your own voice. Generally, the amount of attennation provided
by different types of insert or semi-insert devices which occlnde (seal) the opening to the car
canals can be uniquely judged by each wearer.

The tcchnique is simple: insert the device and listen to the volume or loudness level of your
voice. Since this vocal signal represents the lower range of frequencies, 2000 Hz and below
primarily, the relative loudness can be easily judged even among those who have a rather
significant amount of hearing loss. The softer the level of your voice, the greater the amount of
hearing protection being delivered by the device being tested.

This simple technique allows each uscr to judgc the relative performance of diffcrent devices as
well as when using different hearing protection device insertion methods andior wearing
techniques. This offers important clues: you can compare the relative effectiveness for different
devices, different methods of use or insertion (deep vs. shallow insertion of a plug, for example)
and differenccs betwecn right and left car fittings. These comparisons should be pcrforn1ed in
relatively quiet surroundings.

confidential relationship. lnfonnation contained hereon not laVvlully obtained from another source shall not be reJeased, duplicated, used or
