                                                                  C-35
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                            Page #:

                1                           Hearing Conservation Program                                                             13 of 14

DE-RATING

Hearing conservation professionals have used special equipment in the field to mimic the
procedures for cvaluating hearing protector attenuation in the laboratOlY. A series of studies
using a variety of hearing protectors has shown that the average attenuation that people receive in
the workplace is only about one-third to one-half the attenuation that laboratory subjects receive.
In addition, the variability among wearers, as shown by the standard deviation, is two to three
times greater than in the laboratory. It appears that the differences between field and laboratory
results are greater for plugs than for mutTs, although the foam plugs appear to perform somewhat
better than most of the other plug varieties.

One of the consequences of this disparity between the NRR and actual field attenuation is
reflected in a 1983 enforcement memo issued by OSHA's Office of Health Compliance
Assistance. Based on OSHA's enforcement guidelines, the memo instructs federal OSHA
inspectors to de-rate the hearing protector's NRR by 50 percent (divide the NRR in half).

DE-RATING CALCULATIONS

Use the following calculations to estimate the attenuation afforded to a noise-exposcd employee
in an actual work environment by plugs, muffs or a combination of both.

 USE OF SINGLE HEARING PROTECTION - PLUGS OR MUFFS

 Estimated Actual Noise Level (dBAI" (Noise exposure in dBAI                                [(0.5) x (NRR-7dbl 1


I. Subtract 7dB from the NRR to correct for using A-weighted sound level metcr
   measurements.

2. To adjust for workplace conditions, apply a safety factor of 50%.

            Example: A sound level meter measurement was recordcd at 94dBA. The facility had
            purchased insert hearing protection having a NRR of 31. What would be the employee's
            exposure while working in this area')
                                 =   94dBA         [0.5 X (31         7)]
                                 = 94dBA - [0.5 X 24]
                                 =   94dBA-12

            Answer: 82dBA is the employee's noise exposure wearing this hearing protection.




                 HAH!) COPY IS CO:'\SiDERED         REf'fo~R'E~CE   O:"LY. VERIfY REViSIO?-J       r~   O-BOX BE.FORE    C~E


              PROPRIETARY DATA NOTICE TO ALL RECENING THIS DOCUMENT
The information contained in this document was developed at the private expense of\Vheelabrator Technologies, Inc. The contents are deemed
proprietary and an  rights are reserved. A.ny submission is in a spirit of confidence and acceptance is deemed to be an acknowledgment of the
confidential relationship. InfOimation contained hereon not lav,f..l1Jy obtained from another source shall not be released, duplicated, used or
disclosed in whole or in part for any procurement or manufacturing purpose without the prior \"Titten permission of the president, Wheelabrator
teclmologies, Inc.


                                                                    C-36
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                            Page #:

                1                           Hearing Conservation Program                                                             14 of 14

 USE OF DOUBLE HEARING PROTECTION - PLUGS AND MUFFS

 Estimated Actual Noise Level (dBA) = (Noise exposure in dBA) - [(0.5) x (NRR-7db) + 5]

I. Subtract 7dB from the NRR to correct for using A-weighted measurements.

2. To adjust for workplace conditions, apply a safety factor of 50%.

3. Add 5dB to the field-adjusted NRR to account for the use of the second hearing protector.

            Example: A sound level meter measurement was recorded at 98dBA. This area requires
            double hearing protection (greater than 95dBA). The facility had purchased insert hearing
            protection having a NRR of 31. What would be the employee's exposure while working
            in this area wearing double hearing protection?
                                 = 98dBA          [0.5 X (31 - 7) + 5]
                                 =   98dBA - [0.5 X 24 + 5]
                                 = 98dBA - 12 + 5
            Answer: SldBA is the employee's noise exposure wearing double hearing protection

            Note: When using Double Hearing Protection, an increase in attenuation of 5 is used
            based on scientific studies. However, certain brands and types of ear muffs may afford
            attenuation greater than 5 when combined with insert protection (ear plugs).

                                                                         C-38
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                          Page #:
                   1                        Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                    2   of   30

1.          PURPOSE
            This procedure serves as written certiiication identifying the mmmmm personal
            protective equipment required for general work perfonned at all Wheelabrator sitcs, as
            dctennined by a complete hazard assessment performed by the OHS Management team
            and veritled by the approvers of this docnment.
            Minimnm PPE requirements include:
                · Head Protection
                · Eye and Face Protection
                · Hand Protection
                · Foot Protection
                · Protective Clothing

            Additional PPE requirements and task specitlc hazard assessment certification are
            documented on Job Hazard Analyses (JHAs) in accordance with )1i~:2lJl'i::L1J~!'lt'.J:I·.ill::m!
            bnalvsis PrOQHlll1.

            Additional requirements can be found in the following procedures:
               · Hearing Conservation Program
               · Respiratory Protection Program
               · Electrical Power Generation Program
               · Fall Protection Program

2.          SCOPE
            This procedure applies to all sites operated by Wheelabrator Technologies Inc, to the
            extent applicable.

3.          RESPONSIBILITIES
            3.1.       Plant Manager
                       3.1.1. Has primary responsibility for ensuring nse of PPE in accordance with this
                              procedure.
                       3.1.2. Ensure employees are trained in the use ofPPE.
                       3.1.3. Notify OHS Management of any changes in chemicals, controls,
                              environment or processes iliat would necessitate reevaluation of the PPE
                              program.
                       3.1.4. Purchasing of PPE in accordance with the requirements of this procedure
                              using purchasing approved vendors.

technologies, Inc.


                                                                  C-39
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                             Page #:
                   1                          Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                     3 of 30

            32.        OHS Management
                       3.2.1. Primary responsibility as the identified competent persons                                                      for
                              establishment, implementation and maintenance oflhe PPE program.
                       3.2.2. Responsible for conducting hazard assessment to identifY the requirements
                              for PPE.
            3.3.       Operations / Maintenance Manager
                       3.3.1. Ensnre Job Safety Briefings and/or JHA reviews are conducted with
                              employees before performing tasks where hazard assessment identifies
                              PPE requirements differing from general minimum PPE.
            3.4.       Sr. Technicians
                       3.4.1. At landfills and transfer stations responsible for the administration and
                              execution of this procedure in accordance with the directions of OHS
                              Management.
            3.5.       Purchasing
                       3.5.1. Pnrchase PPE that meet all requirements as established by OHS
                              Management from approved vendors
            3.6.       Supervisors
                       3.6.1. Direct and evaluate employees in the implementation of PPE program.


4.          PROCEDURE

            5.1        TRAINING
                       All employees whose jobs require Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) shall be
                       trained in the requirements of this proccdnre and in the use and maintenance of
                       job-required PPE before being allowed to perform work requiring the PPE.
                       5.1.1     Employees shall be trained to know:
                                          ·   When PPE is necessary
                                          ·   What PPE is necessary
                                          ·   How to properly don, doff, adjust and wear PPE
                                          ·   PPE limitations
                                          ·   Proper care, maintenance, useful life and disposal

                       5.1.2     Employees shall be retrained whenever changes in the workplace (such as
                                 operations, type of PPE required, etc.) render previous training obsolete.



                   HARD COPY IS    co;\smnu:n REfERE:"JCF (r'LV, VEIUVY IU::VlSHY, IN 0-130X BEFORE CSE

                                                                   C-40
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                           Page#:
                  1                           Personal Protective Eqnipment (PPE)                                                   4 of 30

                      5.1.3      Facility management shall verify that each affected employee has received
                                 and understood the required training through a written certification
                                 containing the name of each employee trained, the date of training and the
                                 identification of the subject.

            5.2       GENERAL PPE REQUIREMENTS
                      5.2.1      Minimum PPE requirements when working on company property unless
                                 exempted as listed in specific sections below:
                                          ·   Safety Shoes
                                          ·   Hard Hat
                                          ·   Safety Glasses with permanently attached side shields
                                          ·   Hearing Protection
                                          ·   Respiratory protection as required
                      5.2.2      Only approved PPE meeting Whee1abrator's specifications shall bc used.
                      5.2.3      Areas where PPE is routinely required shall be posted.
                      5.2.4      PPE sball be inspected before usc. Damaged or defective personal
                                 protective equipment shall be repaired or replaced before use.
                      S.2.5      Replace PPE per manufacturer's recommendations. (i.e. Hardhats should
                                 be replaced every 5 years).
                      5.2.6      PPE and protective clothing shall be kept clean. PPE subjected to gross
                                 contamination shall be cleaned or replaced.
                      5.2.7      Protective clothing should be distributed for individual use whenever
                                 possible. Items such as protective clothing, hard hats, eye protection,
                                 hearing protection, and respiratory protection and safety shoes should not
                                 be shared between employees until it has been properly cleaned and
                                 sanitized 111 accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.
                                 Contaminated PPE that cannot be cleaned shall be disposed of in an
                                 appropriate manner.
                      5.2.8      Loose-fitting or hanging items that present a hazard around rotating tools
                                 and machinery or conductive items tbat present a hazard around electrical
                                 lines and equipment shall not be worn (examples include jewelry, chains,
                                 key rings).
                      5.2.9      Hair shall be secured (Jut of the way if it could become entangled in
                                 machinery or obscure vision.

                  1                               Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                               5 of 30

            5.3       HEAD PROTECTION
                      Hard hats shall meet the requirements of ~,=~~-" for both general (Class G)
                      and electrical (Class E) use.
                      5.3.1      Hard hats shall be worn at all times on Company property except as
                                 follows:
                                 Unless an overhead or bump hazard exists or unless required by a task or
                                 IHA, the following areas are exempt [rom mandatory hard hat use:
                                          ·    Control Rooms, administration buildings, offices
                                          ·    Shops, Labs
                                          ·    Lunch and break areas, shower/locker and rest rooms
                                          ·    Scale houses, Continuous Emissions Monitoring System (CEMS)
                                               buildings and crane pulpits

                      5.3.2     Hard hats shall be worn with the brim forward at all times, unless
                                otherwise instructed by a Wheelabrator Supervisor.
                      5.3.3      Hard hats shall be worn when using welding hoods/masks, aluminized-
                                 reflective hoods, arc-flash hoods and sandblast hoods, uuless otherwise
                                 instructed by a Whcclabrator Supervisor.
            5.4       EYE AND FACE PROTECTION
                      5.4. I     All          eye   and   face      protection         shall     meet       the     requirements            of
                                Al':L~        Z   gUo
                      5.4.2     Safety glasses with permanently-attached side-shields shall be worn at all
                                times on Company property except as follows:
                                Unless an eye hazard exists or unless required by a task or JHA, the
                                following areas are exempt from mandatory safety glasses usc:
                                          ·    Control Rooms, administration buildings, offices
                                          ·    Lunch and break areas, shower/locker and rest rooms
                                          ·    Scale houses and crane pUlpits

                      5.4.3     Primary eye protection (either safety glasses with pern1anently-attached
                                side-shields or impact-resistant goggles) shall be worn when using face
                                shields and welding hoods. A full-face respirator with an impact-resistant
                                lens offers equivalent protection as goggles.
                                          ·    Prescription contact lenses may be worn under primary eye
                                               protection, unless otherwise prohibited for a specific task or area.

                      5.4.4      Tinted safety sunglasses are NOT pennitted to be worn inside of buildings.
                                 Tinted safety sunglasses are pennitted to be worn outside of buildings
                                 based on task or location specific hazard assessment.

                      5.4.5      If prescription lenses are required in perfonnance of an activity they shall
                                 be worn. Spectacle kits for goggles and respirator masks may be required.

                      5.4.6      Purchases of prescription safety glasses and respirator spectacle kits shall
                                 be pre-approved by Supervision in accordance with the HR procedures,
                                 using [!\!l}~rQtl2:12.].Q~:@:l2QI1tt~J'li£i.(Iill!i2!Lfuli£l.:d.ililB~..illl1lliuiz.£1:i!;'!l.
                      5.4.7      Goggles shall be worn when working or around others working in areas
                                 containing airbome ashlfly ash, dry chemical or dust hazards (e.g., windy
                                 conditions; positioned bclow ash-laden parts or equipment; ash or dry
                                 chemical handling, such as lime).

                      5.4.8      Indirect-vented goggles and a full face shield shall be wom when
                                 conducting tasks where actual or potential liquid chemical splash hazards
                                 exist (e.g., pumping or pouring chemicals, SDA lance change out).
                                          ·   Indirect-vented goggles shall be wom when entering areas where
                                              others are conducting tasks, such as those listed above.
                                          ·   Indirect-vented goggles and a full [ace shield shall be wom when
                                              in close proximity to others conducting tasks, such as those listed
                                              above.

                      5.4.9      Indirect-vented goggles and a full face shield shall be wom when
                                 conducting tasks where actual or potential pressurized air hazards (e.g.,
                                 using an air lance) or pressurized liquid hazards exist (e.g., tightening a
                                 fitting on a pressurized hydranlic system or using a power washer).

                      5.4.10 Primary eye protection and a face shield shall be wom when grinding,
                             chipping or sawing.

                      5.4.11 Electrical-Qualiflcd Persons shall wear electrical-protective face shields or
                             hoods appropriate for the electrical hazard.

                      5.4.12 Welding helmets or hoods or handheld shields with the appropriate shade
                             lenses to protect against light radiation shall be worn when electric arc
                             welding or cutting.

                      5.4.13 Hot Work
                                  Persons pertonning gas welding and oxygen cutting shall wear welding
                                  helmets or goggles with lenses meeting the minimum specified shade
                                  requirements:

                  1                           Personal Proteetive Equipment (PPE)                                                   8   of   30

            5.5       HAND PROTECTION
                      5.5.1      Leather gloves shall be worn for general protection against dirt and
                                 abrasion during routine work.
                      5.5.2      Gloves shall NOT be worn around rotating machine shop tools such as
                                 lathes and drill presses.

                      5.5.3      Chemical-resistant gloves shall be worn for protection against chemicals.
                      5.5.4      Chemical-resistant disposable gloves shall be worn for protection when
                                 handling Lab test reagents and for potential exposure to bloodborne
                                 pathogens. Gloves shall be properly discarded upon task completion.
                      5.5.5      Welding gloves shall be worn for protection against hot surfaces while
                                 performing Hot Work activities.
                      5.5.6      Aluminized or high-temperature gloves shall be worn for protection
                                 against hot ash.
                      5.5.7      Electrical-Qualified Persons shall use voltage-rated gloves and leather
                                 protectors appropriate for the electrical hazard.
                      5.5.8     Cut-resistant gloves shall be worn for protection against cuts, punctures,
                                and sharp objects. Sec Appendix C for additional information.
                                          ·   Cut/puncture resistant gloves shall be purchased from Hex Armor
                                              as defined for waste management use.

            5.6       FOOT PROTECTION

                      5.6.1     Safety shoes shall mcet the requirements of or =='-'-'-"'-='---"'."'. '--==2."-
                                approved with an oblique or rounded toe.
                      5.6.2     All employees working on Company property in other than an office
                                environment shall wear safety shoes.
                      5 .6.3    Safety shoes shall be 6               I 0 inches high with leather upper construction.
                      5.6.4     Safety shoes shall have a defined heel and slip-resistant soles with treads,
                                also resistant to heat and chemical exposures.
                      5.6.5      Puncture-resistant soles arc required when working in the following areas:
                                      ·       Tipping Floors & RDF Processing areas
                                      ·       Metal recovery areas
                                      ·       Ash monofills
                                      ·       Other areas with exposure to sharps, cuts and pnnctures

                  1                           Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                  9 of 30

                      5,6,6      The selection of what job classifications and/or employees arc required to
                                 wear puncture-resistant safety shoes shall be based on a hazard evaluation,
                                 including such details as previous history of puncture incidents, actual and
                                 potential hazards and frequency of exposure, as determined by OHS
                                 management.
                      5,6,7      Chemical-resistant over-boots shall be worn for exposures to hazardous
                                 chemicals,
                      5,6,8      Metatarsal foot protectors shall be worn for jackhammer and chainsaw
                                 work.
                      5,6,9     Electrical-Qualified Persons shall wear non-conductive boots and use non-
                                conductive mats for work on or around energized conductors appropriate
                                for the electrical hazard,
                      5,6,10 Purchases of safety shoes shall be pre-approved by plant manager in
                             accordance with the HR procedures, using FM-WOHS-191O,S_'l!mart-l- J


            5,7       PROTECTIVE CLOTHING AND APPAREL
                      5,7, I    All non-administrative employees working in other than an office
                                environment and as per site-specific requirements shall wear Company-
                                provided uniforms, Company uniforms shall be long sleeved and
                                constructed of at least 5-ounce, 100% cotton or equivalent material.
                      5,7.2     Uniforms shall be correctly sized, Loose-fitting clothing that may present a
                                hazard around rotating tools and machinery is prohibited,
                                          ·   Shirttails shall be tucked in at all times,
                                          ·   Shirtsleeves shall be long sleeved and not be rolled up in areas
                                              where there is potential exposure to chemical or thermal bums,
                                          ·   Employees shall not contaminate administrative areas, lunch areas
                                              or clean-side change rooms with ash, dust or dirty clothes and
                                              equipment.
                                      ·       Ash-laden uniforms shall not be taken out of the plant,

                      5,7.3     All personnel shall wear high-visibility reflective vests when working:
                                          ·   On Tipping Floors
                                          ·   In other areas with exposure to vehicular traffic, particularly:
                                                  o Fuel Yards
                                                  o In ash and metals recovery loading/unloading areas
                                                  o Along roadways and travel outside of designated walkways
                                                      between admin building and plant.

                                                                  C-46
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                           Page #:
                1                             Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                   10      of   30

                      5.7.4      When using a chainsaw personnel shall wear cut resistant leg protection
                                 such as chaps.
                      5.7.5      Tyvek suits or coveralls shall be worn when working inside boilers, bag
                                 houses, ESP's or in other areas where there is significant exposure to ash,
                                 fuels or lubricants.
                      5.7.6      Thennal protective gear (such as aluminized or NOMEX suits or
                                 coveralls) shall be worn in accordance with JHAs when perfonuing jobs
                                 with potential exposure above 120 degrees Fahrenheit to. See Appendix D
                                 for additional infonnation:
                                          ·   Hot ash
                                          ·   Hot water
                                          ·   Steam

                      5.7.7     Personal cooling/heating apparel (cooling vests, cooling headbands, winter
                                hard hat liners, etc.) shall be used when ambient temperatures cannot be
                                controlled to reduce the potential for heat/cold stress exposures.
                      5.7.8     Chemical-resistant suits or coveralls shall be worn in accordance with
                                JHAs when perlonuing jobs with potential exposure to chemicals,
                                particularly:
                                          ·   During transfer operations and spill response
                                          ·   When working on chemical distribution systems and tanks

                     5.7.9      Chemical-resistant aprons shall be worn lor protection against chemical
                                splash hazards, such as parts cleaning, especially where parts contain
                                chemicals or when part configurations may cause splash.
                      5.7.10 Persons perfonuing Hot Work shall wear appropriate fire-resistant
                             protective clothing (e.g., flame-retardant cotton or "leathers" - gauntlets,
                             aprons, jackets and leg chaps) to protect against sparks, molten metal
                             splash and contact with hot materials.
                     5.7.11 Air-supplied sandblast hoods shall be worn for open sand blasting
                            operations.
                      5.7.12 Knee protectors shall be worn when kneeling on hard surfaces for
                             extended periods of time.
                     5.7.13 Fire-protection gear shall be worn as required by the site-specific Fire
                            Prevention Plan.
                     5.7.14 Electrical-Qualified Persons shall wear electrical-protective clothing,
                            appropriate for the electrical hazard.

                      5.7.15 Cut-resistant apparcl shall be worn for protection against cuts, puuctures,
                             and sharp objects.
            5.8       ELECTRlC ARC PROTECTION

                      5.8.1      Personncl who may be exposed to the hazards of electric arcs or flames
                                 shall NOT wear any clothing (including undergarments) that could
                                 increase the extent of bum injury. Unacceptable clothing includes fabrics
                                 containing acetate, nylon, polyester or rayon unless it can be demonstrated
                                 that the fabric has been treated to withstand the flame or electric arc
                                 conditions that may be encountered. Acceptable clothing includes natural
                                 fabrics (e.g., cotton, wool) and fire-resistant synthetic fabrics (c.g.,
                                 NOMEX). See                  for additional information.
                      5.8.2      NFPA 70E specifies protective clothing requirements for persons
                                 pcrfonning work on energized electrical equipment within the flash
                                 protection boundary. (Flash protection boundaries may also be precisely
                                 calculated as prescrihed in NFP A 70E.)
                      5.8.3      Hazard risk category classifications for tasks pcrforn1ed on energized
                                 electrical equipment are also published in NFPA 70E and are included in
                                 Appendix A of this procedure. (These hazard risk category classifications
                                 may be used or the hazard risk category classification may be precisely
                                 calculated as prescribed in NFPA 70E.)
                      5.8.4      Once the hazard risk category classification for a specific task is
                                 determined, the prescribed protective clothing shall bc worn. Detailed
                                 electric arc protective clothing requirements arc included in       of
                                 this procedure.

            5.9       SHARP OBJECTS PROTECTION
                      The purpose of sharp objects protection policy is to identify potential sources of
                      sharps and sharp materials in the waste stream or processing equipment that may
                      cause injury to personnel if they were to come into contact. This section describes
                      inspection precautions, protective barriers, cleaning and handling techniques to
                      avoid injury from sharp objects. See              for additional information.
                      Millions of Americans use needles (Sharps) to regularly inject prescription
                      medications. Over three billion syringes are discarded into the public solid waste
                      stream every year:
                          · In coffee cans
                          · In plastic bottles
                          · Directly into trash
                          · mto trash recycling containers
                          · mto the toilet
                  HARU COpy IS CO::"SIDERED REFERE:.iCE O:\LV, VERIFY                 REVlS10~     I,\: O-BOX BEFORE CSE

              PROPRIETARY DATA NOTICE TO ALL RECEIVING THIS DOCUMENT
The infonnation contained in this document was developed at the private expense of Wheelabrator Technologies, Inc, The contents are deemed

                                                                  C-48
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                           Page #:
                1                             Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                   12 of 30

                      5.9.1      Sharps and Sharp Objects:
                                 Sharp objects include materials such as the following:
                                          ·   Glass
                                          ·   Nails
                                          ·   Wire
                                          ·   Screws
                                          ·   Syringes
                                          ·   Razor blades
                                          ·   Other metal objects
                                          ·   Wood splinters
                                          ·   Knives

                     5.9.2      Sharp Object Source:
                                The municipal solid waste (MSW) received at the facility may contain
                                sharp ohjects as defined above. The sharp objects may become lodged in
                                numerous locations within the waste processing equipment, which
                                includes receiving on the tipping floor, through the combustion process
                                and the ash management system. See                   for a specific list of
                                typical locations where sharp materials may be encountered.
                                          ·   Develop or revise existing JHAs for tasks in these arcas to reflect
                                              the hazards for sharp objects

                     5.9.3      Protective Barrier
                                Employees shall nevcr handle MSW with unprotected hands. The usc of
                                puncture/cut resistant "WM approved hex armor type gloves" is required
                                for all persollllci who potentially handle MSW as directly by their
                                supervisor or JHA. Always use equipment listed below to touch or handle
                                MSW. Materials or tools designed for the purpose of eliminating personal
                                contact with sharp objects potcntially hidden in a waste stream. For
                                example:
                                    · PPE (i.e puncture/cut resistant gloves)
                                    · Shovel
                                    · Rake
                                    · Pitchfork
                                    · Scraper
                                    · Pike pole
                                    · Broom
                                    · Wash Hose
                                    · Pressure washer
                                    · Hand tool
                HARD COPY IS       co~smERED       REFERE:-':CF: ({'LV. VERIFY REViSiCf,!::" 0-80.\ BEFORE CSE

                                                                 C-49
Revision:                        Title:                                                                                          Page #:

                1                             Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                  13 of 30

                      5.9.4     Personal Protective Equipment
                                PPE is the last line of defense for potential exposures. Engineering
                                controls and administrative controls should bc implemented first where
                                feasible. When PPE is uscd it must be sclected based on the type of actual
                                or potential hazard and accommodate the type of work the employee will
                                be performing. For instance, puncture resistant gloves do not need to be
                                issucd to every employec. Use the correct PPE for the job at hand.
                                Cut/punctnre resistant clothing may not be necessary for every job
                                Examples of PPE that may be selected based on the actual or potential
                                hazards includc:
                                          ·   Puncture/cut resistant shoes
                                          ·   Puncture/cut resistant gloves
                                          ·   Puncture/cut resistant suit
                                          ·   Puncture/cut resistant hood

                      5.9.5     Procedures for Handling Sharp Objects in the Waste Strcam
                                          ·   Always assume sharp objects are present in any waste strcam.
                                          ·   Always use equipment to inspect for sharp objects, never use your
                                              hands, and use PPE that will prcvent cuts and punctures or use
                                              mechanical barriers ifremoval is not an option.
                                          ·   Remove all material (MSW, Ash, Metal, and Glass) from
                                              equipment or immediate arca where cmployee activity will be
                                              prefonncd and dispose of it in another area of the waste stream.
                                          ·   Visually inspect to verify all objects were removed before
                                              proceeding.

                     5.9.6      Bloodbomc Pathogens (BBP)
                                Use universal precautions when handling sharp objects. Universal
                                Precautions is an OSHA-mandated system of infection-control methods.
                                Under this system, the only sensible way to protect employees from blood
                                borne pathogens is by treating all body fluids (OSHA-defined) as
                                potentially infectious. Therefore, everyone needs to protect all points of
                                entry into the body that could be exposed to body fluids while pcrforming
                                job tasks. Points of entry into the body are the mucous membranes of the
                                eyes, nose, and mouth and the skin. For further information refer to
                                WOHS-19lJLLP30 Bloodbomc Pathogens Exposure_Control.

                 1                              Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                     14 of 30

            5.10      CONTRACTORS, VISITORS, AND VENDORS
                      5.10.1 Contractors shall abide by the PPE and apparel requirements described in
                             the Wheelabrator Standard Service Agreement (Contractor Safety
                             Requirements Appendix C ofthe service agreement).
                      5.10.2 Visitors touring Wheelabrator sites shall be provided with the following
                             PPE:
                                           ·    Hard hat - no "bump-caps
                                           ·    Safety glasses (sized to allow wearing over prescription lenses)
                                           ·    Hearing protection (plant personnel will provide brief instructions
                                                on the use of hearing protection; hearing protection is required
                                                except in designated areas.)

                      5.10.3 All visitors must stay on tour routes or other designated transient routes, as
                             instructed by plant personnel. All plant tour routes should have a solid
                             surface (no open grating). No spike high heels or open-toe shoes are
                             pennilted.
            5.11      PLANT ADMINISTRATION, REGIONAL OR CORPORATE PERSONNEL
                      5.1 1.1 Plant Administration, Regional or Corporate personnel and Vendors that
                              remain on designated tour or transient routes shall wear minimum PPE
                              equivalent to visitors.
                      5.11.2 Plant Administratiou, Regional or Corporate personnel and Vendors that
                             do not remain on designated tour or trausient routes shall wear minimum
                             PPE as follows:
                                           ·   Hard hat
                                           ·   Safety glasses
                                           ·   Hearing protection
                                           ·   Safety shoes where there will be potential exposure to foot hazards
                                           ·   Long-sleeved shirts and long pants where there is exposure to
                                               thennal or chemical bums

          General Notes (applicable to entire table):
             · lnfonnation contained in Appendix A is taken from NFPA 70E.
             · Y = Yes (req uired), N = no (not required)
             · Rubber insu lating gloves are gloves rated for the maximum line·to- line vo ltage upon
                 which work will be done.
             · Insulated and insulating hand tools arc rated aud tested for tbe maximum line·to· line vol-
                 tage upon which work will be done, and arc manufactured and tested in accordance with
                 ASTM F 1505, Standard Specification for Insulated and Insul ating Hand Tools.
             · For systems rated less than 1000 volts. the fau lt currents and upstream protective device
                 clearing times are based on an 18 in . working distance.
             · For systems rated I kv and greater, the HazardIRisk Categories arc based on a 36 in.
                 \Vorking distance.

                 1                           Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                       19 of 30

     ·      For equipment protected by upstream current limiting fuses with arcing fault current in
            their current limiting range (l/2 cycle fault clearing time or less), the hazard risk category
            may be reduced by one number.

Specific notes (as referenced in table)
   1. Maximnm of25 kA short circuit available, maximum of 0.03 second (2 cycle) fault clear-
       ing time.
   2. Maximum of 65 kA short circuit available, maximum of 0.03 second (2 cycle) fault clear-
       ing time.
   3. Maximum of 42 kA short circuit available, maximum of 0.33 second (20 cycle) fault
       clearing time.
   4. Maximum of 35 kA short circuit current available, maximum of up to 0.5 second (30
       cycle) fault clearing time.

APP.ENDIXC .,.TYPICAL SHARP$ AR.EA$

Tipping Floor and RD F processing areas
   · On Floor
          o Slipping and falling.
          o Sticking on shoes.
          o Sticking to hose when washing floor
   · On Loader
          o Tires
          o Blades
          o Steps
          o Bucket

Refuse Pit
   · In the refuse

Charging Hopper Deck
  · Floor around Charging Chutes
  · Tops of Charging Chutes
  · Stuck or lodged to flop gate (arch breaker)
  · Stuck on crane grapple when servicing.

Feed Chute
   · Around expansion joints on 3rd floor
   · Leakage through 5th floor around hopper that falls around water jackets and drains and
      the Front air duct.
   · Inside of ram feeder table
   · Hopper for Ram Feeder
   · Inside the feed chute stuck to walls during outage

Boiler
   ·        On grates
   ·        Undergrate hoppers and stuck on carriages
   ·        Sifting Chntcs
   ·        Sifting Chain
                o Stuck to diverter flop gate
                o Stuck to chain
                o Stuck on sprockets
     ·      Sifting Screw

APPENDIX D"'fUGHTEMPERATURETASKS: REQUIRED PPE

     ·      In utilizing the High Temperature Task Charts below, first choose the high temperature
            task that you will be completing in Chart I - High Temperature Tasks.
     ·      Secondly identify the Hazard Risk Category assigned to the task
     ·      Utilizing this number go to Chart 2 - Minimum Required Apparel & PPE and identify all
            the PPE required in the corresponding column to be worn for this task.
     ·      Chart 3 - Protective Apparel Characteristics identifies the characteristics of the apparel
            listed in Chart 2.
     ·      See important notes at the end of this appendix, after the charts.

Chart 1 - High Temperature Tasks

 Notes:
    l. A High Temperature Task is defined as any identified work being conducted that exposes
                  employees to ambient or surface temperatures 2: 120 degrees F.
       2.         In accordance with OSHA, any hazards should be dealt with utilizing the hierarchy of
                  controls, first using feasible engineering, secondly work practices, and then finally PPE
                  for protection.
       3.         The tasks listed are not all-inclusive and address commonly perfonned jobs - add addi-
                  tional site-specific tasks as necessary. Similarly, the specified apparel & PPE identified in
                  the tables are minimum requirements for the task. More protective apparel and equipment
                  may be required based on actual conditions. Always consult task-specific JHA's, WTI
                  supervision, or the Hampton Safety Department if there are any questions concerning the
                  correct protective apparel or PPE for any task.
      4.          Where heat stress or fogging of goggles or respirators are a conccm, evaluate the use of a
                  work/rest regimen, area or personal cooling equipment
       5.         If a task requires the Buddy system, the "Buddy" will need to be at the same level of PPE
                  as the person perfonning the high temperature task unless posted beyond the area of ex-
                  posure (outside the pre-detennined danger zone).

                 1                           Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                       28 of 30

     6. Respiratory protection may be needed for tasks based on potential atmospheric hazards.
         Evaluate potential respiratory hazards and the need for respiratory protection on a case-
         by-case basis.
     7. "View ports" and "covers" are considered to be openings less than 12" in its least dimen-
         sion. Openings 12 inches or greater in its least dimension are considered to be doorways.
     8. Categories I and 3 are based on upper body exposures, while Categories 2 and 4 are
         based on whole body exposures. If actual site conditions for Categories I and 3 tasks re-
         sult in different or additional exposures, protective apparel and PPE willnced to be simi-
         larly upgraded.
     9. Category 0 and 0+ tasks requiring Company-provided cotton unifonn (sleeves rolled
         down) are based on momentary contact exposures up to 300 degrees F. Category I and 2
         tasks requiring NOMEX or equivalent protective apparel are based on momentary contact
         exposures up to 700 deg. F (DuPont reference). Category 3 and 4 tasks requiring alumi-
         nized apparel are based on momentary contact exposures up to 2000 deg. F.
     10. Category I and 2 tasks requiring NOMEX or equivalent protective apparel are based on
         momentary contact exposures up to 700 deg. F (DuPont reference). Category 3 and 4
         tasks requiring aluminized apparel are based on momentary contact exposures up to 2000
         deg. F.
     II. Protective apparel and PPE for Category 3 or 4 on-line or off-line boiler activity tasks
         may be downf,'faded to Category I or 2 tasks (as applicable) if exposure temperatures are
         proven to be reduced to 700 deg. F. or less (such as when boilers and/or ash are cooled).
     12. Protective apparel selection for tasks with high prcssureltemperature steam or t1uids ex-
         posures must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis, considering factors such as tempera-
         ture, pressure, location, and duratiOn/frequency of exposure.
     13. Hard hats are required to be worn under aluminized hoods, unless otherwise instmcted by
         plant supervision.

                1                            Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)                                                      29 of 30

APPENDIX E- REQUIRED SpiLL RESPONSE PPE BY CHEMICAL TYPE

Acetylene
   · Respiratory protection with SCBA
     ·      Safety glasses
     ·      Thermally insulated gloves and clothing if contact with liquid anticipated
Aluminum Sulfate
   · Respiratory protection with HEPA (P3) cartridge if fumes/mists are being generated
     ·      Chemical resistant gloves
     ·      Indirect-vented goggles or full face shield
PCBs Arochlor
  · Full-face respiratory protection with organic vapor and HEPA cartridges or SCBA
     ·      Chemical resistant gloves
     ·      Indirect-vented goggles and full face shield
     ·      Chemical resistant over-boots
     ·      Chemical resistant suit or coveralls
Municipal Waste Combustor Ash
  · Respiratory protection with HEPA (PI OO/N I 00) cartridge if ash dusts are being generated
     ·      Protective Gloves (latex, nitrile or leather)
     ·      Safety glasses or Indirect-vented goggles
Dilution Tank Water / Dump Storage Tank Water / Sump Water / Leachate Treatment Sump
Water / Neutralization Tank Water / Quench Pit Water / Shutdown Wash Water / Turbine
Building Sump Water / Untreated Leachate / Wastewater Storage Tank Water
    · Gloves
     ·      Safety glasses or Indirect-vented goggles
Antifreeze and Coolant / Polytloc AE1703
     ·      Respiratory protection with organic vapors cartridge or SCBA, if fumes/mists are being
            generated
     ·      Chemical resistant gloves
     ·      Indirect-vented goggles and full face shield
     ·      Chemical resistant over-boots
     ·      Chemical resistant suit or coveralls

Gasoline / Oil
     ·      Respiratory protection with organic vapor cartridge if fumes/mists arc being generated
     ·      Chemical resistant gloves
     ·      Indirect-vented goggles
Hydrochloric Acid / Hydrogen Peroxide / Phosphoric Acid / Sodium Hydroxide / Sulfuric Acid
     ·      Respiratory protection with acid gas cartridge or SCBA, if fumes/mists arc being generat-
            ed
     ·      Chemical resistant gloves
     ·      Indirect-vented goggles and full face shield
     ·      Chemical resistant over-boots
     ·      Chemical resistant suit or coveralls
Lime Slurry

     ·      Chemical resistant gloves

     ·      Chemical resistant over-boots
     ·      Chemical resistant suit or coveralls
Urea
     ·      Use SCBA, if mists arc being generated
     ·      Chemical resistant gloves
